Coal is an important issue for Australia. It has helped us enjoy the quality of life we have today and will continue to do so for some time. But a future with coal will lead to environmental disaster. The overwhelming majority of scientists agree we are at a tipping point for the use of fossil fuels. To continue will irreparably poison our atmosphere. My work depicts an arrogant character unwilling to change and unaware of his impending doom. - Louis Pratt, 2015

title: Constructed landscape
description: The Australian landscape has an immense spirituality, which I have evoked in my constructed landscape by using my own language of images, derived from trips to the outback. The inspiration for this work is taken directly from the Australian landscape and my life experience. The images and symbols, which I include in my work, are completely spontaneous and intuitive without using any drawings as a guiding tool. I always try to charge my paintings full of emotion and spirituality, and transport the viewer into a new experience. - Theo Papathomas, 2015

title: Poet
description: My work mostly deals with landscape, memory and the human condition. The paintings are really a personal dialogue. I offer the image and a title; it is then up to the viewer to complete the conversation. In this painting, the calligraphic lines that scrawl across the surface relate to the mystery and elegance of the human mark across the void. It is as though fragments of the written word have broken off from their moorings and float free from the demands of any one language, or from the need to specify any one meaning. - Angus Nivison, 2015

title: Vita in extremis
medium: copper, stainless steel and black steel
description: I started my studies as a biologist and horticulturalist and these passions have stayed with me. Through years of observation, I construct my works from memory rather than reality. My work becomes a meditation on the environment, from the monumentality of landscape to the minute. Vita in extremis investigates the extremities of coastal landscape: the harshness and physicality of its environment as it is repeatedly exposed to the winds. The work reflects the solidarity and strength of a single tree and its antiquity. It evokes a sense of power coupled with fragility. By illustrating the foliage with the roots I hope to illuminate the structure in its entirety, which is often overlooked. - Ulan Murray, 2015

title: Through the circle
description: The works that I am currently painting continue my process of reinterpreting the landscape in a simplified manner. This piece is one of a group of paintings that bring me back to various areas of Sydney – coastal, city or suburbs. Perception and judgment is played out in different areas within the painting, whether that is through the application of paint, flattening of the picture plane or the narrative content unfolding within the painting. - Michael Muir, 2015

title: Terra nullius
description: Atmospheric and mysterious, this work is an invocation of the sacred in all living things. A homage to the deep spirit of land. It draws for inspiration on the vastness of the Australian continent, and the great changing skies above it. By the title I do not mean to endorse the myth of ‘terra nullius’ that scars the relatively recent history of the continent. I mean rather to bring into question the very premise of land ownership. Land, the Earth, cannot belong to anyone; it is we who belong to it. Thus can it be nobody’s land, terra nullius . - Celia Morgan, 2015

title: 'The world of dew is only the world of dew and yet...oh...and yet...' Kobayashi Issa (1763–1828)
medium: brush watercolour painting and black Chinese ink
description: I was searching around Fogg Dam, near Darwin, and recorded unusual plants to put into a study. This same natural beauty surprises us here in the Southern Highlands. Many of the subjects are from Kangaloon and surrounds: winter lichen, seeds, native plants, Aboriginal stones, local birdlife, moths and butterflies. The painting took six months to complete but I enjoy the spirit and detail of these old rainforest areas as a place to work in, with all the abstract forms they possess. - Max Miller, 2015
image_path: data/images/2015_Max Miller__The world of dew is only the world of dew and yet___oh___and yet____ Kobayashi Issa _1763_1828_.jpg
image_stem: 2015_Max Miller__The world of dew is only the world of dew and yet___oh___and yet____ Kobayashi Issa _1763_1828_

title: The fatal shore (island life)
description: I grew up around Berry Island on Sydney’s foreshore and have been visiting this area ever since. This work is part of a series I have been working on looking into both our individual and collective inherited histories. How does our past inhabit our present? At the end of the headland there is a ten-metre Aboriginal rock carving from the time of the Cammeraygal people, thought to depict a stingray inside a whale or sea creature. Beneath this carving down on the water’s edge I came across this rowing boat sitting up high in the rocks, shipwrecked it seemed on an island of Sydney sandstone. Sometimes powerful poetic images are right in front of us. - Julian Meagher, 2015

title: Blackheath street landscape
description: I have lived in Blackheath, a village in the Blue Mountains, for 15 years. My house is just on the other end of this street. Despite the weather, people do a lot of walking around here. You tend to see things better that way. I like what the poet Charles Simic said about poetry, that it was his job to ‘restore strangeness back to the familiar’. I feel it’s the same with painting. We have to take the ordinary, everyday and make it extraordinary. This painting was painted en plein air in two hours after four cups of coffee. - Robert Malherbe, 2015

title: Black gold no. 5
description: The world runs on burning coal, and as I flew over the vast open-cut coalmines of the Hunter Valley, I truly understood our appetite for it and got a sense of it on a global scale. I spent time out there painting the machinery that delivers us our power. It has a sense of being archaic, though it is our current technology. Mining has brought us nearly every manmade object on earth, and has had a profound influence on the landscape, so I cannot ignore it as a subject for landscape painting. - Guy Maestri, 2015

title: Quiet lives ‒ Australia Day revisited
description: ‘Quiet lives’ is an ongoing theme in my work: paintings of buildings in out-of-the-way places, in this case a tiny country town west of Sydney, but it could be any small town. I’m very drawn to places that have no outward sign of life. I’m intrigued they survive and evolve through the ravages of time and economic circumstance to become a sort of portrait of the occupants behind the facade. I’ve been back several times to this one and it gives off a palpable sense of the passing of time in the landscape. The Aussie flag is a permanent fixture, fading like the building. Whoever lives there made the effort to make a statement by hanging it. - Christopher McVinish, 2015
image_path: data/images/2015_Christopher McVinish_Quiet lives _ Australia Day revisited.jpg

title: Bend & stretch
description: After many years of figurative painting, I have recently begun painting gum trees. In Bend & stretch I hope to capture resilience, determination, and frailty in the tree’s brittle aged limbs, lurching forward with the promise of new growth. - Tim McMonagle, 2015

title: Sunlit
description: Winter wattle, lemon yellow, lines flow from eye to eye and tiptoe around the sides. In my room of paint my world is to uncover. I sit and contemplate the beauty of all colours, bathed in sunlit winter light. - Ildiko Kovacs, 2015

title: Called down from the mountains, written in the sea
description: Called down from the mountains, written in the sea is part of a series of landscape paintings, which are meditations about the land. The landscape is not stated, it is suggested, leaving each observer to speculate on their own truth in relation to the image – a stormy sea, a snow-covered landscape, the patterns of geology, and what else? We are left with a sense of isolation. The painting is a depiction of the sense of place, rather than of the place itself. - Aaron Kinnane and Julian Beaumont, 2015
image_path: data/images/2015_Aaron Kinnane_Called down from the mountains_ written in the sea.jpg
image_stem: 2015_Aaron Kinnane_Called down from the mountains_ written in the sea

title: Love letter to a friend
description: Love letter to a friend speaks of writings and musings on love sent to a friend. The work is based on ‘felt’ experiences, sensations and feelings for my subject and for the picture plane, expressed through relationships of colour, line and composition within an overall atmosphere of light. The painting is a search for a resolution of the image, touch and sensibility: a harmony between image and mark. The work is driven by intuition, sacrifice and possibilities that can arouse and reveal. - Nicole Kelly, 2015
image_path: data/images/2015_Nicole Kelly_Love letter to a friend.jpg

title: Kandos
description: This painting is from my memories of time spent in Kandos, a small town in New South Wales. The shapes and colours are a distillation of the energies I remember from being in that landscape. The intent of my work is to express the feeling generated by an environment rather than a precise record of its visual information. I love getting lost in the experience of painting, it’s like being in a timeless dream-like state and then at the end of the night there is this object that didn’t exist before, sitting there in silence looking back at me. - Peter Jones, 2015

title: Think about you
description: I live on 40 acres on the NSW Central Coast. My everyday fascination with the Australian landscape inspires what I paint. Living at the end of a long valley, which I drive through daily, I am constantly and automatically gathering views, flashes of moments and images that I see. I don’t attempt to paint a clear representation of the area but take from everywhere. Then, back in my bushland studio, I reassemble the memories much like a jigsaw into a simplified and emotional interpretation of the beauty that surrounds me. The wintery colours, simplified forms and subtle sense of movement depict a completely isolated view. The title adds a suggestion of human involvement within the landscape. - Belynda Henry, 2015

title: Shutdown
description: This shrouded marble bust of a long-dead hero contains a hidden Trojan: the idea that we like our heroes best when they can be turned on and off; that should they stray too far from the script, or remind us too sharply of our own cowardice, we are able to simply gag them. In referencing the now ubiquitous shutdown button, the carving, with its classical aesthetic, is transported into the contemporary age, reminding us that symbolism is an ever-present force that shapes us. - Robert Hague, 2015

title: The first time again
medium: oil and enamel paint on aluminium panel
description: This landscape painting is formed by apparently ‘collaged’ elements that can be traced to paintings by Paul Gauguin and John Glover in concert with lesser known figures, both human and abstract. These various elements were gleaned from a period of travel that encompassed North West Tasmania, New York and my birthplace in the UK. The terrain of this landscape presents itself as a place of new encounters: a place where ‘Australian landscape’ may be constituted by competing ideas about what may be called exotic and what may be called endemic. - Neil Haddon, 2015

title: Mappa mundi: the known world
medium: mixed media on Japanese rice paper
description: Mappa mundi: the known world emerged from my attraction to the medieval mappa mundi (world map) form, which emphasises the relationship between landscape and story. The Azaria Chamberlain case – a formative introduction to the idea of injustice and media influence – forms the natural foundation of my depicted ‘world’ view, which is grounded within an insular but increasingly global Australia. Stepping beyond sensationalist news cycles to hint at the broader philosophy of related issues, I use the anthropology of motherhood throughout Australian history to explore the character of a country who bases its identity on the natural world, but repeatedly demonstrates its disconnection from natural instinct/processes. - Christine Fontana, 2015
image_path: data/images/2015_Christine Fontana_Mappa mundi_ the known world.jpg

title: Encrusting the marvellous heart
description: Late one night, whilst sleeping in the desert, I dreamed that a woman and child surrounded my swag. They then pried my chest open allowing the contents of the sky to fall in, encrusting my heart like a jewel. That is where the title Encrusting the marvellous heart came from. This star-encrusted heart became a metaphor for the centre of this country. The painting seeks to express the enormity of this experience. - James Drinkwater, 2015

title: On the river
description: The almighty Hawkesbury River is never the same place and it holds its secret life close to its edge. I carry this unfolding world about with me in my sketchbooks, painting the landscape in thin liquid washes en plein air in a tinny, from Wisemans Ferry to Marra Creek or Berowra Waters. The work is relatively undeveloped like the landscape – and I hope it stays that way. - Viola Dominello, 2015

title: The channel series
description: Several years ago, while driving up and down highways, cocooned in my car, I viewed the world outside with a sense of detachment. This led to a series of works involving rudimentary farm dioramas with plastic animals. While creating them, I discovered the OO scale models used by model railway enthusiasts. These nine scenarios are snippets of life. Each has an open-ended narrative allowing the viewer personal interpretation. The house bricks act as a foundation. Each brick is numbered with a vintage bakelite channel knob, compounding the sense of voyeurism. This work explores the distance between what we see and know, and the tenuous connections that help construct our personal realities and identities. - Karl de Waal, 2015

title: Tropical forest II
description: North of Cairns is Kuranda, a rainforest I have visited twice. I like rainforests. The trees are flourishing there. I like to paint dark, using big marks to build up the painting. I also used lots of grey-green in this dark-hued work. The lighting is very important. I used backlighting as an effect to suggest the feeling of moisture in the air and to show the mysterious nature of the forest. - Jun Chen, 2015

title: Chewton Bushlands
description: This diminutive painting appears almost monochrome, but it’s not. The effect is the result of a process whereby many layers and veils of colour are carefully dragged over each other. Once I had the fragile colour field laid in, I made marks into the paint, which cannot be erased other than by being painted out. Each expressive line is a once-only combination of deliberate gesture and chance. These processes combine to create the bush view before you. The paint itself, with its delicious buttery texture, provides the spatial depth. Then, drawing into the paint develops anecdotal and tactile forms on the surface. Together they create a work that is a memory of place. - Steve Burley, 2015

title: Biophilia
description: My miniature oil painting, Biophilia , is part of a recent series that explores the way humans relate to the natural world. Biophilia literally means ‘love of life’ and references a scientific study that suggests our tendency to affiliate with nature is inherent and integral to our psychological and physical development. The inner-city landscape depicted in my painting illustrates a sense of tranquility that contrasts with its active surroundings. My intention is to draw focus on such diverse pockets of nature, and present the idea that we, as humans, are not above nature but very much a part of it. - Natasha Bieniek, 2015

title: Mound spring
description: This mound spring was suspended high in an isolated, rocky escarpment between the sand dunes of the central Simpson Desert. A source of permanent water and an Aboriginal sacred site, littered with Indigenous cultural material and ancient relics, as well as flora and fauna species, it is a secret treasury of desert history. As an expedition artist, I explore remote desert wilderness, places that go beyond boundaries of understanding of landscape, archived ideas and scientific knowledge. Perhaps in the complex, symbiotic, transformative nature of these places, integrated by the artist’s eye, new ways to bring aesthetics and understanding about the land into some meaningful alignment can be discovered. - Jo Bertini, 2015

title: In the name
medium: tinted silicone, urethane, steel gambrel and galvanised chain, edition 1/3
description: In the name invites you into the bright recesses of my childhood memories, when the scarcity of halal meat supplies brought animal slaughter and butchery into the suburban backyard. The pragmatic nature of life and death in the service of dinner became an unspoken ritual of the home, a bloody expression of the sacrosanct enacted behind closed doors. In the name explores the sense of duality embedded within the Muslim-Australian experience, an innate understanding that axioms of the home tend to falter at the front door. - Abdul-Rahman Abdullah, 2015

title: This evening so soon
description: This painting combines memories of walks toward the beach at twilight in various parts of Victoria. The native tea trees are always beautiful and eerie in their random formations. Knotted branches seem to deny a direct path so you are invited to meander. The distant light is a promise of open space and the vast horizon. This painting represents awareness of the journey rather than the destination. The title is taken from a Bob Dylan song. - Heidi Yardley, 2016

title: Approaching storm over Bulga, the Hunter Valley
description: Bulga, which derives its name from an Aboriginal word for ‘big mountain’, is a small town in rural NSW near the Wollombi Brook. Present land use includes grazing, orchards and vineyards. The town sits adjacent to the massive open-cut Warkworth coal mine, which is expanding. The next stage will bring the mine to within 2.6 kilometres of the town centre, and the following stage to within 500 metres. Despite residents winning court cases and appeals, the town is set to disappear forever. In NSW , there is a tradition of artists protesting the degradation of landscape. This has included people like Arthur Streeton who, with others, helped prevent coalmining in Sydney Harbour. - Hadyn Wilson, 2016
image_path: data/images/2016_Hadyn Wilson_Approaching storm over Bulga_ the Hunter Valley.jpg
image_stem: 2016_Hadyn Wilson_Approaching storm over Bulga_ the Hunter Valley

title: Kultureland
description: My interpretation of the Australian landscape is influenced by the concept that landscape is culture before it is nature. The work presents a vision which goes beyond natural appearances and uses myth and memory as a way to connect with the landscape. The finished work presents a visual language possessing unfamiliar and peculiar properties that embody the intrusion of some abstract dimension into the real world. - Stuart Watters, 2016

title: Untitled
description: George Tjungurrayi is a senior Pintupi artist whose paintings draw on the country into which he was born and where he lives and works. The vast spaces of the Western Desert are captured in this painting. Tjungurrayi focuses on a claypan site north of Wilkinkarra (Lake Mackay) as the main subject. It is a place associated with traditional healers – ngangkaris – and the painting alludes to their epic journeys across the land. Of course, this is only part of the story of this painting, which in essence encapsulates not only significant places but is a key as to how they came to be. - Utopia Art Sydney, 2016

title: The solid mandala
description: This is not a painting of Venice. Instead it depicts the collision of two worlds: the Aboriginal and the European. The upper area is an aerial view of a landscape in the Western Desert of Central Australia based on a recent work by Bobby West Tjupurrula titled Snake dreaming at Wilkinkarra . I’ve juxtaposed aspects of this image with a view of the most watery of European cities – Venice, as interpreted by the great 20th-century artist Giorgio de Chirico. The title, The solid mandala , comes from a Patrick White novel. White purchased a series of works from my first solo exhibition in 1973, which he donated to the Art Gallery of New South Wales, so my painting is a homage to him. - Imants Tillers, 2016

title: First creek, Redhead Beach
description: I believe we are all connected to the land: she does not belong to us; we belong to her. When I am alone and consciously engaged with her, I feel this connection intrinsically. Being in the landscape is a spiritual, meditative experience for me and I paint intuitively to convey this connection. I use many layers of paint that I build up and then peel away as a visual metaphor for our relationship with the ever-changing earth and for our own continual transformation. Redhead Beach is my home. I walk on her shores daily; my children swim in her waters every summer. This painting is about my emotional connection to this beautiful place. - Tracey-Maree Smith, 2016

title: Untitled (Oneirophrenia) no 5
description: ‘Oneirophrenia’ comes from the Greek words oneiros (dreams) and phrenos (mind), and means a hallucinatory, dreamlike state caused by conditions such as prolonged sleep deprivation, sensory deprivation or drugs. In Greek mythology, the Oneiroi are personifications of dreaming: Morpheus, the winged god of dreams, can take human form; Phobetor appears in the guise of nightmarish animals or monsters; and Phantasos creates surreal dreams or illusions. In Untitled (Oneirophrenia) no 5 , Tim Silver presents a self-portrait in the form of a classical bust. He has packed his head with bread dough, which, as it rises, ruptures through his plaster skin. This unique form has then been re-cast in pigmented concrete and marble dust, transforming the material resonance of the object once again.

title: Eternally yours
description: The words ‘eternally yours’ were handwritten by my terminally ill friend Elizabeth Caplice, battling cancer at the age of 32. Liz was to spray the text in person, but took a turn for the worse that confined her to bed. Defacing this traditional vanitas is an act of defiance and a tribute to her eloquence and courage. Elizabeth died at 1.35am on 12 July 2016. She had her parents and closest friends at her side. - Alex Seton, 2016

title: Buffalo country, Katherine, NT
description: Buffalo country takes me back to a journey through the grasslands and along the escarpments of Katherine in the Northern Territory. A wild place, entirely unpredictable and immensely powerful, this is a landscape where people and animals are pitted against each other and are at once enmeshed. The dynamic is just as complex between European and Indigenous inhabitants. Here is a painterly response reflecting something of this place of harmony and of paradox. - Luke Sciberras, 2016

title: Rory's vision
description: I was given access to a large number of concept sketches (including some on the back of napkins) and mission statements from key employees involved with the construction of this development in Geelong, Victoria, which is scheduled to open in December 2016. While the placement of roads, river and wetlands are accurate, I took poetic licence with all the little figures, pets and possessions. I am fascinated by the way one developer can direct and shape a suburb or neighbourhood where so many people will live. - Robert Ryan, 2016

title: Untitled
description: Yukultji Napangati lives at Kiwirrkurra in the midst of the vast space of the Gibson Desert, Western Australia. Her painting looks at the land towards Wilkinkarra (Lake Mackay) and refers to the lines of sandhills that stretch to the horizon. There is a sense of the heat captured in the wavering lines and a vastness in the repetition. We see a vision of the land, but the artist is also recalling the epic journey of ancestral women as they made their way to Wilkinkarra. - Utopia Art Sydney, 2016

title: Clarence River, NSW
description: My outdoor studio practice provides me with many opportunities to paint both the broad and intimate landscape that I inhabit. Living in the landscape and locally sourcing my subject matter, as well as painting and framing materials, is about establishing my sense of place in this unique NSW environment. Clarence River, NSW is a painting about the river and its vegetation. In this painting I sought to describe my everyday interactions with my environment. - Robert Moore, 2016

title: The mountain and me
medium: egg tempera and gold leaf on wood
description: The birds have vanished into the sky, and now the last cloud drains away. We sit together the mountain and me, until only the mountain remains. - Lo Po, 701–62 The Southern Highlands in NSW is alive with diverse birdlife, insects and animals as well as wonderful variants in the landscape, which I love to draw and paint. Working on four panels of Fijian cedar, I coated it with burnished gold leaf then painted using egg tempera, made by adding colour pigments to golden yolks from our chooks, which gives it a warm, soft quality. I have drawn on various influences, from 15th-century Flemish artist Jan van Eyck to painters of the Italian Renaissance. - Max Miller, 2016

title: Windswept coastal trees
description: Although very lucky to live in the Blue Mountains, I do spend quite a bit of time painting en plein air down the south coast of NSW . I find the light around the Jervis Bay area extraordinarily intense and it’s always an exhilarating challenge to capture on canvas as much of that light as possible before sunset. These trees were painted by a beach on an afternoon so violently windy that at one point Windswept coastal trees was blown off its easel. Luckily I caught it as it cartwheeled towards the sand. - Robert Malherbe, 2016

title: Grange Burn Bridge
description: I painted the Grange Burn Bridge while on a two-month residency in Hamilton, south-western Victoria. The Western District is highly productive pastoral country. It is literally the ‘land of the golden fleece’, made famous by Arthur Streeton nearly a hundred years ago. Streeton would have crossed the Grange Burn by steam train as he traversed the region making his iconic paintings, which were seen as ‘postwar Australian landscapes full of national pride, prosperity and potential’. The area is still rich, but a train hasn’t crossed the Grange Burn for 30 years. - Guy Maestri, 2016

title: The admiral
description: This old man presents himself as a belligerent old fool, an admiral anchored to his landscape. Gnarled limbs droop and twist towards sinuous foliage, sucking light to grow his story. Pastoralism still encroaches on this guardsman, who keeps watch, helpless to protect his environment, dehydrated when burnt by our blistering sun and flooded when the tempest takes hold. The admiral has untold stamina, and offers a lifeline for the environment that we care not enough about. - Tim McMonagle, 2016

title: Last light
description: Last light is the result of a recent painting trip through the Flinders Ranges in South Australia. Working on location for several days resulted in oil studies that were the basis for this large work. Landscape and urbanscape have always underpinned my broader body of work. It is liberating to be unshackled from the city studio and respond to the rawness that presents itself on a rambling outback journey, working in the moment, with scenes that change hour to hour and day to day. - Stewart MacFarlane, 2016

title: Long day blues – evening light
description: This picture began as a three-panel painting but after a few weeks I changed tack and reduced its scale. I am concerned with finding ways of describing the world or the sensation of being in a certain place. This can vary from painting to painting; there is no consistent method. In this work, the composition of forms, tones and colours meet to convey the feeling of being in the landscape around my farm, south of Walcha on the New England Tableland in NSW . - Ross Laurie, 2016
image_path: data/images/2016_Ross Laurie_Long day blues _ evening light.jpg

title: Seven Sisters
description: This collaborative canvas is painted by five sisters from the Ken family – Tjungkara Ken, Yaritji Young, Freda Brady, Maringka Tunkin and Sandra Ken – who live in the remote Aboriginal community of Amata in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara Lands in the far north-west of South Australia. The painting is a ‘Seven Sisters’ story about family protecting and teaching each other. It tells of women being chased by a bad man but being protected by their elder sisters. We have also included the tjala (honey ant), which refers to our country. When we work together as a family we are learning from each other and teaching each other. Our family is strong because we teach all our young women this important tjukurpa (the force which unites Anangu with each other and with the landscape). Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa (Tjungkara Ken, Yaritji Young, Freda Brady, Maringka Tunkin munu Sandra Ken) Nganampa Tjukurpa Walytja Nganana minyma kunpu kanyini nganampa walytja-ngka. Panya kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa nganampa walytja. Panya paluru tjanayanku tjungungku atunymananyi munu tjungungku nintiningi. Ka palu purunypa Ananguku arangka nganana kanyini walytja uwankara. Nganana uwankara kangkuru pulka tjuta minyma malatja, malatja tjutaka. Panya kungkarangkalpaku tjukurpa purunypa. Nganana mulapa malanypa tjuta pulkara nintima munu atunymanama. Ka nganana walytjapiti Tjungu warkarira nganana tjungu nintiringkupai munula tjungungku nintilpai nganampa malanypa tjuta munu nganampa walyta tjuta munu naganampa untalpa tjutakulu. Ka nganampa art centre kuwari kunpu ngaranyi panya nganana nintini minyma malatja malatja tjuta tjukurpa nganampaku - Ken family, 2016

title: Self-report
description: My sculptures of skulls, heads and body parts are a metamorphosis of my self-portrait drawings. The machete and axe-wielding marks, the gritty black texture of the clay and the primitive forms are ruminations of things in my immediate environment. The work is a self-report on my mental state, on current news stories of boat people, immigration, genocide, terrorism and history. Contemporary savagery is anchored via the gritty clay and primitive forms within vast histories of human violence. The burnt figures are heaved out of the earth, evoking imagery of mass graves, holocausts and burial sites and connecting contemporary events with ancient histories. - Locust Jones, 2016

title: The boab tree
description: The boab tree takes a panoramic view of the Australian landscape by applying various painting styles to imagery that ranges from the desert to the spiritual or metaphysical aspect of nature itself. The boab tree, with its ability to store water, is a symbolic presence that appears throughout the painting. Painting styles referred to include an abstract expressionist use of colour and a kind of free-form expression of the landscape space where the paint itself not only represents but becomes landscape, contextualising the experience of contemplating where we live as a wide-ranging, even cosmic, constructed space. - Tim Johnson, 2016

title: Islands five
medium: acrylic and pastel on polyester canvas
description: An everyday fascination with the Australian landscape is the main inspiration for my work. Living at the end of a secluded valley on the NSW Central Coast, I am always subconsciously gathering the natural shapes, flashes of colour and composition of the mountains and trees that surround me. I don’t attempt to paint a clear representation of the area but take from everywhere, including other places I have visited while travelling. Then, back in my studio, I reassemble both recent and past memories, much like a jigsaw, into a simplified and emotional interpretation of the beauty that surrounds me. Islands five is from a series called Islands inspired by Australian waterways. - Belynda Henry, 2016

title: Wilpena wattle
description: ‘Painting is but another word for feeling.’ — John Constable, 1821 Painting something involves the manifestation of a remembered presence, the occupation within and of a space resulting in a subsequent transformation of fact and emotion with physical matter. — Nicholas Harding, 2016

title: The banker (or the king of comedy)
description: There he is, There. Amongst the fractures Waiting (for another tasty morsel) One more jumps, And another Then another. And the gulls swirl While an island waits And the comedy continues. - Craig Handley, 2016
image_path: data/images/2016_Craig Handley_The banker _or the king of comedy_.jpg
image_stem: 2016_Craig Handley_The banker _or the king of comedy_

title: I read 'The day of the triffids' when I lived in England (and now I live in Tasmania)
medium: oil and enamel paint on aluminium
description: This painting is concerned with the difficulties of constructing meaning in pictures when the supporting contexts for the imagery are unfamiliar. It draws on my experience as a migrant to Tasmania (via six years in Spain) and the ways that migrants find their own poetic meaning in the unfamiliar contexts of a new home. This work conflates aspects of well-known paintings by Paul Gauguin and John Glover and includes other abstracted constructions to picture an unstable Tasmanian landscape where meaning is in a state of flux and is perpetually renegotiated according to the influences of where the artist once was and where he finds himself now. - Neil Haddon, 2016
image_path: data/images/2016_Neil Haddon_I read _The day of the triffids_ when I lived in England _and now I live in Tasmania_.jpg
image_stem: 2016_Neil Haddon_I read _The day of the triffids_ when I lived in England _and now I live in Tasmania_

title: Bush Zero, Darwin River
description: Seventy-five years after this Mitsubishi A6M (‘Zero’) cartwheeled through the bush south of Darwin and came to rest, its elegant aluminium body refuses to decompose. Clouds billow Heat shimmers Trees dance in the breeze Time passes - Steve Gough, 2016

title: North/black lung
description: The bush has become a battleground upon which contesting environmental ideologies fight for dominance. Large multinational entities such as mining companies and the fracking industry, which treat the environment as an instrument, are embroiled with ecocentric and often pan-political alliances that advocate a more sustainable relationship with the land, such as the national coalition Lock the Gate. This monochromatic image, drained of colour, presents an unvarnished reality and speaks to a deeper, more existential foreboding. North/black lung is a reminder of the pervasiveness of history; whatever actions are undertaken now will be our legacy. - Peter Gardiner, 2016

title: Bromeliad forest
description: I discovered bromeliads while visiting the tropics and have become fascinated by their very visible struggle for survival. Painting this subject has forced me to use watercolour in a different way; building up layers to create a feeling of shade and claustrophobic humidity. These plants adapt and grow in extraordinary ways. Many are epiphytes, meaning that they are able to grow in the air, high above ground level in the forest canopy in order to reach sunlight. They are not parasitic and collect their nutrients from organic litter while providing habitats for insects and frogs. - Sophie Dunlop, 2016

title: Ice cliff
description: We have been lucky enough to have travelled to the four corners of the world but never to the basement. No matter what you have seen before, nothing is quite like the Antarctic. It is almost twice as big as Australia and we are responsible for almost half of it. The landscape is stunning: bold, majestic and a bit frightening. Icebergs of every shape and size float gently in a silver sea, while ice cliffs that tower above lead to craggy mountain peaks. We drifted around in Zodiacs, rugged up to endure the freezing cold. Little boats full of ants. - Ken Done, 2016

title: Monaro shadow and light
description: I have spent a large part of my painting career living, travelling and working around the Australian bush. I find that each time I revisit an area, the changes that time and the seasons have created provide me with a fresh perspective on the ever-shifting Australian landscape. I enjoyed some time working in the Monaro in 2014 and this painting is a response to that landscape with its particular qualities of shadow and light. - Elisabeth Cummings, 2016

title: Monaro/Ando
description: Monaro/Ando is a big studio painting I made from a small study. The view is of Rosemount, a large fine-wool sheep property at Ando on the Monaro, NSW . The property once belonged to the Kimbers, old family friends. My family spent a year away from Sydney in the 1970s and we lived there in the old shearers’ quarters. I was eight at the time. The country made a strong impression on me. Nine years ago, I moved to Bibbenluke, a locality near Ando. I love this place. - Lucy Culliton, 2016

title: Conservatory no 2
description: Conservatory no 2 continues my investigation into locations that recreate the natural world. Constructed landscapes such as aquariums, conservatories and dioramas can serve to educate the public about the wonders of nature, as well as the environmental issues facing our planet. These venues also act as a kind of ‘theatre of the real’ where we experience an approximation of nature. In this way these sites are conceptually linked to the act of representational painting itself, which reimagines the world through illusion. - Leah Bullen, 2016

title: I fell behind and you waited for me
description: The Southern Plains of NSW (the Monaro) has long been a form of visual vocabulary to me. An emotional shorthand. I find the limitations of its featurelessness endlessly demonstrative or receptive to the subtle doubts, longings and hopes that we have every day. The light, as always, is representative of someone. - Jason Benjamin, 2016
image_path: data/images/2016_Jason Benjamin_I fell behind and you waited for me.jpg
image_stem: 2016_Jason Benjamin_I fell behind and you waited for me

title: The inexhaustible flux
description: The inexhaustible flux represents the movement of the body within the ever-changing landscape of forest, mountain and river; walking the skin of the earth. The sculpture physically mimics the voids and ellipses of mountain pools articulated by the converging lines of rock formations, while simultaneously transmitting a rhythmic pulse or vibration. Horizontal strata are inverted, flipping mountain forms into a pulse-like abstraction, where the eye of the viewer charts its own journey through interwoven pathways.The work is made from an assemblage of coloured, hexagonal Staedtler pencils, a material for which most people hold a subconscious tactile affinity and, for the artist, a core material. The inexhaustible flux pays homage to a landscape in a state of constant transformation and the physical power that landscape transmits into the body. - Lionel Bawden, 2016

title: Days of spring – irises & grevillea
medium: oil and lapis lazuli on linen
description: For me, painting is a meditative process where I become as one with the image in the making. This painting captures the light and beauty of Australian wildflowers in their natural setting. My technique enables me to portray the sun’s energy coming to earth to create this energy of colour. In order to transmit the beauty in front of me to the eye of the viewer, great dedication and concentration is needed. Salvatore Zofrea, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Salvatore Zofrea_Days of spring _ irises _ grevillea.jpg

title: Tjala tjukurpa (honey ant story)
description: Yaritji Young is a traditional owner for tjala tjukurpa, near the Amata community in South Australia. She paints the rock holes and landmarks of her country, entwined with icons and traditional marks that relate to inma (dance) and tjukurpa (dreaming). The twisted lines and shapes mimic tunnels and formations made by the tjala honey ant. ‘My paintings are of my country: my father’s country, my grandmother’s country, the tjala country. Everything that my grandmother taught me, I’m teaching to my grandchildren now. They dance because I have shared what I got from my grandmother with my granddaughters, so they can know their culture.’ Yaritji Young, 2017

title: Bay of sorrow – Hawkesbury River
description: I paint in my tinny. I carve with a belt sander the tides of the Hawkesbury and eat away like a termite into the raw linen, lifting pulp between the eucalypts. Near me is a midden of oysters thousands of years old in this bay that feels so empty. Joshua Yeldham, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Joshua Yeldham_Bay of sorrow _ Hawkesbury River.jpg

title: Waŋupini
description: The sun rises and sets, painting the clouds. The spirits are born and die, to be reborn once more. Makassan friends from Indonesia visit for trade, arriving with the northern monsoon and departing on the winds associated with bulunu (the south-east cloud formations that bring rain). This painting charts the Djapana song cycle (Djapana means ‘sunset’ in Yolŋu matha or language, and ‘farewell’ in Bugis, an Indonesian dialect). The anvil and triangular shapes are clouds, pregnant women and the sails of red prau (an Indonesian fishing boat). This takes place at the marŋarr (an ancestral Makassan port) in Nawurapu Wunuŋmurra’s Dhalwaŋu clan at Gurrumuru, upstream from Arnhem Bay. He died days after submitting this work. He declined medical treatment, confident of returning. Buku-Larrŋgay Mulka Centre, Yirrkala, NT, 2018

title: Third person
description: This painting is based on scenes from an open-world video game set in a fictitious location. The landscape in much of this virtual place seemed vaguely familiar to places I remember from my youth – a small town in western Victoria sandwiched between the Big and Little Deserts. Rather than a grammatical third person, the painting is intended to be third person in the context of the video game, where the player sees themselves from an elevated distance. It is the viewer who is outside the picture seeing themselves in the orange truck driving up the road. Marcus Wills, 2018

title: Iyakuta tjukurpa
medium: acrylic on linen and canvas mailbag
description: Intuatjanu in South Australia is my birthplace and it is also home to Iyakuta tjukurpa (two sisters). This tjukurpa continues far into the Northern Territory and is an important story for Anangu. This painting is about the mistreatment of Iyakuta at Intuatjanu. Some time ago Iyakuta was damaged by whitefellas taking rock to build a road. Government, anthropology and APY land council, this mob are really no good: they never listen to the traditional owners. Ngunti walytjaringkula Tjukurpa kurantja wiyangku wantima Pampuntja wiya Do not pretend to own what is not yours Never destroy tjukurpa law Do not touch Mumu Mike Williams, 2018

title: Frogs Holla
description: Frogs Holla , in New South Wales, depicts a prominent Milton scene that epitomises the beauty of where I live. I am interested in exploring the wonder of the natural landscape by minimising the details and reducing the scene to fundamental shapes. Driving the road portrayed in this painting, I am often struck by the serenity of my home, and I wanted to recreate that sense of peace on canvas. For me, colour, composition and minimising detail are integral to creating the restful mood of the painting. Sally Willbanks, 2018

title: Ilpili
description: The Watarru Collaborative consists of Wipana Jimmy and her daughters Beryl Jimmy and Imitjala Pollard, all from the tiny remote community of Watarru on the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. Together these three women depict grand creation stories that have been passed down through countless generations. Their paintings show a particular sensitivity to the way these creation myths interact with and shape their beloved homeland, Watarru, and its many unique land formations. The Watarru Collaborative brings together distinct mark-making styles to create cohesive and dynamic artworks, filled with deep cultural integrity and a love and knowledge of country. Tjungu Palya, Nyapari community, 2018

title: Trial Bay
description: Three monolithic rocks, which are statues of ancestral beings, jut from the entrance to Trial Bay. Freshwater imbued with sacred honey flows from fonts deep in the saltwater under these rocks. This sweet saltwater, belonging to the Marrakulu, Golumala, Marraŋu and Wawilak clans, clashes, plays and mingles with the oceanic saltwater of the Djapu and Dhapuyŋu clans. Rushing into the bay, the ocean creates eddies, currents and patterns that define the Märi-Gutharra relationship between Djapu and Marrakulu clans. They are maternal grandmother and granddaughter. A metaphoric ‘backbone’. The eponymous black sand comes from one beach only and is called Yalanba. Buku-Larrŋgay Mulka Centre, Yirrkala, NT, 2018

title: West of Wilcannia II
description: In the far west of New South Wales and into South Australia, places such as the banks of the Darling River, Mutawintji, the Flinders Ranges and Burra are islands separated by vast flat plains. When crossing those plains time blurs into the distance. They are places where the fleeting moment feels endless. Last year, I made a suite of paintings grounded in my memories of many crossings of the western plains. West of Wilcania II is one of that suite. John R Walker, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_John R Walker_West of Wilcannia II.jpg

title: Phosphorus. Yellow landscape
description: Phosphorus extends the conception of conventional landscape painting. Though profoundly about ‘place’, it is not rooted in location. My concern is to invoke a condition, the spirit of place that is conceptually framed by time and the accumulation of experience. The title partly references Fred Williams’ painting Yellow landscape , which came to mind towards the completion of this work. Australia has been my home for many years now and still the quality of light, the particularities of colour, the form and structure of the land continue to affect me. Painting can reveal something fundamental to our shared sense of place in the land. Aida Tomescu, 2018

title: My stolen sisters from Gija country
medium: ochre and natural pigments on linen
description: This story is about the Stolen Generations from the East Kimberley region of Western Australia, and the journey through the landscape to Oombulgurri that was the fate of two young Gija girls. Phyllis Thomas was born in a place called Riya, on the Turner River, south-east of Purnululu (the Bungle Bungles). Her sister Stella and her cousin-sister Molly-Go were taken away by gardiya (whitefellas) when they were fairly young. They would take kids from stations and bring them to Moola Boola station, which was like a holding place for the stolen children. So, the two girls were taken to Oombulgurri (top section of the painting), where they stayed for good, married and had children. Warmun Art Centre, Gija Contempory Art, Western Australia, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Phyllis Thomas_My stolen sisters from Gija country.jpg
image_stem: 2018_Phyllis Thomas_My stolen sisters from Gija country

title: Red moon
description: Red moon is part of an ongoing series of works exploring themes of embedded trauma and the potential for healing through art. The intense colour of Red moon signals primal emotions and reactions triggered from the amygdala – a part of the brain no bigger than a dice that is responsible for the ‘fight or flight’ reaction. It speaks to a state of mind where we become driven by survival instincts, and embedded fears that, left unaddressed, only seem to grow larger. Red moon does not feel safe, but the danger is in the past. Gradually fear recedes, giving way to gentle illumination. Hiromi Tango, 2018

title: At sea (for Pamela)
description: A painting shouldn’t need the artist’s statement to guide understanding. However, the background to this particular picture may be of interest… Lee Marvin, the American screen actor, died suddenly in Tucson, Arizona, on 28 August 1987. Lee’s widow Pamela and her dear friend Margaret Throsby scattered roses and Lee’s ashes into the sea off Cairns. It was the place Lee loved to fish in Australia. Ashes and red roses into the Pacific had another resonance as Lee had been seriously wounded on Saipan as a marine during the Pacific campaign of World War II. On 2 April this year, Pamela died. In memory of dear friends… Tim Storrier, 2018

title: Kembla, Mount Kembla
description: In 1922, DH Lawrence and his wife Frieda came to Thirroul, about an hour south of Sydney, by train. It was here that he wrote the novel Kangaroo , in which he described ‘the town that slid down at the bush-covered foot of the dark tor’. I have lived beneath this dark tor for most of my life. It is omnipresent, it shields us and acts as a gilded cage. In summer, spring and early morning, it captures the sun and glows. But in winter, it stands against the western sky as a dark fortress, blocking our escape and most of the afternoon sun. This a painting of a deep love of place. Paul Ryan, 2018 Highly commended in the Wynne Prize 2018

title: Figure with plant
description: Figure with plant borrows from and subverts the classical rendition of the female body. Form is inverted. Line and shape reference the structure of text on the page. The body is headless but the head is present, growing plant-like from the ground. Caroline Rothwell, 2018

title: Embrace
description: To hold closely in one’s arms – An idea in a form that is not anchored by its weight, Essence is revealed without having to circulate around the form. Motion is within the sculpture. Lustrous sheen – highly polished metal. Sculpture imbued with the essence of individuals as it shimmers and glows. Individuals but together. An optical allegory conveying us beyond the solid form. Andrew Rogers, 2018

title: Wringing core (we are letting go completely)
description: This work comprises a series of vertical wooden objects that buckle and bend as if subject to some invisible force. While suggestive of a wooden henge or funerary poles, they eschew any explicit references yet subtly correspond to the human body and its articulations; think of jointed knees and elbows, and the deviations of our bodies around a central core or spine. Despite the integrity of wood as a material, these upright sculptures appear to soften, kink and collapse upon themselves, as if unable to sustain their own weight. In conceiving this work, I referenced figurative sculpture and therapeutic body practices such as meditation and relaxation techniques. Todd Robinson, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Todd Robinson_Wringing core _we are letting go completely_.jpg
image_stem: 2018_Todd Robinson_Wringing core _we are letting go completely_

title: Antara
description: Antara is an extremely important site for Betty Kuntiwa Pumani and her family. Antara is her mother’s country. This place and its significant maku (witchetty grub) tjukurpa were a constant in the paintings of the late Kunmanara (Milatjari) Pumani. Today, Betty and her older sister Ngupulya Pumani are proud custodians of this country; they map its significance and hold its stories strong in their paintings. Betty’s signature reds evoke the rocky desert country of Antara, while simultaneously suggesting blood or viscera and an unmistakable energy. The contrasting areas of white and its subtle tonal shifts are a quiet and patient counterpoint to the pulsating reds. Mimili Maku Arts, 2018

title: The banality of evil (Manus)
description: The repeated image is of Manus Island, from the cover of a Walkabout: Australian Geographical Magazine from 1952. My intent was to create a colourful yet banal holiday destination poster. This is how our government and certain sections of the media have often tried to portray conditions in our offshore detention centres despite the UN describing them as immensely harmful, alarming and torturous. Most of us agree, considering them downright un-Australian and evil. James Powditch, 2018

title: The tree of life
description: The centrality of everything for me is about what things actually feel like. My paintings are statements of empathy; statements about the feeling of being in the landscape. To be an Australian artist is to be an explorer – unlike artists in Europe where landscape painting has been manicured by genius artists, writers and musicians. This has not occurred in Australia besides the magnificent presence of Aboriginal art. Let us remember that before the Heidelberg School there had been no rendition of the unique Australian light. Neither had there been an acute observation of how the landscape actually looked. Aboriginal art had its profound focus on the Dreamtime. John Olsen, 2018

title: Untitled
description: This painting is associated with Yunala, a rock hole and soakage water site among sandhills west of Kiwirrkura in Western Australia. During ancestral times a group of women camped at this site. While at Yunala, the women camped beside the rock hole, digging for the edible roots of the bush banana or silky pear vine ( Marsdenia australis ), also known as yunala. The lines in the work represent both the sandhills surrounding the site as well as the yunala tubers underground. The women later continued their travels east, passing through Marrapinti, Ngaminya and Wirrulnga on their way to Wilkinkarra. Yukultji Napangati, 2018

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: This is my painting about the country where I was born. I grew up in a traditional way, none of us had any clothes and we’d never seen houses. Back then we lived in the bush, slept in the warm sand and lived on the bush tucker. My painting is where it all started. This country is my home. I know this land all over, this is strong country. These things, everything, is my memory – my knowledge. I like painting my country, I like to paint the memories of my country. Peter Mungkuri, 2018

title: Backyard
description: My partner and I have made a garden around our suburban home which consists predominantly of exotic native plants selected and arranged to create exciting textural and colour shifts. Nearly everything in the garden is arranged for the purpose of painting. Backyard is part of a series of works that have been painted in this garden. The process of working en plein air has an intensity of focus quite different from painting in the studio. I have experimented with creating vistas exploring varied light effects by linking paintings from different viewpoints across the landscape. Stephanie Monteith, 2018

title: Next door
description: This was painted plein air on a 30-degree day under the tree at the front of our house. Suburbia is my current habitat and I’ve found the landscape has all sorts of connotations – peaceful, boring, sinister, safe. The houses on the street look similar, though on closer inspection are fiercely individual, colours of roofs differ but complement each other and the trees loom above, suggesting a balance between the human and natural world. I feel it’s my job to encourage intense observation of the world, to take a normal, familiar view and attempt to point out the interest, the beauty in the ordinary. Rachel Milne, 2018

title: Three birds
description: Like a thousand sparks from a thousand fires light moves through leaves Like a thousand dreams of a sunlit afternoon high in the trees you sit Watching the folly of a thousand painted marks making a thousand leaves and the branches on which you sit A thousand feathers make a single bird and a thousand parts make just one Three birds Six wings One sun Ben Milne, 2018

title: Arcadia Road, Blackheath
description: I’ve lived with my family in Blackheath in the Blue Mountains, New South Wales, for over 17 years. In the late afternoon, I walk my dog or ride my bike around the neighbouring streets. Very often I see things that are inspirations for paintings. I came across this motif on Arcadia Road while cycling and came back the next day at the same time with canvas and paints. The people around here are used to my behaviour and seem sympathetic to the plights of a plein-air painter, at the end of summer, struggling against the dying light. Robert Malherbe, 2018

title: Shadow captain
description: In my painting Shadow captain I was interested in capturing an imagined anthropomorphic nature. In the changing low light of dawn or dusk the large eucalyptus seems to twist and contort, fastened to the ground where it is anchored. Tim McMonagle, 2018

title: The lucky country?
medium: acrylic, oil and enamel on linen
description: This painting depicts me as a field officer for Papunya Tula, during a time where I spent two years in central Australia and the Kimberley, mixing paint for the great artist Naata Nungurrayi in Kintore. It was the time when I came to understand the significance and depth of Aboriginal culture (Pintupi culture in this case) and their true connection to country. The contemporary reality is bleak. But times were also tempered with amazing people really trying to help heal what is still an open wound caused by colonisation, trauma and disenfranchisement. It is very complex, and that is what I am trying to get across here. The nuances. William Mackinnon, 2018

title: Door, Hunter Valley
description: The Hunter Valley is an area I have got to know a bit over the last ten years due to knowing a few people who live there and, as a result, spending some time in the region. As well, a few years back I got involved with protests to stop a particular coal mine, Bickmore, being developed there. The mine was to be located very close to some horse studs and we were successful in stopping the mine. Noel McKenna, 2018

title: A silence
description: This painting came from a trip I took to the rainforest-clad peaks of Bunya Mountains National Park in south-east Queensland, which shelters the largest stand of ancient bunya pines in the world. I had heard stories of the Aboriginal groups that came every three years for the bunya nut feasts. I also heard other, more recent, sinister stories about the Native Police and their push into Queensland, which left many dead and the landscape haunted by fear and denial. The bunya feasts ceased after traditional pathways became blocked by settlement and loggers began cutting down the bunya trees. Today these tree ferns sit like sentinels beneath what remains. The silence is deafening. Fiona Lowry, 2018

title: Anumara
description: Anumara is a place near Irrunytju (Wingellina) in Western Australia. This is my family’s country. Anumara is also the name for a kind of caterpillar and Anumara is the tjukurpa (dreaming) place for this caterpillar. When I am painting, I am thinking like the caterpillars; I am thinking about my family’s country. I am creating anumara tjina tjuta (many tracks), like they are crawling, crawling. I am painting this country and this tjukurpa to keep it safe and strong. This is how my people care for our places and our stories. Yurpiya Lionel, 2018

title: Martuwarra
description: Sonia Kurarra’s paintings reflect her love for her river country in Nookanbah and fishing for barramundi on the river. Sonia has a unique style and story that reflects the depths of the river story she paints. ‘Martuwarra is my river country; this painting is all about the Fitzroy River which flows down through Nookanbah. All kinds of fish live in the water, we catch big mob of fish there. I like parlka (barrumundi). We catch catfish and brim there too. Nganku (shark), wirritunany (swordfish) and stingray also live there. These fish live in these waters long after the flood has gone.’ Sonia Kurarra, 2018

title: Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa (Seven Sisters story)
description: Sylvia Ken is from the Amata community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. She was born in 1965 and has been painting since 1999. Her family are traditional owners for significant sites where the Seven Sisters story takes place. This painting refers to this story, the landscape that the story takes place in, as well as the characters in the story. ‘I listen to the old people’s stories and I think about these stories and then the ideas come for my paintings… I listen when they are talking about tjukurpa and telling creation stories, and when they say to me, “No, you should paint this way, the Seven Sisters”.’ Sylvia Ken, 2018

title: Tali tjukurpa (sand dune country)
description: Ray Ken is a senior artist from the Amata community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) region in South Australia. His paintings reflect his intimate knowledge of the landscape and reminisce about long journeys traversing the sand hills of his country as a stockman. He also shares his deep understanding of Anangu culture. ‘When we are resting, it will be the young fellas’ turn to look after our country. This is the Anangu way. As they’ve been growing up, they’ve been learning how our stories can make you strong inside – and to be strong is to keep culture safe so that nothing can take it away.’ Ray Ken, 2017

artist: Naomi Kantjuriny, Mona Mitakiki, Tjimpayi Presley
title: Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa (Seven Sisters story)
description: Naomi Kantjuriny, Mona Mitakiki and Tjimpayi Presley paint kapi tjukurla (rock holes) that relate to the Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa. This story involves the Seven Sisters being chased across country by Wati Nyiru (a bad man). The elder sisters protect and teach the younger ones, and keep them from falling for his tricks. Wati Nyiru can change shape into different rock formations and landmarks. These sites remain part of the landscape and are important Anangu ceremonial places. These three artists were taught to paint by senior artist Kunmanara Katie Kawiny. She has passed away but the younger women carry her story on for future generations. Tjala Arts, Amata community, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Naomi Kantjuriny_ Mona Mitakiki_ Tjimpayi Presley_Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa _Seven Sisters story_.jpg
image_stem: 2018_Naomi Kantjuriny_ Mona Mitakiki_ Tjimpayi Presley_Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa _Seven Sisters story_

title: Boab at El Questro (Kimberleys WA)
description: Whenever I’m in the Kimberley region, I’m always fascinated by the ubiquitous boab tree and its ancient and sensuous shape – an incongruous presence in that rugged landscape. On this occasion, I stayed at Anna Gorge – a station at El Questro, a property of nearly a million acres – and painted two sunrises (plein air, with gouache) featuring boab trees with the marvellous Cockburn Ranges in the background. This prompted me to paint a group of boabs near Anna Gorge camp, in watercolour, with the ever-present Cockburn Ranges embracing them. Bela Ivanyi, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Bela Ivanyi_Boab at El Questro _Kimberleys WA_.jpg

title: Funny hahas and bloody galahs
description: Sometimes I feel certain about what I am about to embark upon the moment I pick up a brush. At other times I must allow myself to surrender to my doubts in the hope that eventually I am asking the right questions of myself. It can be a risky high-wire walk. So, Funny hahas and bloody galahs is about a collective loss, an inability to hold onto joy without the constant clicking, tapping and swiping. It’s about falling for the snake charmer’s music and the panacea of a modern medicine man’s magic all dressed up with the jingles and flashy cuts of the sale frenzy. Craig Handley, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Craig Handley_Funny hahas and bloody galahs.jpg

title: Garrapara
description: Garrapara is a striking rocky coastal headland and bay area within Blue Mud Bay, on the eastern coast of Arnhem Land. Sketched in 1803 by English artist William Westall, who worked as a painter on Matthew Flinders’ voyage of discovery to Australia, it is known on maps in English as Mt Grindall and Djalma Bay. Garrapara is depicted here by the patterns built up in sand and white clay using a Yolŋu clan design called miny’tji. There are songs about the drowning deaths of two canoe-borne heroes by a tsunami that was caused by their transgression of a sacred site. Their deaths led to the first Yiŋapuŋapu mortuary ceremony at a sand sculpture at this place. The bark is shaped to represent that coastline. Buku-Larrŋgay Mulka Centre, Yirrkala, NT, 2018

title: As I recall
medium: oil and mixed media on paper, plastic 35mm slide mounts
description: The magic lantern show, dating back to the 17th century, was the forerunner of the cinematic experience. People would pay to see images projected on a screen, the travelling showman telling stories or adding comments for the audience. The original images were hand-painted on glass slides using transparent colours. The slides used here are opaque and cannot be projected. Each image is… memory of place as impression place as idea as mood not the place inventing a memory invention as a process of recalling the record of an invention the realisation of a place a collection of memories imagining the past remembering the future Keith Fyfe, 2018

title: Glory be, water tree
medium: watercolour and mixed media on paper
description: Have you ever felt drawn to a location? Mount Buffalo, in central Victoria, is the place for me. Glory be, water tree was documented on a five-hour snow hike in late July. On the cusp of spring, the snow had begun to melt, with rivulets flowing, pools of free and frozen water, and a peaceful stillness. My attraction to Mount Buffalo is its stillness – a place of pure distraction, not of day-to-day things but to myself… my essence… with feet solidly planted amongst other life. To let yourself ‘be’ is to love oneself. Phillip Edwards, 2018

title: Hammer and breath
description: In early 2018, I visited Bundanon – the property on the Shoalhaven River in southern New South Wales, which artist Arthur Boyd gifted to the nation in 1993. It is a pilgrimage long sought out by artists and subscribers to the ‘Boyd church’. A self-confessed Boyd tragic, I found the visit to the homestead and surrounding area deeply profound. I’ve always seen a link between Boyd’s Pulpit Rock and Cézanne’s Mont Sainte-Victoire. Painters require places to meditate on, places which inspire endless exploration with the ancient material of paint. James Drinkwater, 2018

title: Before they all came true
description: This painting was born out of recent travel to Tasmania and depicts one of the many hiking paths through the bush. I created a series of works based on these walks, which were all taken with my partner on our first holiday together. I guess I began thinking about the beauty of the inner journey; what is gained and lost as we progress, and how we are continuously transformed by our experience. And this idea of transformation and change was present in the landscape we walked through, that the path itself was different for everyone who walked it. Things unseen but deeply felt. Katie Daniels, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Katie Daniels_Before they all came true.jpg

title: Tjuntala ngurangka (country with acacia wattle)
description: I was born near the Wintinna Homestead close to Oodnadatta in South Australia. When I was young we would walk everywhere. That’s how I know this country so well. My painting is about the tjuntala tree (native acacia wattle) that grows everywhere near Oodnadatta and the far east of Indulkana. The flowers are bright yellow and are very beautiful. When the flowers come, it is my favourite time of year, they are so special. My parents taught me how to grind the tjuntala flowers with sand and ashes. We would grind them together into a paste to eat – it’s very sweet and delicious! Nellie Coutlhard, 2018
image_path: data/images/2018_Nellie Coulthard_Tjuntala ngurangka _country with acacia wattle_.jpg

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: The Trustees of the Art Gallery of New South Wales has awarded the inaugural Roberts Family Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Prize to Wawiriya Burton for Ngayuku Ngura (my Country) . Wawiriya Burton is a senior woman from the Amata community. In this painting, she tells the story of her father’s country near Pipalyatjara, west of Amata in South Australia. It depicts minyma mingkiri tjuta (small female desert mice). The mingkiri are pregnant and give birth to many babies. They then journey to the surrounding rock holes in search of food and water for their young. The dotted lines are mingkiri tracks. ‘A long time ago, when we were little children, we ran around Puta Puta and Ilitjata, our grandfather’s and father’s ground, and because of this we grew up strong. Why? Because it’s Anangu country – Aboriginal people’s Country – of their spirit.’ Wawiriya Burton, 2017

title: Queenstown, Tasmania
description: This painting is the result of eight days spent in the Tasmanian wilderness, totally ‘off grid’. I was waking up at 4.30am every morning, jet-lagged and fatigued after a month in London with family and friends. Camping along the river, I’d spend hours alone every morning, immersing myself in the landscape and climate, painting the light, mood and colour of the Australian bush. Painting, for me, is a spiritual experience; during this time, I was able to connect with nature and with the energy of the earth. This work is an expression of both that journey, and a resetting of my inner self. Christian Bonett, 2018

title: Minyma kutjara tjukurpa
description: Maringka Baker is a senior Pitjantjatjara artist living in the remote community settlement of Kanpi, on the South Australian Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands. She was born around 1952 at Kaliumpil rock hole, a traditional camping area in Western Australia. Her painting style is distinguished by a mastery of tone and a self-assured command of colour and composition, which she uses to express a deep connection and knowledge of country. Her work is highly sought after by a loyal group of collectors, and she has been hugely influential on a younger generation of APY artists. Tjungu Palya, Nyapari community, 2018

title: Landscape
description: In the 1970s, Nyapanyapa Yununpingu survived a near-fatal buffalo goring whilst collecting bush apples. Forty years later, in a significant departure from traditional sacred art, she created an installation called Incident at Mutpi consisting of a bark painting and a personal video narration about the attack, filmed at the Buku-Larrnggay Mulka Centre in Yirrkala in the Northern Territory. The work won an award at the 2008 Telstra National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Awards. That night, she had a nightmare about the buffalo and vowed never to paint the beast again. This work is a painting of the native orchard where she was attacked: a gentle landscape of bush apple trees. Buku-Larrnggay Mulka Centre, 2017

title: Ngayuku ngura – tjala tjukurpa (honey ant country)
description: Yaritji Young is a traditional owner for tjala tjukurpa, near the Amata community in South Australia. She paints the rock holes and landmarks of her country, entwined with icons and traditional marks that relate to inma (dance) and tjukurpa (dreaming). The twisted lines and shapes mimic tunnels and formations made by the tjala honey ant. ‘My paintings are of my country: my father’s country, my grandmother’s country, the tjala country. Everything that my grandmother taught me, I’m teaching to my grandchildren now. They dance because I have shared what I got from my grandmother with my granddaughters, so they can know their culture.’ – Yaritji Young, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Yaritji Young_Ngayuku ngura _ tjala tjukurpa _honey ant country_.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Yaritji Young_Ngayuku ngura _ tjala tjukurpa _honey ant country_

title: Landscape abstraction
description: Landscape abstraction is part of a series of miniature paintings that I have been developing over the years as a personal diary. The series pays tribute to the Tang dynasty poem The arduous road to Shu by Li Bo, in which he described the dizzying cliffs, deep ravines and hidden dangers of the journey from Chang’an to Shu. I have always thought of this poem as being allegorical in some ways and can empathise with the venture as each painting represents my own mountainous and sometimes tortuous journey as an artist. Chee Yong, 2017

title: Mother tree – Morning Bay
description: Over a period of 11 years, I have sat beneath a powerful grey mangrove in a remote lagoon near Pittwater, NSW . On thick hand-made paper, I have carved her trunk with a belt sander, digging through the ink to reveal her – a scarification of carved lines that build a bridge over the vast landscape towards my inner world. Joshua Yeldham, 2017

title: Little hinterland no 1
description: This painting is based on a landscape very close to home. I often walk up the hill behind our house where I can gain some elevation and enjoy the view across the valley. There is some remnant native vegetation here which I have used to frame the view. I have employed the graphic qualities of the half-dead shrubs and trees to develop a tracery through which one can still discern the distant horizon. My admiration for the paintings of Claude Lorrain and John Constable is evident in my choice of a ‘portrait’ format to heighten the drama of the sky and the trees. Philip Wolfhagen, 2017

title: Shadows of Shaw
description: Shaw is a sun mat representing the life given by mirri (the sun) as it moves across the landscape. The sacred, decorative mat is woven by the women of Peppimenarti in the Northern Territory using pandanus strands. The pandanus grows on the banks of the Tom Turner River, which runs alongside the community and casts shadows on the water. Like the mat, Shadows of Shaw represents the water and the flow of the river through the community. A landscape of pandanus creates reflections on the surface of the water from the life-giving rays of mirri, producing shadows at waltyi or mirri kultyi (sunset). This is a story from my mother’s dreaming. Regina Pilawuk Wilson, 2017

artist: Mumu Mike Williams, Willy Muntjantji Martin, Sammy Dodd
title: Ngura (country)
medium: acrylic, ink and acrylic marker pen on canvas mailbags, with kulata (spear) made from punu (wood), malu pulyku (kangaroo tendon) and kiti (resin made from spinifex grass)
description: This is a land rights painting, with writing in Pitjantjatjara so people can see and know that our tjukurpa (law and culture) and our manta (land) are still strong and our wangka (language) is still alive. The painting is on Australia Post mailbags – this is about ownership. Government always want to say that something belongs to them, but I’m saying ‘wiya (no), this belongs to Anangu, the traditional owners’. For this painting, I worked together with two other tjilpi (senior men) from Mimili [in South Australia]. Sammy Dodd made the kulata (spear) using the proper irititja (traditional) way. The kulata stands for strong men’s culture, protecting our manta and guarding the tjukurpa. Willy Muntjantji Martin painted his mother’s country, Piltati, near Nyapari, and the wanampi (watersnake) tjukurpa from there. Mumu Mike Williams, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Mumu Mike Williams_ Willy Muntjantji Martin_ Sammy Dodd_Ngura _country_.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Mumu Mike Williams_ Willy Muntjantji Martin_ Sammy Dodd_Ngura _country_

title: Bamurrungu
medium: natural earth pigments on hollow tree trunk
description: Bamurrungu is a sacred rock, which stands at the mouth of the Gurka’wuy River within Trial Bay, above Blue Mud Bay, north-east Arnhem Land. The river flows past this rock, clashing in turbulent unity with the incoming tidal waters from the deep ocean. Bamurrungu is surrounded by wawurritjpal (sea mullet). When Yolngu perform ritual dances for Marrakulu clan events, participants move towards a held spear representing the steadfastness of the rock. It splits the dancers, who then surround Bamurrungu, moving like the sea to song and rhythm. This trunk of the stringy bark tree represents the submerged rock Bamurrungu and symbolises the foundation landscape of Gurka’wuy, Trial Bay. Buku-Larrnggay Mulka Centre, 2017

title: Callitris, Oratunga
medium: gouache, watercolour and ink on paper
description: This drawing comes from a walk down Oratunga Creek towards Glass Gorge in the Flinders Ranges, South Australia. The most common trees are callitris, or black cypress, a quick-growing, fire-sensitive and relatively short-lived tree. Their timber is inedible for termites, so the dead skeletons remain standing for some time. The floor of the creek gorge is littered with debris: tangles of fencing wire, twisted sheets of iron. Now and then, there are petroglyphs of small engraved circles on the rock walls. The hum and light echo an ancient hymn: ‘We blossom and flourish as leaves on the tree, And wither and perish – but naught changeth Thee.’ John R Walker, 2017

title: The artist
description: The human skin is far more than a life support system, it is a modern-day canvas. Tattoos can display the life story of an individual, exploring their relationships, experiences, ideology and culture over periods of time. Permanent markings can either attract or repel the viewer. They provoke us to think and ask the question: ‘what goes on inside a person’s mind to cover their body with their life story, exposed for all to see?’ Tattoos allow you to express your personality, without having to say a thing. Paul Trefry, 2017

title: No place is without a name (Para Creek, Wodi Wodi country)
description: Commenced on site and completed in the studio, this watercolour relates to a place that I sometimes visit on early morning walks. What draws me here are its essential elements: the patterns of the landforms, the flora and the gorgeous light. There is an understated, timeless quality in this landscape that I find so compelling and have tried to convey in this work. Tony Tavares, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Tony Tavares_No place is without a name _Para Creek_ Wodi Wodi country_.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Tony Tavares_No place is without a name _Para Creek_ Wodi Wodi country_

title: Time and tide
description: Time and tide is from a series of paintings that I am currently working on about the Australian coastal landscape. These paintings are about time past and the promise of slowing down in the future; the anticipation, contemplation, sunlight and shadows, still salt air and silent static moments. Approaching the landscape as a living vessel of memory, the work considers how certain places conjure images from the past, tempered with the transient shadow of the present. They express personal embedded ideas about my own experiences of place and of those that have been here before. Robyn Sweaney, 2017

title: The Arcadian repose
description: In my opinion it is axiomatic that if a painting requires an explanatory text it has failed. In this particular painting, the title is explicit. Tim Storrier, 2017

title: Relics from romantic attachments
