description: An object, sometimes extraordinary, sometimes ordinary, can tell a story or reflect on a watershed event. Relics from romantic attachments navigates the nostalgia or sentiment built into an object. Like any complex form of human behaviour, collecting objects to remind us of something important has many meanings, both at the level of the individual and of a wider culture. The most fragile aspects of these vessels have been elongated and exaggerated to create a bottle neck, in turn exploring the nostalgia placed on objects with functional values, turning memories into delicate things that could break. Alexandra Standen, 2017

title: Sun shines in the rusty morning
description: Sun shines in the rusty morning is my response to memories of growing up on a farm in the Riverina, in south-western New South Wales. It’s a studio painting built from photographs and recollections. I’m interested in using colour, composition and gesture to describe a scene, to create a sense of place that conveys what it feels like to be in a particular landscape. Rowan Robertson, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Rowan Robertson_Sun shines in the rusty morning.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Rowan Robertson_Sun shines in the rusty morning

title: Antara
description: Antara in South Australia is an extremely important site for Ngupulya Pumani and her family. Antara is her mother’s country. This place and its significant maku (witchetty grub) tjukurpa were a constant in the paintings of her mother, the late Kunmanara (Milatjari) Pumani. Today, Ngupulya and her younger sister Betty Kuntiwa Pumani are proud custodians of this country; they map its significance and hold its stories strong in their paintings. Ngupulya says: ‘Antara is my mother’s country. She taught me the stories and showed me the places, like one special rock hole where women would have inma (ceremony). Now I remember her when I paint Antara.’ Mimili Maku Arts, 2017

title: Antara
description: Antara in South Australia is an extremely important site for Betty Kuntiwa Pumani and her family. Antara is her mother’s country. This place and its significant maku (witchetty grub) tjukurpa were a constant in the paintings of her mother, the late Kunmanara (Milatjari) Pumani. Today, Betty and her older sister Ngupulya Pumani are proud custodians of this country; they map its significance and hold its stories strong in their paintings. Betty’s signature reds evoke the rocky desert country of Antara, while simultaneously suggesting blood or viscera and an unmistakable energy. The contrasting areas of white and its subtle tonal shifts are a quiet and patient counterpoint to the pulsating reds. Mimili Maku Arts, 2017

title: Pernicious
medium: acrylic spray-paint and charcoal on paper
description: Sometimes the things mankind does in the name of progress, religion or the greater good, for itself and the planet beggar belief! It makes me think of a virus, a particularly virulent one. Watching the news from the Middle East, looking on with dismay as centuries of architecture or culture are reduced to rubble, and lives to dust, I feel that perhaps mankind resembles a virus that is pernicious and all-consuming. Angus Nivison, 2017

title: Untitled
description: This painting draws on designs associated with the site of Marrapinti, west of Kiwirrkurra, a rock hole amidst the endless dunes of the Gibson Desert. Here, a large group of ancestral women camped and made nose bones, also called marrapinti, before continuing their travels to the east, through Wala Wala, Kiwirrkurra and Ngaminya. On their journey, they gathered the edible berries known as kampurarrpa, or desert raisin, to sustain themselves. Yukultji Napangati, 2017

title: Bellinger River, Thora
description: This watercolour is the result of two-months’ work in Thora, NSW , painting the Bellinger River as it appeared before me. The view that I tried to capture changed throughout each day in relation to the angle of the sun and the weather. Twice the river flooded – once a large flood and one quite minor. But still the variations were confined to the variations that happen to that river, just as I passed through my own moods and issues but remained myself, perhaps both of us hardly knowing ourselves. John Murray, 2017

title: Ngayuku ngura – kapi tjukurla (rock holes near my country, Ti Tree – Anmatyerre country)
description: Barbara Mbitjana Moore grew up in Amoonguna and her father’s country near Ti Tree in the Northern Territory, moving to the Amata community when she was married. In this painting, Barbara has depicted her country near Ti Tree. The different colours and shapes represent variations in the landscape. Some of the landmarks are the rock holes that lie in and around her country. Connected by travel lines, these sites hold important tjukurpa (dreaming). Through her painting, Barbara stays connected to her own country in the Northern Territory, even though she lives far away. She draws inspiration from the wildflowers that carpet the desert in spring. Tjala Arts, Amata community, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Barbara Mbitjana Moore_Ngayuku ngura _ kapi tjukurla _rock holes near my country_ Ti Tree _ Anmatyerre country_.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Barbara Mbitjana Moore_Ngayuku ngura _ kapi tjukurla _rock holes near my country_ Ti Tree _ Anmatyerre country_

title: Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa (Seven Sisters story). Kapi tjukurla tjuta (many rock holes)
description: Naomi Kantjuriny and Mona Mitakiki paint kapi tjukurla (rock holes) that relate to the Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa. This story involves the Seven Sisters being chased across country by a bad man (Wati Nyiru). The elder sisters protect and teach the younger ones, and keep them from falling for his tricks. Wati Nyiru can change shape into different rock formations and landmarks. These sites remain part of the landscape and are important Anangu ceremonial places. The Seven Sisters story is very important to Anangu culture, as a story about family and culture. Mona and Naomi were taught to paint by senior artist Kunmanara Katie Kawiny. She has passed away but the younger women carry her story on for future generations. Tjala Arts, Amata community, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Mona Mitakiki_ Naomi Kantjuriny_Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa _Seven Sisters story__ Kapi tjukurla tjuta _many rock hole.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Mona Mitakiki_ Naomi Kantjuriny_Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa _Seven Sisters story__ Kapi tjukurla tjuta _many rock hole

title: Rainy day, Hill End
description: This is the first painting from a series painted in residency at Haefligers Cottage in Hill End, NSW . When I start a new series, it feels as if I’m pushing a truck from standing – head down, shoulders braced, concentrating hard till the wheels start to move. Small canvases are quick visual poems. They demand intense concentration and concise marks. Plein-air painting in a Hill End winter also forces fast decisions. The winter light is fast-moving and you’re challenged to paint everything you need to say before the sun moves and the clouds set in. Rachel Milne, 2017

title: The bush studio – Jack's Track
description: The bush always waits Rosie and I walk the track I carry my board and easel She carries her stick hoping Dad might finish the painting early today To sit and throw her favourite thing in the world The track is steep and cool in the shade of the mountain Ghost gums finish the work Monet began The fire of late afternoon light burns against the sandstone cliffs across the valley Still cool air makes mixing colour easier This is the blood of our country All answers can be found here In the late afternoon light On that bush track which always waits Ben Milne, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Ben Milne_The bush studio _ Jack_s Track.jpg

title: Self-portrait (for posterity)
description: Though the classical bust is something commonly referenced and ever-present in contemporary art and society, the tradition, practice and materiality of the bust is a dying art. With this plasticised and defaced self-portrait I don’t intend to mock tradition, more to present a version of a traditional standard that aligns itself with the material values of the 21st century. Guy Maestri, 2017

title: Landscape as self-portrait
medium: acrylic, oil and enamel on canvas
description: I call my work psychological landscapes. In a way, the roads and houses are always something more than just roads and houses. The cracks, drains, shadows, rips and glitter are stand-ins for emotional states, or symbolic of greater themes of life. I am interested in communicating what it feels like to be in our world in this time. The more personal I seem to make my paintings, the more they connect with others. William Mackinnon, 2017

title: FNQ
description: My work FNQ – as in Far North Queensland – is a scene made up from a combination of photos I have taken or seen in books and magazines. I grew up in Brisbane so I know the Queenslander-style house very well. However, I have never been to Far North Queensland, so my work is imagined but features things I know are there like palm trees, Hills Hoist clotheslines and the mountains in from the coast. Noel McKenna, 2017

title: Beneath this dry land
description: A few years ago, a friend who lives in the high country north of Jindabyne [in the NSW Snowy Mountain region], mentioned a tree near his place that has wild dogs hanging from it. I had never heard of anything like it. The drive there takes you past the Gungarlin River, a popular picnic spot for the early settlers, and then onto Snowy Plain Road where the landscape is silent until you see the dogs hanging in different states of decay, some mummified. These spectral ‘dog trees’ go back to the earliest days of European settlement and this old Eucalypt has been in use for over 60 years. Fiona Lowry, 2017

title: Ngayuku ngura
description: Manyitjanu Lennon often paints her mother’s country west of Kaltjiti and south of Watarru in South Australia. This is a painting of Mamungari’nya. As Manyitjanu describes the country: ‘Mamungari’nya is a long way away. It is over the other side of the sand dunes past Tipilnga, a place where many white trees grow. This is the place where women came and were turned into the white marble gums on the sand dune south of Watarru – this is a tjukurpa story. So, this is Mamungari’nya where lots of little gum saplings and emu bush grow. This is a place of claypans and a women’s site.’ Kaltitji Arts, 2017

title: Great Dividing Range
description: This view is of the Main Range of the Snowy Mountains in Kosciuszko National Park, New South Wales. I went there as part of a hiking team, and did the iconic 19-kilometre walk from Charlotte Pass to the summit of Mount Kosciuszko. This particular vista of a landscape once covered by glaciers – the sweeping valley, the chilly weather, the strong breeze, the shimmering, scattered flat stones in the foreground reflecting the sunlight, and the contrast present in the scene – immediately struck a chord. The landscape made a strong impression on me, I felt an urge to attempt to capture it on canvas. Dinesh Kumar, 2017

title: That which provides safety and the possibility of growth, that which you can put your trust in
medium: Jingdezhen porcelain, Southern Ice porcelain, terracotta clay, paraffin wax, resin, silk thread, merino wool, fox and rabbit pelt, Tibetan gazelle horns, teeth, echidna quills, bodhi seeds, marine ply and treated pine
description: This installation is a heady mix of artefact and disturbing viscera, a kind of contemporary shamanism, playing with representations and perceptions of the human and animal condition. The universal language here represents the outsider versus the insider, acceptance and isolation, connection and displacement – a theme that is constant in the lives of people living in remote areas, though is ultimately united by the human condition. The juxtaposition of inanimate materials is suggestive of the cycle of life. It also creates the sense that the work is alive, in an ironic way, as all living things decay. Juz Kitson, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Juz Kitson_That which provides safety and the possibility of growth_ that which you can put your trust in.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Juz Kitson_That which provides safety and the possibility of growth_ that which you can put your trust in

title: Ngayuku ngura tali tjukurpa (my country near Wingellina, sand dune country)
description: Ray Ken is a senior artist from the Amata community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) region in Central Australia. His paintings reflect his intimate knowledge of the landscape and reminisce about long journeys traversing the sandhills of his country as a stockman. He also shares his deep understanding of Anangu culture. ‘When we are resting, it will be the young fellas’ turn to look after our country. This is the Anangu way. As they’ve been growing up, they’ve been learning how our stories can make you strong inside – and to be strong is to keep culture safe so that nothing can take it away.’ – Ray Ken, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Ray Ken_Ngayuku ngura tali tjukurpa _my country near Wingellina_ sand dune country_.jpg
image_stem: 2017_Ray Ken_Ngayuku ngura tali tjukurpa _my country near Wingellina_ sand dune country_

title: Painting 218 (The Domain)
description: This landscape is a reflection of everyday life. It depicts a walk that I took to the Art Gallery of New South Wales with my son. It had just stopped raining and the sun was reflecting on the wet trees and pathway, creating a silvery light. I enjoyed experimenting with collage to produce this work. It is one of the more abstract landscapes I have produced. It felt free from formal constraints. I worked quickly and intensely on each assembled piece. Applying thin acrylic washes to raw plywood added an element of unpredictability and immediacy, like working in a sketchpad. Alan Jones, 2017

title: Nyangatja Watarru
description: Nyangatja Watarru is about a special place called Watarru [in South Australia]. Watarru is my home. Anangu tjuta (people) are moving around, between waterholes and creeks, looking for food. They search in the daytime, walking slowly and patiently around my country, trusting that they will find something to bring back to the children who are waiting at camp. When the water dries up at one place, they move on to the next waterhole. If there’s no water, they keep walking until they find something. Knowing where to find the water is special knowledge. Beryl Jimmy, 2017

title: Wilpena eucalypt and wattle
description: Wilpena Pound is an amphitheatre of mountains in South Australia’s Flinders Ranges National Park. Nicholas Harding describes his response to working from this landscape as: 'Reflected sky pooling in stream water. Wattle blooms amongst bark and bough. Bleaching light refracted through twigs and leaves. Birdsong and insect buzz. Wilpena in the spring.’ Nicholas Harding, 2017

title: Reflection #10
description: Reflection #10 is inspired by the images of 17th- and 18th-century ceramics and textiles related to explorations, discovering new land and utopia. Like a mirror, these works superimpose, reflect and mix the history and reality, culture and society of the country in which I find myself, together with my personal imagination and my home country’s history through time. Beyond the narrative of history, Reflection #10 discusses the sensitive, fragile, yet deep and serene psychological world of humans: where we are from, where we are going. Guan Wei, 2017

title: Fitzroy Falls
description: My father’s aunt, Vera Wormley, married Albert Edgar Victor Gordon Earle. They spent their honeymoon visiting Fitzroy Falls [in the NSW Southern Highlands]. Ever since hearing that story as a child, I have had a soft spot in my heart for that special place. I hope my plein-air painting of it has done it justice. Neil Evans, 2017

title: Passage to Rungli Rungliot
description: Rungli Rungliot, from the language of the Sauria Paharia people of West Bengal, translates as ‘thus far and no further’. It is the name given to a Tasmanian Highland hut nestled in a sapling forest in the land of a thousand lakes. Sixty years ago, the original owners of the hut found their Eden. It was a place to be at peace with the world – they needed to search no more. I travelled to this place and immersed myself in the trees next to the lake where I documented and created drawings and paintings, both day and night. James Drinkwater, 2017

title: Love lies bleeding
description: I love my garden. Living on a property with a few acres means when I need to expand the garden I move a fence. This bed was paddock. I have planted trees that will one day be spectacular in front of the rocks. For now, I have planted love lies bleeding, orange button chrysanthemums and dahlias. I needed to use the reds and orange after looking at Elizabeth Cummings’ paintings. Lucy Culliton, 2017

title: Ngayuku mamaku ngura (my father’s country), minyma mingkiri tjuta (small desert female mice)
description: Wawiriya Burton is a senior woman from the Amata community. In this painting, she tells the story of her father’s country near Pipalyatjara, west of Amata in South Australia. It depicts minyma mingkiri tjuta (small female desert mice). The mingkiri are pregnant and give birth to many babies. They then journey to the surrounding rock holes in search of food and water for their young. The dotted lines are mingkiri tracks. ‘A long time ago, when we were little children, we ran around Puta Puta and Ilitjata, our grandfather’s and father’s ground, and because of this we grew up strong. Why? Because it’s Anangu country – Aboriginal people’s Country – of their spirit.’ Wawiriya Burton, 2017
image_path: data/images/2017_Kunmanara _Wawiriya_ Burton_Ngayuku mamaku ngura _my father_s country__ minyma mingkiri tjuta _small desert female .jpg
image_stem: 2017_Kunmanara _Wawiriya_ Burton_Ngayuku mamaku ngura _my father_s country__ minyma mingkiri tjuta _small desert female

title: Minyma Malilunya
description: This painting depicts the story of Malilu, an important creation being. Malilu was a crippled woman. As she moved and preformed a sacred inma (dance) she left peculiar tracks in the sand. Her two daughters ran off to get married, leaving her to fend for herself. It was very hard for her to collect bush foods and water because she had to drag her leg as she walked. Through much effort she collected desert raisins, bush tomatoes, berries and many different kinds of wild foods. Teresa Baker, 2017

title: Bulli: bricks and black diamonds
description: As a teenager, the abandoned brickworks behind this house was our playground, a refuge from high school and a place to skateboard. I have lived in the suburbs north of Wollongong my whole life, an area once defined by its heavy industry and the postwar brick and fibro houses, squeezed between the coast and the towering escarpment. In my practice, I use woodblock printing techniques combined with painting to depict the vernacular architecture. This house, like many others, is vulnerable to the changing circumstances in recent years. By carving the image I create a level of density that ensures permanence, whether the existing structure remains or is destroyed. Christopher Zanko, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Christopher Zanko_Bulli_ bricks and black diamonds.jpg

title: Djuḏutjuḏumun djinawa guṉḏirrŋura (pardalotes nesting inside termite mound)
description: These idiosyncratic tall, thin, grey, slab-like magnetic termite mounds are almost flatly two dimensional and oriented north-south so they receive the warmth of the eastern and western sun but don’t suffer the extreme heat of midday. The termites, munyukuluŋu, are eusocial. This is the highest form of communality and includes sharing the care of their offspring. These insects feed the ecosystem, including the forest itself, and also live in balance with others, including ferocious meat ants, ŋäḏi, which often share their nest. Even the tiny birds known as pardalotes, or djuḏutjuḏumun, nest within these constructions. Mulkuṉ Wirrpanda, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Mulkuṉ Wirrpanda_Djuḏutjuḏumun djinawa guṉḏirrŋura _pardalotes nesting inside termite mound_.jpg
image_stem: 2020_Mulkuṉ Wirrpanda_Djuḏutjuḏumun djinawa guṉḏirrŋura _pardalotes nesting inside termite mound_

title: Fireground 2 (for Matty H)
description: In Braidwood, NSW , during last summer’s horrific bushfires, we were dominated by an all-pervasive smoke, on streets where the only movement was the endless queues of emergency service tankers refuelling. One of the firefighters, Matty H, told me he and his crew would reverse their truck in close to the threatened houses, fight the fire, then when it got too hot they’d hightail it out a few hundred metres. Once the flames subsided they’d reverse back in and resume the fight, for hours non-stop. Matty was exhausted, running on adrenaline. Fireground 2 (for Matty H) is what I saw in his eyes. John R Walker, 2020

title: Silent spring
description: My paintings have long responded to the particular conditions of the Australian landscape – the sheer expansiveness of the land, the splendour and severity of colour, and specifically the quality of light. In the extreme circumstances of 2019–20, each of those conditions was dramatically altered, practically and emotionally. The openness of this diptych’s structure, the fluidity of the pigments and the potential in the material residue signal the manner in which nature will reconstitute form in the most unpredictable way. The title Silent spring references the environmental science book by Rachel Carson published in 1962. Aida Tomescu, 2020

title: Untitled
description: This painting relates to the claypan site known as Mamultjjulkulnga, on the edge of Wilkinkarra (Lake Mackay) in Western Australia. This site is of great importance to me as it is where my father passed away. After rain, this claypan becomes a large shallow freshwater lake, which provides ideal conditions for the fleshy shrub known in Pintupi as mungilya. In ancestral times, two Tingari men of the Tjungurrayi and Tjapaltjarri kinship groups camped at this site. They gathered the seeds from Mungilya which, when ground into a paste, is roasted in the campfire coals to produce a type of unleavened bread. George Tjungurrayi, 2020

title: Prayer for rain
medium: synthetic polymer paint, gouache on 54 canvas boards
description: A flower meadow is an unusual subject for an Australian landscape – we are more familiar with the harsh realities of fire, drought and flood. Yet such gentle, quiet and fecund places exist on our continent – notably in the subalpine areas of NSW , Victoria and Tasmania. And indeed proximity to the summer meadows of the Kosciusko National Park was one of the reasons I moved with my family to Cooma, 25 years ago. But here the meadow of daisies is also a metaphor for the self. So we pray: ‘ MINE THOU LORD OF LIFE , SEND MY ROOTS RAIN’. Imants Tillers, 2020

title: The plague year (an itinerant’s repose)
description: If a work of art requires an explanatory text, the meaning and purpose of the work has failed. If the text communicates the aim of the work accurately why have the work? Just display the text. With a well-considered work of art, the less said the better. Tim Storrier, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Tim Storrier_The plague year _an itinerant_s repose_.jpg

artist: Keith Stevens, Taylor Cooper, Witjiti George
title: Piltati–Malara: wanampi tjukurpa
description: Witjiti George and Keith Stevens are cousins, Taylor Cooper their uncle. Mr Stevens was visiting Kaltjiti from his hometown of Nyapari in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia, when they made this work. The tjilpi pampas (elder men) got talking about painting their story together. And so, they did… George and Stevens share the Piltati wanampi tjukurpa – a story about two water snakes and their homeland. Cooper paints Malara wanampi tjukurpa – the place of the water serpent. ‘This painting is our story, this is our Country, this is our culture.’ – Keith Stevens, Taylor Cooper, Witjiti George, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Keith Stevens_ Taylor Cooper_ Witjiti George_Piltati_Malara_ wanampi tjukurpa.jpg
image_stem: 2020_Keith Stevens_ Taylor Cooper_ Witjiti George_Piltati_Malara_ wanampi tjukurpa

title: Proposal for a humble monument
description: There is no place for ‘humble’ in public space, particularly in marble monuments. Public spaces represent our shared values. Those change constantly. Isn’t it time we considered a humble monument? Something with a little more humility, something that acknowledges our imperfection – that we have gotten it wrong, and will get it wrong again, that we are constantly evolving, constantly learning. The kneeling figure contained in the block is made from an old hand-picked piece of Australian Molong marble that sat in a quarry yard for years, used as the recalibration weight to check the accuracy of their scales. Alex Seton, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Alex Seton_Proposal for a humble monument.jpg

title: White Christmas, Bell, NSW
description: Immediately after the fires of December 2019 I walked through the ashen bush and as the stumps and ground were still hot and smouldering it struck me I was immersed in a predominantly white landscape. The bark of the trees was dotted with fine white powdery ash and the nuts and pods had cracked open, spilling their seeds. Though the forest floor retained an incredible heat, the sky had momentarily cleared to form crisp blue shards against the shapes left after the blaze. Various versions of white had briefly formed a fine downy layer all over the place, changing my way of seeing a habitat gutted by fire into a visual cleanse rather than a sooty black mess. Luke Sciberras, 2020

title: No man is an island
description: At the halfway stage of this work, the shapes began to resemble a floating island reminiscent of Swiss artist Arnold Böcklin’s third painting of The isle of the dead 1883, which features towering cliff faces. I then developed the painting further, with Böcklin in mind. At around the same time, I came across John Donne’s prose work Devotions upon emergent occasions 1624 in which two lines are memorable: ‘No man is an island’ and ‘For whom the bell tolls’. I use the first of these as my title, noting that we should feel a sense of belonging to the whole of the human race. Gareth Sansom, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Gareth Sansom_No man is an island.jpg

title: Symbiosis (bluebeard orchid)
medium: hyrdrostone, canvas, paint, epoxy glass, stainless steel, wood, hardware
description: Symbiosis (bluebeard orchid) is a sculpture influenced by the endemic bluebeard orchid and 19th-century botanical models made by Brendel, a German company. The sculpture supports elements of 21st-century infrastructure and grows avaricious tongues. The work points to the Symbiocene, a future where man-made systems attempt to align with nature, rather than overpower it. Caroline Rothwell, 2020

title: Ngayuku ngura
description: When I paint my mind travels back to my Country. I had to move to Adelaide for medical treatment many years ago. So now when I paint, I am right on my Country in the western Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, near Pipalyatjara in South Australia. I am not able to be there to look after this Country anymore, but through my painting I celebrate the tjukurpa of the Country and keep it alive, so my painting is caring for Country too. Margaret Richards, 2020

title: Tjoritja (West MacDonnell Ranges, NT)
description: I am a Western Aranda man. My family believe giant caterpillars called the Yeperenye became Tjoritja (West MacDonnell Ranges in the distant past). The giant caterpillars entered through gaps in the ranges. In this painting the trees are a symbol for caterpillars coming through to the Country, and they travelled from Mount Zeil past Mparntwe (Alice Springs) to Emily Gap. I believe Emily Gap to be part of the West MacDonnell Ranges (although other people refer to them as the East MacDonnell Ranges). I got all the ideas for the painting from my father, Ruben Pareroultja, because he was a Western Aranda man. Hubert Pareroultja, 2020

title: Nobbys Head – storm approaching Newcastle
description: The lighthouse on Nobbys Head sits at the entrance to Newcastle Harbour, like a sentinel standing guard. On this day, walking along the breakwall that juts out into the ocean, one could imagine being aboard a ship, looking back towards Nobbys Head and the city of Newcastle. The scene was sketched very quickly as the storm came rolling in from the south. Turneresque skies with Sargent’s descriptive brushwork provide the influences to maximise the drama. Painted just before the COVID-19 lockdown, it seems to be a premonition of impending danger. Gino Palmieri, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Gino Palmieri_Nobbys Head _ storm approaching Newcastle.jpg

title: Afternoon light on coral house
description: In my practice I am interested in capturing the atmospheric effect of the transitional light phases that occur between day and night on the urban and natural landscape. In this particular work, I wanted to reflect the time of day when the setting sun is close to the horizon, causing the light that is hitting the angular houses and surrounding flora to appear softer, and immersing the streetscape in the warm tones of the fading light. Lucy O’Doherty, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Lucy O_Doherty_Afternoon light on coral house.jpg

title: Untitled
description: This painting depicts designs associated with Yunala, a rock hole and soakage water site situated among sandhills just to the west of the Kiwirrkura community in the Gibson Desert in Western Australia. During ancestral times, a group of women camped at the site, digging the edible roots of the bush banana or silky-pear vine, also known as yunala. The lines in this painting represent both the sandhills surrounding the site as well as the yunala tubers underground, and the concentric circles surrounded by the ‘U’ shapes depict groups of women camped together. Yukultji Napangati, 2020

title: Ngalyod at Kubumi
medium: natural pigments and PVA fixative on bark (Eucalyptus tetradonta)
description: The large lorrkkon (hollow log) depicts two Ngalyod (rainbow serpents) at the site Kubumi on Kulmarru clan country. Ngalyod is an important female creator ancestor in Kuninjku religion, associated with the storms and the tempestuous weather of the wet season. Kubumi is a series of deep waterholes along the Mann River that are connected by underground tunnels that Ngalyod created and where she rests today. The site is owned jointly by the Kurulk, Kulmarru and Bordoh clans. In this work, the Ngalyod are depicted with forked tongues, sharp teeth and fin-like tails, referencing the freshwater bodies she inhabits and guards. Paul Namarinjmak Nabulumo, 2020

title: Ngangkari ngura (healing place)
description: This is my Country, Yalungu, south of Watarru, in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia. It is a place where the emus drink at the waterhole. The emus made this shelter at Yalungu, which I love to paint, and their emu tracks were made as they travel. There is a rock shelter above, and below this there is good ground for the emus. My paintings are about ngangkari (traditional healers/healing practices) and sites related to healing. I’ve painted rock holes and the water flowing through the landscape, just like the energy that flows through people and places – it’s invisible to most people, but ngangkari can see spirits and feel a lot of different energy. Betty Muffler, 2020

title: Yalaŋbara (sand dunes at Yalaŋbara)
description: The design contains the identity of the coastal place of Yalaŋbara – some of the finest sand dunes in the Northern Territory towering above a windswept oceanic beach near the junction of the Arafura Sea and the Gulf of Carpentaria. It’s an important place for the Yolŋu people, especially the Dhuwa moiety, as it’s the landing site of the Djaŋ’kawu – the major creator beings for everything associated with the Dhuwa. Arriving at sunrise, the Sisters prepare for the first birth, a self-fertilised act of creation. Their white hair, Djawulu, is symbolic of sacred wisdom. Mawalan is the name given to the sacred staff the Sisters use to create springs and rocks and other features in their later journeys through the land of other Dhuwa clans. The design shows saltwater drying on their skin, the sand slipping down as the Sisters mount the dunes. The sun has risen on the birth of a nation: the Rirratjiŋu clan. Dhuwarrwarr Marika, 2020

title: Lightning and the rock
medium: natural pigments and printer toner on bark (Eucalyptus tetradonta)
description: This is a monolithic rock off the coast of north-east Arnhem Land, just north of Cape Shield in the Northern Territory. It is emblematic as a statue of the ancestors. This Madarrpa clan rock is set immovable in deep water hit by the electric ‘curse’ that the snake spits into the sky in the form of lightning and the oceanic sea spray. Millennia of cyclonic wave action cannot shift its holy foundation. Noŋgirrŋa Marawili, 2020

title: The rain song
description: There is an immense old sheep station in Wilcannia (north-western NSW ) where I go to paint from time to time. In the homestead’s front-yard is a grand old cactus garden. All attempts at its upkeep were abandoned years ago and it is being reclaimed by its harsh surrounding landscape. It is somehow unsettling and represents an extraordinarily slow dance between man and nature. It gives me a sense of the persistent march of time, of our often-futile attempts at controlling our environment. It also inspired this painting – the first I have ever made from memory. Guy Maestri, 2020

title: Anumara
description: I am painting my family’s place called Anumara, near Irrunytju (Wingellina), in Western Australia. Anumara is also the name for a type of caterpillar and Anumara is the tjukurpa place for this caterpillar. When I am painting I am thinking like the caterpillars, and creating anumara tjina tjuta (many tracks), like they are crawling, crawling everywhere on Country. In the wintertime you can see these caterpillars everywhere. Ara irititja (a long time ago), we cooked them in the fire and ate them, but not anymore. Yurpiya Lionel, 2020

title: Spoonfuls of Milo at Kosciuszko
description: Inspired by a recent trip to Thredbo, my painting depicts Harry Seidler’s 1963 ski lodge. My paintings typically depict suburban architecture from the mid century with the use of flat planes of colour, clean geometric forms and a nostalgic inflection. The lodge was the first house I’ve been able to visit and draw in person since the restrictions, so I wanted it to stand isolated, enveloped by trees, the mountain all to itself. I’ve never been inside the house, but like to imagine through my titles what the occupants are doing. A day of skiing, undies wet and noses red, shovelling Milo into hot milk, huddled by a fire. Eliza Gosse, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Eliza Gosse_Spoonfuls of Milo at Kosciuszko.jpg

title: This moment
description: This work reflects upon the absurdity of attempting to dominate and control the natural world. After all, we are products of nature and not separate from it. The human will to control nature is evident in the illustrations of landscapes that we are so used to. Ponder this: when one stands in a landscape, the experience of doing so is utterly different to the experience of looking at an image of the same landscape. This difference is so great that it verges on the farcical. This work depicts that yawning divide, in being a painting of landscape that has been painted. Juan Ford, 2020

title: Gunningrah, Bottom Bullock
description: Bottom Bullock is the name of the paddock on a property on the Monaro, southern NSW . I have been making a series of paintings of the ponds on Charlie Maslin’s farm. He has slowed the watercourse with leaky weirs, creating ponds with reeds and grasses. We have been in drought the past few years and I want to show the positive work that’s being done. I painted a study by the creek while Charlie flew his drone, taking photos in the smoke of the bushfires. Back in the comfort of my studio I made this larger painting from the study. Lucy Culliton, 2020

title: Kulama
medium: natural ochres, binder, gesso primer on linen
description: During his extensive career, Timothy Cook has focused on representing the kulama ceremony, an initiation for young Tiwi people that coincides with the harvest of wild yam in the late wet season when a ring appears around japarra (the moon). The circles in his work symbolise the moon, yam, the ritual circles of the ceremony, and the pwanga (dots) echo the japalinga (stars). Cook paints exclusively with natural red, white and yellow ochres sourced from Country around Melville Island off the Northern Territory coast, creating a rich cultural and material representation of the Tiwi landscape. ‘I will take a painting to heaven so my mother will recognise me.’ – Timothy Cook, 2020

title: Ngalunggirr miinggi (healing spirit)
description: This painting as a whole is about my grandmother entering back into Gaagal, the ocean. Otis Hope Carey, 2020

title: Seven Sisters
description: Kungkarangkalpa – seven pa tjukurpa mulapa ananguku iriti nguru alatjitu tjana kanyiningi munuya lalatja malatja Tjuta nintinu. Ka kuwari tjana ngapartji kanyini. This story has been held by Aṉangu since long ago, passed through generations, and is celebrated today. The Seven Sisters story shares lessons in women’s leadership. It tells women how to be strong, how to look after each other – such important lessons today for our young women and girls. Our future leaders. This year has been hard for artists worldwide because of the coronavirus. It’s been really hard for Aboriginal people in Australia. A lot of Aboriginal people have poor health, so it’s a frightening time. For me, making paintings this year and celebrating my tjukurpa has been more important than ever, it’s something I’ve needed to hold onto. Painting has kept my mind clear and away from the worries of the world. Nyunmiti Burton, 2020 This work was awarded the Roberts Family Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Prize 2020 and was highly commended in the Wynne Prize 2020.

title: Piltarti tjukurpa
description: I am painting a really important place located between Amata and Nyapari communities on the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia – the Piltarti tjukurpa and rock hole. My grandmother was pregnant with my mother at the top of the hill overlooking this rock hole. My mother, Nganyinytja, was an important leader who started the NPY Women’s Council. I have my own commitment to leadership now, having helped senior women start the APY Gallery and Studio for Aṉangu in Adelaide last year; this is where I paint every day I can. I celebrate my culture and work beside other women who have moved to Adelaide. It’s a piece of the APY Lands in the city. Leah Brady, 2020

title: Savage entropy in Payne's grey
description: There is a busy, chaotic feel to my work; a world of debris and clutter that one often finds in the Australian landscape. I often search for places that have a heightened sense of drama and find it particularly in subjects that are in an advanced stage of collapse and decay. The subject of this painting is a mine-tailings pond at Savage River in Tasmania. It is a place of conflict, a landscape where both human interests and wildness compete. Paradoxically, it is also a place of beauty at odds with the drama that is unfolding. Nicholas Blowers, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Nicholas Blowers_Savage entropy in Payne_s grey.jpg

title: Lalla
description: This year has unearthed much chaos and tragedy. The coronavirus pandemic has had an unprecedented impact on our community and forced us inside our homes. As a Victorian currently experiencing stage-four lockdown, some form of escapism is necessary. It’s the small pockets of nature like the one featured in my painting, Lalla , that offer respite and tranquillity amid such challenging conditions. Local parks and gardens enable us to recharge our batteries and are imperative to our physical and mental wellbeing. My painting explores my ongoing interest in the relationship between people and nature within an urban context. Natasha Bieniek, 2020

title: I take it down to the flow
description: I take it down to the flow every time I step into the studio. To do the work I need the abstract, expansive pulse of the brain-space in utter connection to the feeling-self. And all this sensation held somehow by the energy-matter of our physical self, which, in my experience, is more mutable than we have been led to believe. This shiny one looks up and outwards; she knows how to stretch, command and move her being! Del Kathryn Barton, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Del Kathryn Barton_I take it down to the flow.jpg
image_stem: 2020_Del Kathryn Barton_I take it down to the flow

title: Nganampa Ngura (our Country)
description: I made this painting working together with Alec Baker, my oldest friend. Alec and I have known each other our whole lives. We’ve painted our Country – it’s beautiful Country – with a lot of tjukurpa. We protect our Country, we look after it. The tjilpis (senior men) like us to teach the younger people everything about looking after Country, how to protect culture. I’ve painted all different types of punu (trees), because they’re a symbol of Aṉangu culture –  the tree is where our culture starts. Alec has painted his Country, his story – kalaya tjina (emu tracks), tjukula (rock holes), minyma (women) travelling. Peter Mungkuri, 2020
image_path: data/images/2020_Alec Baker_ Peter Mungkuri_Nganampa Ngura _our Country_.jpg

title: Mollitium 2
medium: triptych: watercolour, pencil, charcoal on 21 birch wood panels
description: Mollitium means ‘resilience’ in Latin. Resilience is the Australian bush; she embraces and forgives. My work travels from right to left – from the threat of fire, to escape and regrowth. I’ve drawn wattle, banksia, grevillea, waratah, gumnuts, gum blossoms, seeds and leaves from different native plants, the Gymea lily and the wildlife of the bush. Last summer’s fires were stopped 20 minutes from our family getaway at Burralong Valley, near Laguna in the lower Hunter Valley, NSW . I spend much of my time there, drawing from all that surrounds me. When I walk through the valley, the scents, sounds, textures and colours envelop me and I lose myself. When you’re in nature, I encourage you to stop, stand still, close your eyes and listen, then open your eyes and try to find what you saw, smelt and heard. Julianne Ross Allcorn, 2020

title: Tjala tjukurpa (honey ant story)
description: Yaritji Young is a traditional owner for tjala tjukurpa, from the Amata community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. She paints the rock holes and landmarks of her country, entwined with icons and traditional marks that relate to inma (dance) and tjukurpa (dreaming). The twisted lines and shapes mimic tunnels and formations made by the tjala honey ant. ‘My paintings are of my country: my father’s country, my grandmother’s country, the tjala country. Everything that my grandmother taught me, I’m teaching to my grandchildren now. They dance because I have shared what I got from my grandmother with my granddaughters, so they can know their culture.’ Yaritji Young, 2019

title: Lion Island, Pittwater
medium: acrylic on hand-carved board with cane
description: I am a painter in the dark swell of Lion Island. My boat rolls past the lumps at Broken Bay’s mouth to the calm waters of Smiths Creek, with her cicadas drilling and her still water. I imagine I will send my paint brush roots down, and settle in. Joshua Yeldham, 2019

title: Untitled
description: This painting relates to the lake site of Wilkinkarra (Lake Mackay in Western Australia). In mythological times two Tingari men of the Tjungurrayi and Tjapaltjarri kinship subsections travelled from Wala Wala, near Kiwirrkura, to Marawa on the western side of the lake. From here, they continued to Mamuiltjulkulnga on the northern side of Wilkinkarra. The men gathered at the site to perform the dances and sing the songs associated with the area. George Tjungurrayi, 2019

title: Perfect uncertainty
description: Residencies, travelling to new places and revisiting past landscapes have become an extremely important element of my work. My painting Perfect uncertainty has multiple meanings. It is about light and shade, literally and metaphorically, and colour and balance. Distinctly Australian, this simple home sits facing the street of a small rural town in Victoria. Its facade is open to passing traffic and scrutiny, yet its appearance is softened by the paint colour choices and a tree planted on the verge. One can only imagine what histories have occurred within this small and humble house facing the street. Robyn Sweaney, 2019

title: Piltati, Nyapari munu Ilpin
description: Keith Stevens and Ginger Wikilyiri’s collaborative painting represents the tjukurpa of several sites in the region surrounding the remote Nyapari community in the western Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. Working side by side, the men retell their ancestral stories in their own distinctive styles. Stevens paints the Wanampi tjukurpa and Nyapari tjukurpa. Wikilyiri depicts Ilpin, the site of which he is traditional custodian. ‘This story is very important. An important painting. Real tjukurpa I learnt from my father, so I am doing painting on the canvas now from that story, because my father taught me these stories. Look at the painting. Piltati is a big place; big stories.’ Keith Stevens, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Keith Stevens_ Ginger Wikilyiri_Piltati_ Nyapari munu Ilpin.jpg
image_stem: 2019_Keith Stevens_ Ginger Wikilyiri_Piltati_ Nyapari munu Ilpin

title: Antara
description: Antara is an extremely important ceremonial site close to the Mimili community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. The women in my family have been custodians of this country and the stories that have shaped it for as long as people can recall. I learned about the maku tjukurpa (witchetty grub story) from my mother Milatjari. Like my mother, I map its importance in my paintings. My sister Ngupulya also holds this same story, but we paint it in different ways. The reds in my painting evoke the rocky desert country surrounding Mimili and suggest a continuous energy from the past. Betty Kuntiwa Pumani, 2019

title: Bushfire – minyma mamu
description: Matjangka Nyukana Norris is from the Fregon community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. ‘Mrs Norris’, as she is fondly known, is famous for dancing the minyma mamu inma in which she portrays the ‘monster’ woman. She says of this painting: ‘As the woman walks through the burnt country, she becomes covered in white ash, jumping about on hot coals with a large, bright red mouth, yelping in pain and scaring everyone. She picks up a stick and dances as she goes. She takes the wrong track and finds herself in the path of a big bushfire – Waru pulka pitjanangka.’ Matjangka Nyukana Norris, 2019

title: Untitled
description: The lines in this painting represent the sandhills at the rock hole site of Marrapinti, west of the Pollock Hills in Western Australia. A large group of ancestral women camped at this rock hole before continuing their travels further east, passing through Wala Wala, Kiwirrkura and Ngaminya. While at the site the women made nose bones, also known as marrapinti, which are worn through a hole made in the nose web. These nose bones were originally used by both men and women but are now only inserted by the older generation on ceremonial occasions. As the women continued their travels towards the east they gathered the edible berries known as kampurarrpa or desert raisin. Mantua Nangala, 2019

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: I’ve painted my country and all the different types of trees there. Trees are a symbol of Anangu culture – the punu (tree) is where our culture starts. This is beautiful country and we protect our country. Anangu have so much knowledge about country, it’s an important part of our culture to pass that knowledge on to the next generation. Peter Mungkuri, 2019

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: Barbara Mbitjana Moore grew up in Amoonguna and her father’s country near Ti Tree in the Northern Territory, moving to the Amata community in Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia when she was married. In this painting, Barbara has depicted her country near Ti Tree. The different colours and shapes represent variations in the landscape. Some of the landmarks are the rock holes that lie in and around her country. Connected by travel lines, these sites hold important tjukurpa (dreaming). Through her painting, Barbara stays connected to her own country in the Northern Territory, even though she lives far away. She draws inspiration from the wildflowers that carpet the desert in spring. Tjala Arts, Amata community, 2019

title: Pink lightning
medium: reclaimed printer toner (ground polyester) and natural earth pigments with PVA binder
description: Yolŋu philosophy suggests, ‘If you paint the land you should use the land’. Industrial materials dumped on the land may now be re-used in depicting the land. This work includes magenta toner from smashed, discarded printer cartridges. This place is Baraltja, north of Cape Shield in the Gulf of Carpentaria. These are cyclonic, crocodile-infested waters with huge tides and ripping currents. Rocks are set in deep water between the electric ‘curse’ that the lighting snake spits into the sky and the sea spray from the ocean waves trying to shift the rocks’ immovable foundation. Noŋgirrŋa Marawili, 2019 This work was awarded the Roberts Family Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Prize 2019.

title: Lithgow, path to water
description: I live in Blackheath in the upper Blue Mountains but often go to Lithgow, a 30-minute drive west, to paint. There are more clouds and lakes in Lithgow, and this image – Lithgow, path to water – was painted en plein air with the sun on my back and flecks of paint splashing the grass. What I hope to capture, painting directly like this from the motif, isn’t just a picture of the experience but the experience itself. Robert Malherbe, 2019

title: Blue to eye's touch, Merlin's Lookout
description: I went on a painting trip to the gold-mining town of Hill End in New South Wales earlier this year and visited one of my favourite spots, Merlin’s Lookout. I was drawn into the eucalypts, submerging myself completely in flora. I love how, on a clear day, everything in this world is held against blue, which allows for all the warmer tones of the bush to shine. My painting is an attempt to give sense to the engulfing yet expansive nature of the landscape, as the eucalyptus trunks, the fallen leaves and the tufts of native grass become jewels of colour when suffused with light. Bronte Leighton-Dore, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Bronte Leighton-Dore_Blue to eye_s touch_ Merlin_s Lookout.jpg
image_stem: 2019_Bronte Leighton-Dore_Blue to eye_s touch_ Merlin_s Lookout

title: Seven Sisters
description: Tjungkara Ken is an important figure in contemporary Indigenous art from the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. She paints the Seven Sisters story. This story involves the sisters being chased across country by Wati Nyiru (a bad man). The elder sisters protect and teach the younger ones and keep them from falling for his tricks. Wati Nyiru can change shape into different rock formations and landmarks. These sites remain part of the landscape and are important Anangu ceremonial places. Tjungkara paints these sites. Tjunkara Ken says: ‘I hold my father’s story, I hold my mother’s story… [it] doesn’t come out of paper or out of a book. It’s coming out of the ground here.’ Tjala Arts, Amata community, 2019

title: Seven Sisters
description: Sylvia Ken is from the Amata community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. Her family are traditional owners for significant sites where the Seven Sisters story takes place. This painting refers to this story, the landscape that the story takes place in, as well as the characters in the story. ‘I listen to the old people’s stories and I think about these stories and then the ideas come for my paintings… I listen when they are talking about tjukurpa and telling creation stories, and when they say to me, “No, you should paint this way, the Seven Sisters”.’ Sylvia Ken, 2019

title: Piltati wanampi tjukurpa
description: Witjiti George is from the Fregon community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. He is a senior traditional elder. His mother’s country is Piltati and his father’s country is Coffin Hill, south of Kaltjiti. He says of this painting: ‘This painting refers to the story of Piltati, a story about two brothers and two sisters. The two brothers, two water snakes, are at Piltati rock hole waiting for the two sisters. The two women had gone to find food. They were gone a long time and the men were hungry. They all live there in this rock hole. This is a love story.’ Witjiti George, 2019

title: The view from my mum and dad's place
description: I am a self-taught painter from Gymea. My work usually revolves around popular culture, childhood memories and everyday domestic life, mostly with a darkly humorous twist. Lately I have been enjoying painting landscapes that inspire me. This painting is the view overlooking Gymea Bay from my parents’ balcony. It’s my favourite view in the world. Marc Etherington, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Marc Etherington_The view from my mum and dad_s place.jpg
image_stem: 2019_Marc Etherington_The view from my mum and dad_s place

title: Ashes, damper and kangaroo stew for dinner
description: Aunty Elaine’s style was the most influential on my development as a painter. Both her and Leonie Dennis’s works appealed to me because of their simplicity, naivety and colour. The most important element, however, are the key lines. Aunty Elaine was a fellow exhibiting artist at Boomalli Aboriginal Artists Co-op and a regular finalist in major awards. Knowing that, I became keen to acquire one of her works. Her son Troy suggested I might complete this, the last painting Elaine began before passing. Blak Douglas, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Blak Douglas_ Elaine Russell_Ashes_ damper and kangaroo stew for dinner.jpg
image_stem: 2019_Blak Douglas_ Elaine Russell_Ashes_ damper and kangaroo stew for dinner

title: Outback
description: Although most Australians cling to the edge of the country, the landscape of the outback, the Red Centre and Kakadu are firmly embraced by the Australian soul. This painting came from a recent camping trip in Kakadu. I was thrilled by the wonderful statuesque feel of the termite mounds and the scrubby landscape and grasses on which they stand. I hope this painting conveys something of that feeling and the heat of a hot summer’s day. Ken Done, 2019

title: Tjuntala ngurangka (country with acacia wattle)
description: My painting is about the tjuntala (acacia wattle) that grows in the country where I’m from, near Oodnadatta in South Australia. They have beautiful yellow flowers. When I was younger my parents taught me how to grind the flowers with sand and ashes, to make a paste to eat. It’s very sweet and delicious! Nellie Coulthard, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Nellie Coulthard_Tjuntala ngurangka _country with acacia wattle_.jpg

title: Australian warhead with rising tide of human rights abuses
medium: origami shirts folded from world currencies on cotton thread
description: Is Australia capable of manufacturing nuclear weapons? Australia is set to jump from 20th to 10th position in the global arms race through Malcom Turnbull’s Defence Export Strategy. Electro Optic Systems, an Australian-owned Canberra-based company, has received grants worth $3.7 million from the Federal Government for the delivery of state-of-the-art remote weapon systems to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. Australian Defence exports are currently worth about $2 billion per year. While our First Nations people are still second-class citizens, Australia’s treatment of refugees on Manus Island and Nauru is strategically aimed at gaining a fist-full of election votes. From 1920 to 2019, has the word ‘humanity’ lost its meaning? Glen Clarke, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Glen Clarke_Australian warhead with rising tide of human rights abuses.jpg
image_stem: 2019_Glen Clarke_Australian warhead with rising tide of human rights abuses

title: Magnolia trees
description: Toowoomba is not far from Brisbane, where I live. It is situated at the top of a mountain that is about 800 metres high. In September, it is covered in spring flowers. I love to be there in spring and paint the views. This is one of my Toowoomba spring paintings. Pink magnolia trees cover almost the whole canvas, while the blue sky makes a strong colour contrast. Painting the field and remote mountain with big marks, combined with the magnolia trees, makes the whole painting active and powerful. It also shows how prosperous, joyous and hopeful spring is. Jun Chen, 2019

title: Where I scattered my father's ashes, Oratunga, SA
description: After the scattering of my parents’ ashes in Sydney Harbour, I was given the wooden box which had contained those of my father. There were still some ashes left around its edges, and so I scraped them into an old film canister. My father and I had shared a love of outback landscapes and I decided to take his remnant ashes inland, far from the sea. I waited five years until I found this valley in the Flinders Ranges, at Oratunga. I scattered them there – a small grey cloud that drifted sideways and settled on the rocks and bushes. Tom Carment, 2019
image_path: data/images/2019_Tom Carment_Where I scattered my father_s ashes_ Oratunga_ SA.jpg
image_stem: 2019_Tom Carment_Where I scattered my father_s ashes_ Oratunga_ SA

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: Wawiriya Burton is a senior woman from the Amata community in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. In this painting, she tells the story of her father’s country near Pipalyatjara, west of Amata. It depicts minyma mingkiri tjuta (small female desert mice). The mingkiri are pregnant and give birth to many babies. They then journey to the surrounding rock holes in search of food and water for their young. The dotted lines are mingkiri tracks. ‘A long time ago, when we were little children, we ran around Puta Puta and Ilitjata, our grandfather’s and father’s ground, and because of this we grew up strong. Why? Because it’s Anangu country – Aboriginal people’s Country – of their spirit.’ Wawiriya Burton, 2019

title: Interlude
description: The journey by boat to Port Davey, on Tasmania’s south-west coast, is rugged and exposed. When I finally passed the Breaksea Islands and entered the bay, the calm water and mist-filled mountains induced a sense of relief. In the following days, travelling through the waterways, I was met with never-ending possibilities. It was the moments of pause, finding myself between one place and another, that was to later become the inspiration for this painting. To me, the organic, round shape of hand-beaten steel, bearing the marks of time and work, is a portal to a past experience. Michaye Boulter, 2019

title: Reflection
description: My artwork, Reflection , pairs intricate oil painting with a large gold-mirrored surface. Its sleek physical appearance embodies my interest in present-day image trends. As a culture, we are obsessed with recording and documenting our surroundings. Our phones have become an extension of ourselves and, as a result, we often experience our environment through screens. If we don’t truly absorb our surroundings, I wonder how this will impact on real experience. My painting explores my ongoing interest in the relationship between people and nature within an urban context. Natasha Bieniek, 2019 Highly commended in the Wynne Prize 2019

title: Mask (after Ned Kelly)
description: Canonised in the public imagination as a restive anti-hero, Ned Kelly embodies the enduring fiction of the embattled underdog. In the National Portrait Gallery, stripped of armour, life and beard, Kelly’s death mask lies in state – a disembodied, sallow description of the hangman’s grim task. Australia continues to polish its idols from a cast of rapacious and violent men. Lionising historical acts of brutality as the just consequences of perceived oppression gives implicit consent to those enacted today. Whether it’s at Don Dale Youth Detention Centre, Manus Island or right next door, the perpetrators of violence need to be revealed for what they are. Abdul-Rahman Abdullah, 2019

title: A terrible burden
description: The history of Australian landscape painting has been cloaked in the language of colonialism: frontiers, exploration and discovery – the language of ownership. The rhetoric regarding taming, conquering and capturing the Australian landscape reflects a desire to possess it. ‘Frontiers have always been broken’ is a quote from one self-identifying Australian landscape painter referring to the practice of another. The phrase written across the painting quotes the latter painter when asked to discuss his status as Australia’s greatest living artist. Like the settlers before them the moral obligation to claim the Australian landscape is the cross they feel the need to bear. Abdul Abdullah, 2019

title: Garak – night sky
description: Djulpan, the Seven Sisters, are one of the first creations. They left the ancestral elders Nyiwuṉba and Rranyirranyi at the islands called Djakapurra, Gurrarri, Nalkuma, Dhakalŋa, Bandayŋa, Ŋarrayarri and Wärru. They paddled until they arrived at Nanydjaka (Cape Arnhem). There they rested for some time to gather their strength, then set off again along the coast, passing the Gumatj lands near Manydjarrarrŋa (Daliwuy Bay). They travelled past the Dhuwa lands, Bariŋurawuy and Ŋumuwuy (Turtle Beach), and landed at Gärriri (the Yirritja side of the creek at Rocky Bay). They paddled up the beach called Dhuraka (Rocky Bay) and this is where the Djulpan ended their journey. Nyapanyapa Yunupiŋu, 2021

title: Tjala tjukurpa (honey ant story)
description: Yaritji Young is a traditional owner for tjala tjukurpa (honey ant story). She is from Amata in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia. She paints the rock holes and landmarks of her country, entwined with icons and traditional marks that relate to inma (dance) and tjukurpa. The twisted lines and shapes mimic tunnels and formations made by the tjala (honey ant). Yaritji Young says: ‘My paintings are of my country: my father’s country, my grandmother’s country, the tjala country. Everything that my grandmother taught me, I’m teaching to my grandchildren now. They dance because I have shared what I got from my grandmother with my granddaughters, so they can know their culture.’ Tjala Arts, Amata, 2021

title: Dove Lake dawn
description: In 2020, my wife and I were meant to travel to Tokyo to see our daughter graduate from university. COVID-19 began to shut the world down and the graduation ceremony was cancelled. At the last minute we headed to Tasmania instead, as domestic travel was still open. Within two days the state borders began to close. We drove through the wilderness, our anxiety building as the seismic shift to the world started unfolding. We made it to Cradle Mountain – a long-held dream. On a clear and calm morning, we found a refuge from the outside world in the ancient majesty of the mountain, reflected in Dove Lake. Graham Wilson, 2021

title: Untitled
description: This painting depicts designs associated with the rock hole and swamp site of Mamultjulkulnga, on the western side of Wilkinkarra (Lake Mackay in Western Australia). During ancestral times, a large group of Tingari men travelled south from Mamultjulkulnga to Marawa and, after arriving at the site, passed beneath the earth’s surface and travelled underground. It is also said that a huge ancestral snake sleeps in the swamp at Marawa. Warlimpirrnga Tjapaltjarri, 2021

title: The night road
description: This study in ultramarine, cobalt and cerulean is essentially an azure composition. It is tempered by alizarin crimson, Payne’s grey and burnt sienna, all tonally controlled with titanium white. (The headlights are cadmium yellow deep.) All the pigments are used variously as underpainting, impasto and glazing on linen canvas to try to convey simply the beauty of a night. Tim Storrier, 2021

title: Hat Hill Road
description: On the edge of a dramatic escarpment in the heart of Dharug Country, at a place known as Blackheath in NSW , grows a life-affirming forest of waratahs. These incredibly resilient native flowers grow high above the recently burned ground at the beautiful home of my friend, fashion designer Jenny Kee. For 15 or 16 years, I’ve sporadically visited her superb forest of trees that grow like lanterns in and against the Blue Mountains bush. In defiance of or perhaps due to the fierce fires that engulfed this fragile ecosystem in 2020, these triumphant beauties rise phoenix-like from the seemingly barren sandstone and give great heart not only to the human inhabitants, but also the bird and insect life in need of a good feed of nectar. Luke Sciberras, 2021

artist: Betty Kuntiwa Pumani, Marina Pumani Brown
title: Antara
description: This work is a collaboration between Betty Kuntiwa Pumani and her daughter Marina Pumani Brown. Interweaving their distinctive styles, the two women create a conversation on the canvas, retelling the storyline of Antara, a site cared for by their ancestors since time immemorial. ‘I am glad to be able to pass this story down to the younger generation, showing them everything that needs to be known. Painting this work with my daughter Marina made me proud of everything she has learned from us old people.’ Betty Kuntiwa Pumani, 2021
image_path: data/images/2021_Betty Kuntiwa Pumani_ Marina Pumani Brown_Antara.jpg

title: Spun idol
medium: machined polystyrene, polyurethane and automotive paint
description: Spun idol is inspired by Renato Bertelli’s 1933 ceramic bust of the Italian dictator Benito Mussolini, Continuous profile (Head of Mussolini) Profilo continuo (Testa di Mussolini) . It stands as a pop cultural sentinel, omnipresent and ever watching. Like the monuments to devotion unearthed from ages past, I imagine it to be a speculative future historical relic to be discovered, or a monolith yet to be erected; an absurdist monument that is a testament to our time. Philjames, 2021

title: East MacDonnell Ranges
description: This image depicts a section of the East MacDonnell Ranges – a complex geological area in the Northern Territory, significant to Eastern Arrernte people. The ancestral wallaby trail is just beyond these hills. I was drawn to the strata of rock that traverse the peaks and ridges, undulating in elegant movements and fascinating patterns. It is a dry area, but its evocative colour, dynamic shapes and rugged lyricism make it lush to the painter’s eye. This particular location was close to our lodgings. The intriguing interplay between the slopes exudes many different moods in the course of a day, but none more dramatic than late afternoon, when a haze seems to fuse the distant hills. Daniel Pata, 2021

title: Gum trunk with banksias
description: This painting was based on a drawing I made while on a visit to an upland swamp in the Blue Mountains in NSW with a group of artists and scientists. It is called the Leura swamp. The trip was part of The Painted River Project, a participatory art and science project devised by Leo Robba from Western Sydney University. It seeks to better value our water and river systems and how we care for them. We spent a couple of days drawing, painting and photographing the swamp and its creatures. The gum trunk and the surrounding trees and banksias in the picture had been burnt in a recent bushfire. Reg Mombassa, 2021
image_path: data/images/2021_Chris O_Doherty _aka Reg Mombassa__Gum trunk with banksias.jpg
image_stem: 2021_Chris O_Doherty _aka Reg Mombassa__Gum trunk with banksias

title: Untitled
description: This painting depicts designs associated with Yunala, a rock hole and soakage-water site situated among sandhills to the west of Kiwirrkurra in Western Australia. During mythological times, a group of ancestral women camped here after travelling from the west, and while here they dug for the edible roots of the bush banana or silky pear vine ( Marsdenia australis ), also known as yunala. The women later continued their travels to the east, passing through the Kiwirrkurra area on their way to Wilkinkarra (Lake Mackay in Western Australia). The lines in this painting represent both the sandhills and the yunala. Yukultji Napangati, 2021

title: Ngalyod (Rainbow Serpent)
medium: earth pigments and PVA fixative on bark (Eucalyptus tetradonta)
description: Kenan Namunjdja has depicted Ngalyod (the Rainbow Serpent), which is one facet of the marladj djang (orphan dreaming). At a place called Kabbari, two brothers had no parents. One day, the older brother decided to go hunting for goannas, leaving his younger brother alone. The family tried to hush the younger brother by feeding him sweet damper but once he’d finished the portion he started crying again. The little boy’s cries aroused the attention of Ngalyod who became angry at the family’s neglect, turning them into stone. Maningrida Arts on behalf of Kenan Namunjdja, 2021

title: Wandawuy
description: The grid refers to the landscape of Waṉḏawuy – a network of billabongs surrounded by ridges and high banks. And also an ancient woven fish trap, which briefly impeded the shark spirit here. Yolŋu throw short hollow logs into the river, which act as traps for yabbies. Groups of kids and adults trawl the river catching dhakawa (freshwater crayfish) with their hands and throw them onto the bank where they fill up multiple flour tins. The effect of a tight-packed, laughing, screaming, splashing unit moving through the environment is like a massive powerful beast, which scares the crocodiles away. Pigeons and file snakes watch on. Dhambit Munuŋgurr, 2021

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: I have and hold the old people’s tjukurpa (ancestral stories). The old people’s important stories of long ago. I’ve painted my country and all the different types of trees there. That’s the story in my paintings. The paintings have our culture in them. Our culture is in our trees. Our fathers would use these trees to make spears and other hunting tools. I would sit and watch and see, ‘Oh, that’s how my father makes a spear’. That’s what our culture was. We were learning. I was learning from all my elders – the senior men. So now I know everything. Peter Mungkuri, 2021

title: Ngangkari ngura (healing country)
description: We two ngangkari (Aṉangu traditional healers) painted this together. Our painting comes from our shared experience of working together as ngangkari. Each of us has painted the country where we were born and belong. These places are an essential part of each of us. I paint Anamara Piti, the caterpillar tjukurpa site near Wingelina. Betty has painted her country, Yalungu, south of Wataru. Maringka Burton, 2021 Our collaborative painting is about healing the sick, our work as ngangkari and the ways the two of us work together as ngangkari. We two women are healers, we have the hands to heal. Betty Muffler, 2021
image_path: data/images/2021_Betty Muffler_ Maringka Burton_Ngangkari ngura _healing country_.jpg

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: Barbara Mbitjana Moore grew up in Amoonguna and her father’s country near Ti-Tree in the Northern Territory, moving to Amata in Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia when she married. In this painting, she has depicted her country near Ti-Tree. The different colours and shapes represent variations in the landscape. Some of the landmarks are the rock holes that lie in and around her country. Connected by travel lines, these sites hold important tjukurpa. Through her painting, Barbara stays connected to her own country in the Northern Territory, even though she lives far away. She draws inspiration from the wildflowers that carpet the desert in spring. Tjala Arts, Amata, 2021

title: Bol’ŋu
medium: earth pigments and recycled print toner on composite board
description: As Bol’ŋu (Thunderman) travelled through the country, the Dhuwa clouds and the rain followed him. Rivers and creeks and springs with freshwater for the dry season formed. And he said to himself, ‘May it always be this way’. All the Dhuwa clans that sing Bol’ŋu each have a special piece of rainforest dedicated to Bol’ŋu. From each of these rainforests, small clouds rise from each territory. He has brought them all together in one. They are the spear he holds which curves above his head. He is the wet season. Here he is at Djapu clan country at Boruwuy. Noŋgirrŋa Marawili, 2021

title: Govetts Leap
description: I live in Blackheath, NSW , traditional land of the Dharug and Gundungurra people, not far from the Govetts Leap lookout with its views of the rugged Grose Valley. I’ve painted this view many times in the 20 years that I’ve lived here. I never tire of its rhythms, shifting colours and vast space. This work, like all my landscapes, was painted in the open air, in situ. In 1836, English naturalist Charles Darwin travelled from Bathurst for two days on horseback just to look at this view, which he described as ‘most remarkable’. Today the drive from Sydney to Blackheath will take you less than two hours. Robert Malherbe, 2021

title: The flood
description: This is a memory painting. Becoming a parent has made me reflect on my own childhood, and also consider the world we will leave to our kids. For a child growing up near a river, a flood is one of those markers in time. Your childhood timeline is punctuated with memories of these exciting and awe-inspiring spectacles. Floods were a natural cyclical event. Unfortunately, floods now seem more about climate change than spectacle, and I am forced to think about how these current and future ‘weather events’ will punctuate my own child’s memories, and the weather we will bequeath to our kids. Guy Maestri, 2021

title: Adventure and folly (ii)
medium: acrylic, oil and automotive enamel on linen
description: In 2019, I made a large triptych about the Australian explorers Burke and Wills. This opened up a new territory for me. Adventure and folly (ii) references time spent in the powerful Kimberley region, but it is an invented landscape. For me, landscape painting is more about what is going on inside me. Adventure and folly (ii) follows Australia’s ever-hotter summers and increasingly frequent, devastating fires. However, the black represents any unforeseen negative force, be it COVID-19 or any event that devastates one’s personal landscape. In 1983, when I was five, our family house burnt down in the Ash Wednesday bushfires, just two weeks after we moved in. Importantly, fire creates regeneration and opportunities for growth and change. William Mackinnon, 2021

title: South Coast headland (2), Ottoman rose
description: This painting is based on an old photograph I took many years ago. I’m not sure of the location, but it could be around Newcastle, just north of Sydney. That said, it could be many places where the sea meets the land. The placement of the lone tree near the edge creates a kind of apprehension when viewing the picture. Ottoman rose, mentioned in the title, is the name of the beautiful wash I put down on the paper. It is also connected to my interest in the history and culture of the Middle East, from Egypt through Turkey to Iran. Noel McKenna, 2021
image_path: data/images/2021_Noel McKenna_South Coast headland _2__ Ottoman rose.jpg

title: A lightness of touch, a being with and feeling into space
description: I recently went on a painting trip to Mangrove Mountain on the NSW Central Coast. The property I visited backs onto a national park. Each morning I would take my paper and paints into the bush, where I would wander between the eucalypts and banksias and study the light to choose the ideal landscape to paint. I believe we have to be quiet within ourselves to really see. This painting was a gentle meditation between myself and the subject, feeling into the space of the paper, absorbing the visual cues in front of me and the sensations of being in the landscape. Bronte Leighton-Dore, 2021
image_path: data/images/2021_Bronte Leighton-Dore_A lightness of touch_ a being with and feeling into space.jpg
image_stem: 2021_Bronte Leighton-Dore_A lightness of touch_ a being with and feeling into space

title: Seven Sisters
description: Tjungkara Ken is an important figure in contemporary Indigenous art from the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) lands in South Australia. She paints the Seven Sisters story. This story involves the sisters being chased across country by Wati Nyiru (a bad man). The elder sisters protect and teach the younger ones and keep them from falling for his tricks. Wati Nyiru can change shape into different rock formations and landmarks. These sites remain part of the landscape and are important Aṉangu ceremonial places. Tjungkara Ken says: ‘I hold my father’s story, I hold my mother’s story … [it] doesn’t come out of paper or out of a book. It’s coming out of the ground here.’ Tjala Arts, Amata, 2021 This work was awarded the Roberts Family Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Prize 2021.

title: Seven Sisters
description: Sylvia Ken is from Amata in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia. Her family are traditional owners for significant sites where the Seven Sisters story takes place. This painting refers to this story, the landscape that the story takes place in, as well as the characters in the story. Sylvia Ken says: ‘I listen to the old people’s stories and I think about these stories and then the ideas come for my paintings … I listen when they are talking about tjukurpa and telling creation stories, and when they say to me, “No, you should paint this way, the Seven Sisters”.’ Tjala Arts, Amata, 2021

artist: Naomi Kantjuriny, Mona Mitakiki, Tjimpayi Presley
title: Seven Sisters
description: Naomi Kantjuriny, Mona Mitakiki and Tjimpayi Presley paint kapi tjukurla (rock holes) that relate to the Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa. This story involves the Seven Sisters being chased across country by Wati Nyiru (a bad man). The elder sisters protect and teach the younger ones and keep them from falling for his tricks. Wati Nyiru can change shape into different rock formations and landmarks. These sites remain part of the landscape and are important Aṉangu ceremonial places.
