These three artists were taught to paint by senior artist Kunmanara (Tjampawa) Katie Kawiny. She has passed away, but the younger women carry her story on for future generations. Tjala Arts, Amata, 2021
image_path: data/images/2021_Naomi Kantjuriny_ Mona Mitakiki_ Tjimpayi Presley_Seven Sisters.jpg
image_stem: 2021_Naomi Kantjuriny_ Mona Mitakiki_ Tjimpayi Presley_Seven Sisters

title: Bushfire ephemerals – Wollangambe wilderness
description: Early this year, I heard rumours that fields of tiny pink flannel flowers were popping up all over the Blue Mountains, just west of my hometown of Kurrajong, NSW . Actinotus forsythii are described as bushfire ephemerals, and this event was a once-in-a-lifetime mass synchronicity of flowering. Their seeds have lain dormant for years, requiring a rare confluence of events to trigger germination – smoke from the catastrophic 2020 bushfires and the heavy rain of last summer. No-one had seen them grow on this scale since the 1950s – they blanketed the ridges and completely altered the feel of the landscape. Swallowing up blackened tree trunks and burnt banksia remains, they were a bittersweet reminder of the firestorm that preceded them. Laura Jones, 2021

title: Kapi tjukula
description: Yaritji Heffernan was born in 1955 at Mulga Park Station near Pukutja in the far north-west of South Australia. Her parents were both Pitjantjatjara; her father was from Angkatja and her mother was from Umutju. She moved to Adelaide in 2010. The circles of this design represent rock holes, where water collects after the rains. These rock holes were an important source of water during the dry season when most of the waterholes and creeks dried up. Water is an essential element in the desert. Knowledge of rock hole sites is passed on from generation to generation and revered by all Pitjantjatjara Aṉangu (people). APY Gallery, Adelaide, 2021

title: Escarpment forest
description: In this painting, I wanted to capture the native angophora trees on the Wodi Wodi walking track near Stanwell Park. The track is named after the original custodians of the land in the Illawarra in NSW and can be found on an escarpment containing the most extensive area of rainforest in the Sydney basin. The area acts as an important refuge for species that are affected by environmental disturbances such as development and bushfires. The 500-metre-high escarpment provides a dramatic backdrop to my local town of Thirroul and spans 200 million years of geological history. Ashley Frost, 2021

title: Tree spirit
description: Tree spirit was inspired by the devastating 2020 bushfires. The charred native banksia tree branches, sourced from a farm in Bilpin in the Blue Mountains, NSW , are a connection to the unprecedented, horrific fires. The haunting, ghostly branches create a striking form visually. A shadow and silhouette of their previous life, the branches are interwoven with charred, repurposed wooden sticks, twisted, turned and interlocking. Tree spirit embodies a juxtaposition: a dance between Mother Nature’s powerful force and the fragility of humanity. Tracey Deep, 2021

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: My painting is about the country that is my home, Indulkana, in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in the remote north-west of South Australia. I feel truly connected to the place I’m painting and it’s incredibly important to me. My painting includes specific sites, like the Iwantja karu (creek), tjukitji (soakage) and tjurki tjukurpa (native owl ancestral story). I use my colours and marks to reflect the way the landscape changes from the rocky ridge to the sandy creek beds. As I paint, I am thinking about stories and my memories of the different places. This country is beautiful and it is special. Betty Chimney, 2021

title: Dried bush
description: Charleville is situated in central Queensland. I travelled there recently to do some landscape painting. The orange field and hot weather caused the colour of the trees to look quite different to the trees on the east coastline. It is hard to describe it in words. Sometimes they looked brown and sometimes almost grey-purple. I did lots of small paintings while travelling around Charleville. Back in my studio, I painted this landscape, basing it on those small paintings. I named it Dried bush as that is how it felt to me when I was there. Jun Chen, 2021

title: Moonrise, Koroop
description: Koroop lies about 12 kilometres south of the Murray River in Victoria, and consists of just a white-painted community hall above a creek. The nearest house was occupied by my friends Wayde and Michelle. They had come to help their daughter run a buffalo dairy farm; to mix silage and look after grandchildren. One evening I watched a big full moon come up over their house and made some drawings. A year later, back in Adelaide, I completed this painting. By then, my friends and their daughter had had to leave the farm. I sent them a postcard of my picture and they have it on their fridge in Parkes, NSW . Tom Carment, 2021

title: Korrmanguntja
description: Korrmanguntja directly translates to ‘thunder is happening there’ or ‘a place of thunder’. This place is very important for Katjarra. She was born at this very site, to the north of Tjukurla in Western Australia. She has the strongest connection to this place though Pintupi/Ngaanyatjarra customs. At Korrmanguntja, when Katjarra’s mother was pregnant with her, a python (Kuniya) appeared in front of her. Katjarra’s mother killed the snake, and Kuniya became Katjarra’s totem. Katjarra’s mother believed that that very python was symbolic of the tjukurrpa python from this area. Kuniya, the creation python, travelled to Korrmanguntja, where the thunder instructed Kuniya to continue onwards to Patjantja, but with a warning. Winston Green, grandson of Katjarra Butler, 2021 This work is now in the collection of the Art Gallery of New South Wales.

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: Kunmanara (Wawiriya) Burton was a senior woman from Amata in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia. In this painting, she tells the story of her father’s country near Pipalyatjara, west of Amata. It depicts minyma mingkiri tjuta (small female desert mice). The mingkiri are pregnant and give birth to many babies. They then journey to the surrounding rock holes in search of food and water for their young. The dotted lines are mingkiri tracks. Kunmanara (Wawiriya) Burton said: ‘A long time ago, when we were little children, we ran around Puta Puta and Ilitjata, our grandfather’s and father’s ground, and because of this we grew up strong. Why? Because it’s Aṉangu country – Aboriginal people’s Country – of their spirit.’ Tjala Arts, Amata 2021

title: Ngayuku ngura (my country)
description: Nyunmiti Burton was born in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1960 and raised in Pukatja on the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia. In 1980 she moved to Amata and trained to become a teacher. She is the vice chairperson of Ngaanyatjarra Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( NPY ) Women’s Council, and holds senior positions within her community. This painting is Seven Sisters tjukurpa. The sisters make up the constellation of Pleiades, and the constellation Orion is said to be the man Nyiru or Nyirunya. Nyunmiti Burton says: ‘I heard these stories from my father, mother and grandfathers. I think about the future of the country for the next generation.’ APY Gallery, Adelaide, 2021

title: Arid garden, Wollongong
medium: watercolour, gouache and monotype on paper
description: My recent work examines the garden as a site that attempts to recreate and curate the natural world. Through gardens, I explore how we experience and consume the spectacle of nature more broadly within contemporary culture during an era of increasing environmental uncertainty. This work was made after time spent at the Wollongong Botanic Garden while I was an artist in residence at Hazelhurst Regional Gallery. Under a blazing sun, despite the drought, the arid climate plants were flourishing. In these ecologically precarious times, botanical tenacity gives me hope. Leah Bullen, 2021

title: Piltati tjukurpa
description: Leah Brady was born in 1962 in Pukatja, a community in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia. She comes from a line of important regional leaders. Her mother was a founding director of the Ngaanyatjarra Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( NPY ) Women’s Council, and her family has been involved in cultural tourism initiatives for the APY Lands. Piltati is the well-known tjukurpa of two snake brothers and their wives, who are sisters, who lived near Piltati, west of Amata. APY Gallery, Adelaide, 2021

title: Into the glade
description: Nestled in a deep enclave, this is an imagined scene, drawn from memories and sensations inspired by various places. I wanted to evoke the spaciousness of the Australian bush, and the feeling of excitement at stumbling upon such a sparkling glade. I hope the painting conveys a sense of expansiveness and the interconnectedness of everything. I see the interconnections between people reflected in nature – our flaws, like the disfigured joints of the trees, are grafted together in an embrace of damage, renewal and deep hope. Nicola Bartos, 2021

title: Thesaurium insula (treasured island)
medium: pencil, watercolour, charcoal, chalk pastel and acrylic on 12 boards
description: Climate change and COVID-19 have made us, as a nation, look more closely at our country, and really treasure it. My painting is a visual story; a map of Australia’s flora and fauna. The Red Centre is shown with the flower of the boab tree and the red Gymea lily. The koalas turn their backs and gaze over dancing brolgas. For the east coast there are kookaburras and frogs, and a platypus for Tasmania. Zebra seahorses and coral represent the west coast. There are billabongs and kingfishers, while coloured cockatoos soar above, squawking news of the bush to all who will listen, even the crocodile. Julianne Ross Allcorn, 2021

title: Eagle spirit, Vathiwarta
description: Since 2016, my wife Anne and I have stayed regularly at the Oratunga homestead in the northern Flinders Ranges, South Australia. We have climbed the rocky ridge behind the homestead, and sat and stared at the beauty, the wonder. At the centre of this vast space is the distinctive, sharply rising rock massif, Patawarta Hill. During our most recent stay we got to know a local Adnyamathanha artist, Kristian Coulthard. After I finished my painting I couldn’t think of the right title, so I asked Kristian. He explained that the story of Patawarta (or Vathiwarta) is connected to the sacred eagle, Wildu. And so, the title became Eagle spirit, Vathiwarta . John R Walker, 2022

title: Nganampa Ngura (Our Country)
description: Jeannie Minunga and Kay Finn are sisters-in-law and live in far north South Australia. Myra Kumantjara is Minunga’s daughter and is based at Umoona community. They began painting together as the Umoona Senior Women’s Collaborative at Umoona Art Centre in Coober Pedy in 2021. This is their first collaborative work. The women depict important cultural sites and stories of their Pitjantjatjara and Yankunytjatjara Country. Minunga paints Wanampi Tjukurpa (water serpent) near Paradise; Finn paints the kapi tjukula (waterholes) around Oodnadatta, and Kumantjara depicts Kalpi, a women’s site near Mimili. APY Art Centre Collective, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Umoona Senior Women_s Collaborative_Nganampa Ngura _Our Country_.jpg

title: Piltati Tjukurpa
description: ‘I think of my wonderful Grandma when I paint. Her name was Eileen Stevens. She was an incredible artist and a powerful woman. She taught me my culture.’ Rhoda Tjitayi, 2022 Rhoda Tjitayi was born in 1969 in Pukatja (formerly Ernabella), Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands in South Australia. Her grandfather was from Nyapari and her grandmother from Makiri, Tjala Minyma Ngura (Honeyant Women’s sacred place). She is now based in Adelaide and began working at the APY Adelaide Studio in 2019. Her works depict Piltati Tjukurpa, her grandmother’s ancestral creation story. APY Art Centre Collective, 2022

title: Untitled
description: This painting depicts designs associated with Yunala, a creek and rockhole site west of Kiwirrkurra in Western Australia. Edible tubers of the silky pear vine, also known as yunala, grow along the creek, and the lines in this painting represent the roots of the plant. In ancestral time, a large group of Tingari women camped here to dig the tubers before travelling northwest to Wilkinkarra (Lake Mackay). Tjapaltjarri, 2022

title: LAKE MUNGO, 6:10AM
description: Understanding LAKE MUNGO , 6:10AM is understanding Lake Mungo itself – seemingly rough but soft and fragile; ever-changing in its multiplicity; apparently static yet so mobile. The strips of shredded classified documents on the painting’s surface symbolise the constant shifts and transformations that occur on the dry lakebed. They also serve as a metaphor, exploring the need for circular-economy practices. The recycling of the strips, painted in blue, echoes the land’s renewal. Above all, this work is a contemplation of the blue haze that fills the early morning at Lake Mungo. It is so superbly terrifying in its beauty that the right hemisphere of the brain shuts down. And then the horizon vanishes. Christophe Stibio, 2022

title: Wati Tjakura
description: I am a Pitjantjatjara woman from Pipalyatjara in the far west of the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands. In this work, I am painting Aralya, the ancestral home for my family. My painting practice combines elements of the artistic styles of my two grandmothers, Kuntjiriya Mick and Kunmanara (Wawiriya) Burton, and my mother, Josephine Mick. The painting depicts the Tjukurpa (creation story) of Wati Tjakura, an edible skink lizard. The Wal Mala (army) of Wati Wanambi (snake men) from Malara came and threw spears at Wati Tjakura. He tried to escape but they killed him. His family came to grieve and bury him. Sally Scales, 2022 This work was awarded the Roberts Family Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Prize 2022.

title: Tjukula tjuta
description: When I paint, my mind travels back to my Country. I had to move to Adelaide for medical treatment many years ago. So now when I paint, I am right on my Country in the western Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, near Pipalyatjara in South Australia, where I was born. I am not able to be there to look after this Country anymore, but through my painting I depict the many tjukula (rockholes) and celebrate the Tjukurpa (spirituality and traditional law of Aṉangu culture) of the Country and keep it alive, so my painting is caring for Country too. Margaret Richards, 2022

title: Framed by life offshore
description: Welcome to Scotland Island: a short boat ride, casual paddle or vigorous swim from Church Point Wharf on Garigal Country, NSW . We offshore dwellers blow in and out with the tides, basking like seals when the sun shines and washing up like drowning rats when the squalls hit. This place and its people – a quirky and multifarious community – warm my soul and flood my creative practice with colour and movement. This artwork is a collection of moments captured around the island and its surrounding bays from friends’ and neighbours’ houses. It is an ode to the place I call home. Gemma Rasdall, 2022

title: The white fig (Ficus virens), Royal Botanic Garden, Sydney
description: I have been drawing the fig trees of Sydney for the last 18 months. They are everywhere, silently lending an important sense of place, especially to the older parts of the city. Also known as ‘strangler figs’, they can germinate in other trees and eventually overwhelm them. This is not so much a landscape as a portrait of the white fig ( Ficus virens ) located towards the northern end of the Royal Botanic Garden. Hard to miss due to the astonishing span and girth of its branches, it radiates a presence that seems inadequately conveyed by the word ‘tree’. Jude Rae, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Jude Rae_The white fig _Ficus virens__ Royal Botanic Garden_ Sydney.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Jude Rae_The white fig _Ficus virens__ Royal Botanic Garden_ Sydney

title: Winga (tidal movement/waves)
medium: natural ochres with acrylic on linen
description: This work depicts the tidal movement of waters in and around the seas and creeks of the Tiwi Islands. Not just influencing fishing and hunting opportunities, the movement of water carries masses of silt and sand, transforming the land and changing the coastal landscape. Winga can also be translated as ‘waves’, just one part of the changing tides. Tidal surges are at their most powerful when a king tide occurs during the wet season, especially during a full moon. Alison Puruntatameri has a strong bond to the waters surrounding the Tiwi Islands, forged by a lifetime of memories living encircled within the tides of the Arafura Sea. Munupi Arts and Crafts, 2022

artist: Gordon Pupangamirri, David Tipuamantumirri, Barry Kantilla, Graham Tipungwuti
title: First death on the Tiwi Islands
medium: ironwood, natural ochres and cockatoo feathers
description: This story goes back to Creation times. The group of four figure carvings tells the story of Purukupali, a great hunter and warrior, his wife Wa-ai, their son Jinani, and Purukupali’s brother Tapara, the Moon man. Purukupali was off hunting and Wa-ai was approached by Tapara, as he wanted her. Her baby was placed on the ground but the sun moved and Jinani died. Tapara wanted to bring the baby back to life, but Purukupali refused, declaring that now all people must die. At night the eerie wailing of Wa-ai, as a curlew, can be heard. Jennifer Isaacs for Ngaruwanajirri Inc, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Gordon Pupangamirri_ David Tipuamantumirri_ Barry Kantilla_ Graham Tipungwuti_First death on the Tiwi Islands.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Gordon Pupangamirri_ David Tipuamantumirri_ Barry Kantilla_ Graham Tipungwuti_First death on the Tiwi Islands

title: Crowdy Head (after Peter Powditch)
description: Crowdy Head on the NSW Mid North Coast holds a special place for us Powditchs. Dad grew up in nearby Taree and spent summers at Crowdy, a tiny fishing village, harbour and headland with two sweeping beaches on either side. As kids we spent January there, existing on a diet of prawns from the fish co-op and waiting for the perfect king tide that made the rockpool dangerous but not too dangerous. I’ve got a little painting Dad did of Crowdy in 1969 hanging above the couch, which I look at every day and think of him. Its simplicity and curve were the starting point for this work. James Powditch, 2022

title: Home
description: This painting is of a site at Telegraph Station in Mparntwe/Alice Springs, Northern Territory. It takes the Western figurative landscape tradition and imbues it with the personal and spiritual associations of Country. The place has a complex history and is the nexus for my own lifelong journey, deepening my connection with my culture. This body of work came about during lockdown. Being unable to travel there, I felt a longing for Country. This current series started during the bushfires and has continued through the floods. I think it was a way of processing my fears and grief. Country is our home – we must protect it. Thea Anamara Perkins, 2022

title: Beacon
medium: acrylic, gesso and carbon on polyester
description: During the drought of 2019–20, my nephew Jock, who runs the property ‘Yalgoo’ in Walcha, NSW , was not only making decisions on which livestock to keep and feed, but also those he had to let go. Such decisions never come without consequences. This, coupled with long periods spent alone, feeding the stock and watching the topsoil blow away – along with hope – found him deep in melancholia. He told me the thing that got him through this desperate time (besides family and love) was this beaten-up, struggling tree, which was visible from all parts of the property. It became his beacon. Angus Nivison, 2022

title: Untitled
description: This painting draws on designs associated with the site of Marrapinti, west of Kiwirrkurra, a rockhole amid the endless dunes of the Gibson Desert in Western Australia. Here a large group of ancestral women camped and made nose bones, also called marrapinti, before continuing their travels to the east, through Walla Walla, Kiwirrkurra and Ngaminya. On their journey they gathered the edible berries known as kampurarrpa, or desert raisin, to sustain themselves. Yukultji Napangati, 2022

title: Ŋathi and the Ḏawu – Muŋgurrawuy fights the bulldozer
description: My Ŋathi (mother’s father) Muŋgurrawuy led the fight against the Nabalco mining company stealing our land on the Gove Peninsula in the 1970s. He took them to the Supreme Court and helped make the Bark Petition. But when they sent the bulldozers to destroy the sacred Tree of Knowledge, he had had enough. He painted himself with gapan (white clay) and stood with an axe in front of the bulldozers. The only way they could kill the tree was to first run him over. He showed no fear. His courage was rewarded, and that tree is still alive inside the massive processing plant. Dhambit Munuŋgurr, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Dhambit Munuŋgurr_Ŋathi and the Ḏawu _ Muŋgurrawuy fights the bulldozer.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Dhambit Munuŋgurr_Ŋathi and the Ḏawu _ Muŋgurrawuy fights the bulldozer

title: Ngangkari Ngura (Healing Country)
medium: pigmented ink and acrylic on linen
description: This is my Country, Yalungu, south of Watarru in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia. It is a place where the emus drink at the waterhole. The emus made this shelter at Yalungu, which I love to paint, and the tracks the emus make as they travel. There is a rock shelter above, and below this there is good ground for the emus. My paintings are about ngangkari (traditional healing practices) and sites related to healing. I’ve painted rockholes and the water flowing through the landscape, just like the energy that flows through people and places – it’s invisible to most people but ngangkari can see spirits and feel a lot of different energy. Betty Muffler, 2022

title: The acquired Arcadia
medium: acrylic on board with gesso and iridescent wash
description: Towering jungle surrounds a confidently posing figure and at first seems a picturesque rainforest paradise. It is illusory, however. Based on a historic photograph, this painting reflects upon the complex histories of colonised landscapes from where my Aboriginal family comes. Beneath a giant fern tree stands Walter Roth, Chief Protector of Aboriginals in northern Queensland, who exempted my great-great-grandmother from the Aboriginals Protection Act of 1897 and whose decisions affected generations of lives to come. The land in this scene is transfigured through colonial presence and revisions of power. Nature is claimed and possessed, its holistic beauty yet to be fragmented and scarred. Danie Mellor, 2022

title: 3 Queenslanders
description: 3 Queenslanders portrays three traditional timber houses in tropical northern Australia – a form of vernacular domestic architecture. Built with a fairly standardised timber frame, they are usually lined with timber slats known as chamfer boards. They stand on timber or cement stumps, creating an area under the house which can take advantage of afternoon breezes. I have painted these houses numerous times. I grew up in one, so I do have a nostalgic feel for them. However, on a few occasions, when standing in front of one of my paintings, people have commented that I have made the stumps too high. Noel McKenna, 2022

title: Machine-assisted memory of Harewood Farm, Meadows
description: Harewood is a farm in the Adelaide Hills that was formerly owned by geologist and Antarctic explorer Douglas Mawson. My grandparents and then my aunt managed it for many years, and I spent a large part of my childhood there. I trained an artificial intelligence model by inputting a series of images of my own previous paintings and photos of the farm and the area. The computer learned how to produce new images that resembled the place. I sorted through thousands of proposed compositions until I found one that closely re-created the look and feel of the place as I remember it and developed this painting from it. Sam Leach, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Sam Leach_Machine-assisted memory of Harewood Farm_ Meadows.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Sam Leach_Machine-assisted memory of Harewood Farm_ Meadows

title: An unwavering truth. She walks in beauty, of the night and all that’s best of dark and bright. In memory of the wildfires
medium: porcelain, timber, resin, marine ply, polyurethane and enamel
description: This work reflects on the opposing themes of vulnerability and strength, and an undeniable tension after raging wildfires devastated the south coast of Australia and the landscape around my home and studio. It captures the beauty of the dark trees vitrified by fire, despite the charred remains that lay like ruins. It is this form that rises with vigour and reminds us all of the sheer forceful resilience of nature. A sense of intimacy and vastness is captured as the porcelain elements fold along the body, appearing to bristle as if in fight or flight, prompting the audience to acknowledge the entanglements between humans and nature. Juz Kitson, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Juz Kitson_An unwavering truth_ She walks in beauty_ of the night and all that_s best of dark and bright_ In memory.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Juz Kitson_An unwavering truth_ She walks in beauty_ of the night and all that_s best of dark and bright_ In memory

title: One whitefella, one blackfella swimming, all them animals frightened to drink the water, that’s true!
description: Billy Tjampitjinpa Kenda started painting at Bindi Mwerre Anthurre Artists, Mparntwe/Alice Springs, Northern Territory in 2004. He primarily paints his mother’s Country, Jay Creek, in the Tjoritja/West MacDonnell Ranges. Drawing inspiration from the increasing population and traffic within the Central Desert region, his textured landscapes of rock formations and flora are interspersed with trucks, cars, aeroplanes, helicopters and people. Animals look on from a rock or from the shade of a tree, functioning as observers and survivors of this changing place. From remote communities to town camps, Kenda paints all things unique to Central Australia with style, playfulness and strong connection to Country. Bindi Mwerre Anthurre Artists, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Billy Tjampitjinpa Kenda_One whitefella_ one blackfella swimming_ all them animals frightened to drink the water_ t.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Billy Tjampitjinpa Kenda_One whitefella_ one blackfella swimming_ all them animals frightened to drink the water_ t

title: Namatjira family picnic at Impurtna
description: This is all the Namatjira family out for picnic, other side from Albert Namatjira’s house at Impurtna (Goat Camp), Northern Territory. They go fishing in the Finke River, kids went swimming. Robina, Albert’s wife, would always make really good damper – she is on the lid, cooking damper with her daughter and granddaughter Gillian Namatjira. Gillian was my good friend. Albert is making a painting, the kids are looking around and watching grandfather doing the painting. They been taking a lot of dogs with them too, for company. They are digging for minna yalka (bush-onion) and boiling water for cup of tea. Judith Pungarta Inkamala, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Judith Pungarta Inkamala_Namatjira family picnic at Impurtna.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Judith Pungarta Inkamala_Namatjira family picnic at Impurtna

title: Lismore flood 2022
medium: watercolour pigment with acrylic binder on canvas
description: I painted this image of the recent floods to help me come to terms with what had just happened to Lismore. My own house was washed away in the surging floodwaters and completely destroyed. Fortunately, no one was hurt as it was vacant at the time. Doing this painting has been a cathartic experience. My heart goes out to all the thousands of people affected by these unprecedented floods throughout Australia, and the hardship they are enduring because of this global warming disaster. Geoff Harvey, 2022

title: Eora
description: ‘Eora’ was the word used by Aboriginal people of Sydney to describe where they came from when asked by the British invaders what the place of first settlement was called. My favoured pandanus trees are harbingers for the cabbage palms, while the ferns are influenced by our courtyard ferns that were shadowed by a neighbour’s eucalypt but perished when exposed to the sun’s heat after the tree was removed. Leafless fern trunks haunt Eora as warnings for the consequences of land-clearing. The locations observed for this landscape are now small, dwindling pockets amongst suburban developments. The dragonflies, which are not easy to find, are symbols of change, transformation, adaptability and self-realisation. Nicholas Harding, 2022

title: Bittersweet
description: I regularly head out of town to immerse myself in nature and seek solace in it. I’ve often reflected on what it means to represent landscape through art, and have concluded that being in nature bears little resemblance to seeing a painting of the same scene on a gallery wall. The two experiences are entirely dissimilar, yet, absurdly, are about the same thing. I spilled paint onto the landscape, then repainted the result to illustrate this dissonance. Its analogous to the way we treat nature as if it’s something separate to us, when really we are products of natural processes. We can’t continue to trash, mine and pillage it without harming ourselves. Juan Ford, 2022

title: Mooresprings, a good season
description: ‘Mooresprings’ is a lovely property in my locality of Bibbenluke in NSW . I was commissioned by her new owners to paint the farm a couple of years ago. We were going through a dry time. I only recently got around to making the painting. Fortunately, we have had good rain and the grass has grown great guns. A good season! Lucy Culliton, 2022

title: Untitled (landscape painting in the 21st century)
medium: Ngunnawal ochre, binder, acrylic polymer, charcoal and oil on linen
description: This small painting manifests thoughts on necessity and relevance; perspectives and privileges; and comprehending the difficult nuance between ownership and custodianship. It presents the landscape for what it is – a palimpsest. Our landscape is a site where histories collide in both material and immaterial ways, and the scars of these collisions can be seen and felt across our continent. Dean Cross, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Dean Cross_Untitled _landscape painting in the 21st century_.jpg

title: Tjuntala ngurangka (Country with acacia wattle)
description: I love painting the trees and flowers of the Country where I grew up – Yankunytjatjara Country near Oodnadatta, South Australia. After the rain and before the summer starts, the landscape here changes colour with lots of wattle blossoms. My favourites are the bushes of tjuntala (native Acacia murrayana ). The flowers are like little yellow pom-poms, they’re very pretty. The seeds are small and lined up in a row inside brown seed pods. I paint the trees and flowers and it reminds me of my childhood, travelling on Country with my family. Nellie Coulthard, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Nellie Coulthard_Tjuntala ngurangka _Country with acacia wattle_.jpg

title: Erraanta and elintja; Tnyam-iparta
description: This Country is west of Ntaria/Hermannsburg, Northern Territory, other side of Tnyam-iparta, which is a little outstation. This is Sandhill Country. We always travel here for family picnics. We go hunting and we look for bush tucker. We take all the kids with us and teach them about Country; how to find bush tucker and how to hunt and cook goanna. We always watch all the birds eating the bush foods – ilkurta (native melon), erralunga (honey grevillea), lupa (acacia bush seed), kaltjirra and arlparrantji (bush tomatoes). We see erranta (red-tailed black cockatoo), elintja (galah) and pirlkara (crested pigeon) and all the other birds too. Hayley Panangka Coulthard, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Hayley Panangka Coulthard_Erraanta and elintja_ Tnyam-iparta.jpg

title: Nganampa Ngura – ngunytju munu untalpa (Our Country – mother and daughter)
description: Our collaborative paintings are about the Country around Indulkana in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia. This is our home, it is beautiful and special Country. We have our family history here, and this Country holds important Tjukurpa (cultural heritage) for us Yankunytjatjara people too. Sharing the process of painting with my daughter is really special. As we work, I share stories with her about what it was like here when I was growing up, how it has changed over the years. When I was younger, the older ladies here taught me a lot about Country and culture, and I love sharing this with my daughter through our paintings. Betty Chimney, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Betty Chimney_ Raylene Walatinna_Nganampa Ngura _ ngunytju munu untalpa _Our Country _ mother and daughter_.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Betty Chimney_ Raylene Walatinna_Nganampa Ngura _ ngunytju munu untalpa _Our Country _ mother and daughter_

title: Franklin River valley, lutruwita/Tasmania (topographic relief)
description: The Franklin River winds its way through west lutruwita/Tasmania. Rugged and wild, this breathtaking terrain has sparked a lasting legacy of wilderness protection and activism. Notably the works of artists Bonita Ely, Olegas Truchanas and Peter Dombrovskis helped turn this river into a catalyst for environmental protection. Through abstraction and reduction, this work pares back the landscape to its bare topographic features. Drawing on our continued exploration of the healing qualities of charcoal, this work seeks to find balance and harmony in a time of increased environmental vulnerability in the face of human-induced climate change. Wona Bae and Charlie Lawler, 2022
image_path: data/images/2022_Wona Bae_ Charlie Lawler_Franklin River valley_ lutruwita_Tasmania _topographic relief_.jpg
image_stem: 2022_Wona Bae_ Charlie Lawler_Franklin River valley_ lutruwita_Tasmania _topographic relief_

title: Implexis
medium: watercolour, pencil and gouache on pine board, in found walnut cabinet
description: I love the Australian bush and all she shares with us. There is so much to learn and discover. With this in mind, I created Implexis (‘interwined’ in Latin) based on the four seasons as I know them – summer, autumn, winter and spring – and intertwined them with the six seasons from the Indigenous D’harawal calendar – Burran, Marrai’gang, Burrugin, Wiritjiribin, Ngoonungi and Parra’dowee. Hidden throughout the painting are D’harawal flora and fauna that suggest the change of season. There are also Indigenous words, while the river glides seamlessly through the landscape with sea creatures. Julianne Ross Allcorn, 2022

title: Christmas cloud
description: I began painting clouds as a kind of backdrop for my figurative works, although they soon revealed themselves as the centrepiece. They are figurative beings, towering and monumental. Their formations are in a state of constant flux. The painting is one moment in their time of continuous change. This particular cloud, a Cumulus congestus, was painted from a formation accumulating on the afternoon of Christmas Day, 2021. These clouds bring rain and unsettled weather, but from afar it was a perfect day. Clara Adolphs, 2022

title: Vinbana-Yura-Mulka (Breakneck Gorge) I
description: John R Walker has regularly visited the northern Flinders Ranges, on Adnyamathanha Country in South Australia, since 2016. The gorge depicted in this work runs through a belt of ancient, twisted rock – an area that amazed the artist for its geological complexity and variation. ‘Breakneck Gorge is not a place that initially took my attention. It is quiet and a bit neglected; however, it had begun to haunt me,’ says Walker, a 15-time finalist in the Wynne. ‘The painting almost took me by surprise. I had started working on a canvas and suddenly realised what it was. I then asked Adnyamathanha artist Kristian Coulthard for the correct name for this place: Vinbana-Yura-Mulka.’ Walking extensively across the ranges making drawings with gouache to capture the timeless spirit of the Country, Walker later made this painting flat on the floor of his Braidwood studio in the NSW Southern Tablelands, on Walbanga Country.

title: Tapestry: lotus
description: A first-time Wynne Prize finalist, Louise Zhang was inspired to record her experiences of sitting by the lotus pond in Sydney’s Royal Botanic Garden, located on Gadigal land. The work stems from a practice of ‘slowing down and simply being,’ Zhang explains, with the act of painting offering an opportunity for reflection and providing solace. Found at the harbour end of the gardens, the pond is a site that Zhang has enjoyed since childhood. In this painting, Zhang imbues the ancient Chinese symbol of the lotus with a pop sensibility. Flourishes of purple–pink coalesce around a focal point that frames a blossoming lotus – a flower traditionally associated with elegance, longevity and other virtues. ‘I’ve reflected deeply on the concept of an “Australian landscape”,’ Zhang says. ‘My artwork has been interpreted in this context before but was never fully recognised as “Australian”, like me. I see my experiences with our landscape as inherently “Australian” and intertwined with my Chinese–Australian heritage.’

title: Personal plethoras
medium: synthetic polymer paint on hand-carved wood
description: Growing up, Christopher Zanko formed impressions of local architecture that helped him build a ‘cognitive map’. Particular houses and streets in the Wollongong suburbs of his childhood, on Dharawal land, became markers for him in a place now undergoing development and gentrification. Zanko, a two-time Wynne finalist, noticed this house while walking to his daughter’s preschool in 2023. ‘The arrangement of shadows cast by the eaves and the glimpse into the backyard gave a sense of familiarity,’ he says. Rendered large, with confident lines, the house’s textures of red brick, speckled concrete, pruned bushes and drawn blinds have been lovingly depicted. Zanko carves into the wooden surface with small hand chisels before adding colour, then accentuates the work’s graphic details and deep shadows by applying black paint with a roller. While the changing nature of our environment can be challenging, Zanko notes, it ‘is arguably necessary, especially considering Australia’s current housing crisis’. ‘Through my process I seek to give a sense of permanency to the narratives and experiences of suburban Australia.’

title: Nyalala gurmilili
description: Depicted here is the miwatj, or ‘sunrise side’ in Yolŋu Matha. It relates to the north-easternmost part of Arnhem Land, Northern Territory, that receives the first light as the sun rises in the east. This is the landscape during April and the start of Miḏawarr (the harvest season following the wet), when the earth receives sudden surprise showers during what is meant to be the dry. Djakaŋu Yunupiŋu, a first-time Wynne finalist, paints lore connected to the beach at Garriri/Rocky Bay, through songs gifted to her by her father, renowned artist Muŋgurrawuy Yunupiŋu. It refers to the tale of the Djulpan, a group of Yirritja spirit women who are a constellation – the Pleiades. These are the seven sisters, who come together to gather food. They then retreat over the northern horizon to their homes. If fires are lit before these celestial movements take place, the Djulpan become sad and cry, as is evident in this painting. This work is now in the collection of the Art Gallery of New South Wales.

title: Kulata punu
description: This is Watarru, a site in the south-west of the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands where the kulata tree grows abundantly among rocky outcrops and tali (sandhills). There is a distinct punu (wood) that first-time Wynne Prize finalist Frank Young uses to craft kulata (spears). This is a special skill, shared from grandfather to grandson, and has been championed in recent years by the Tjilpies (senior men) from across the Lands as part of the Kulata tjuta (many spears) project. This initiative was originally conceived by the Amata community and its artistic outcomes have been seen across national and international exhibitions. Young is recognised for his pairing of flattened landscapes and two-dimensional objects with Pitjantjatjara text. Often used as a framing device, the language in this work recounts both the Wanampi and spear tjukurpa, along with methods of crafting kulata. This is a laborious process that includes cutting and burning the punu, wrapping the sharpened head with kangaroo or emu sinew, and binding it with a resin made from mulga or spinifex.

title: Kitar
description: Tiger Yaltangki’s fantastical works often explore the divergent influences that have shaped his world view, offering a unique image of life in Indulkana on the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia. As Yaltangki is largely non-verbal, his art practice also represents a vital form of self-expression. Yaltangki’s oversized and exaggerated electric kitar (‘guitar’ as spelt and pronounced in Pitjantjatjara/Yankunytjatjara) draws on the artist’s love for music, particularly classic rock bands Creedence Clearwater Revival and AC/DC. This form has become a recurring motif within Yaltangki’s practice, alongside the words ‘ ROCK N ROLL’, which hover over an abstract topography of colour. On the alternate face of the kitar, a humanoid form emerges. This is Mamu, an Aṉangu spirit person or creature. This is the first time Yaltangki has been selected as a Wynne Prize finalist.

title: Untitled
description: A few years ago, John West Tjupurrula took his first helicopter trip. ‘Seeing my Country from above changed my style, and now I paint my Country that way,’ he says. Using photographs and drone footage as source material, Tjupurrula has painted an aerial view of Palipalintja, a site of swamps and rock holes, found just west of Jupiter Well in Western Australia. ‘I chose colours that reminded me of the landscape at that place.’ Tjupurrula’s mottled fields of colour reveal the path taken by a large group of Tingari men who camped at this place while on their journey to Kiwirrkurra in the distant past. The events associated with the Tingari cycle are restricted knowledge, yet the adventures of these ancestral beings are enshrined in songlines. As the son of two recognised artists who worked through Papunya Tula Artists, Freddy West Tjakamarra and Payu Napaltjarri, the first-time Wynne finalist appreciates the importance of documenting cultural knowledge through art and sharing it with younger generations.

title: Untitled
description: ‘I wanted to paint this work for the Wynne Prize and I wanted it to be big,’ explains Bobby West Tjupurrula. ‘I imagined the place, Palipalintja. I can see it when I close my eyes,’ he says, speaking about a location for which he is a senior custodian. In this painting, Tjupurrula has captured Country in a mesmerising hypnotic form. His idiosyncratic visual language of multidirectional chevrons reverberates from and demarcates important sites that relate to the actions of the Tingari around the area of Palipalintja in Western Australia. Ancestral figures, the Tingari travelled over vast stretches of the Western Desert in the distant past, with their actions and interactions shaping Country. Tjupurrula is a leading artist and member of Papunya Tula Artists, where his father Freddy West Tjakamarra was a founding member. This is his first time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize. The work of his brother, John West Tjupurrula, is exhibited nearby.

title: Little by little
description: Robyn Sweaney has always been drawn to the exteriors of modestly sized Australian homes. This painting of a permanent caravan site in Wooli Holiday Park captures a slice of life in the unassuming northern NSW coastal town on Bundjalung Country, a few hours south of the artist’s home in Murwillumbah. Struck by the poignant contradiction of a ‘permanent’ caravan, Sweaney observes that these converted dwellings demonstrate ‘resourcefulness, adaptation and a human need for close connection to the landscape and others within it’. She documents a carefully placed blue vase and row of chairs, hinting at the communal outdoor life of the home’s absent owners. In the face of modern dilemmas like homelessness and a national housing crisis, Sweaney considers what a home is or could be. A five-time Wynne Prize finalist, Sweaney won the Trustees’ Watercolour Prize in 2019.

title: Ngura tali – sand dune Country
description: Rene Sundown has fond memories of growing up in bushland with her siblings near Erldunda, Northern Territory. As a young woman, she found work at the nearby Erldunda Station, where her father also worked as a stockman. Sundown regularly paints this imposing desert landscape, dominated by sand dunes and spinifex grass. ‘Nganana rawangku inkapai mangka-mangkangka, kutin-kutinkatinyi,’ says Sundown, detailing how, while collecting milkweed, she and her siblings would often playfully tumble down a sand dune and roll to the bottom. Evident from her use of colour and the marks she makes, Sundown has portrayed a changing landscape, reflecting how the tiniest particles of Country shift and move. Sundown is a senior artist working through Iwantja Arts in Indulkana in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands. This is her first time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize.
image_path: data/images/2024_Rene Sundown_Ngura tali _ sand dune Country.jpg

title: Dancing teddy
medium: synthetic fur, textile, buttons, steel, plastic, motor, foam, video camera, monitor
description: EJ Son is fascinated by teddy bears as objects representing innocence and human comfort. Son’s larger-than-life Dancing teddy toys with this perception, incorporating swaying limbs, a camera for an eye, and a monitor displaying a live video feed of its onlookers. The dancing sculpture imitates the movement of South Korean ‘broadcast jockeys’: the term used for live streamers on the country’s popular video-streaming platform AfreecaTV. In South Korea – where pornography is banned – molka or ‘hidden camera’ crimes are rife. Women are often the targets of these illegal cameras, concealed in bathrooms and other public places. For Son, the ‘cam girl’ streamers who dance for online spectators claim their agency in the context of an often invasive and patriarchal culture. ‘The bear serves as a performer on my behalf,’ says Son, a first-time Wynne finalist. With its themes of attention and surveillance, the work taps into both desire and anxiety: the impulse ‘to be seen, and the fear of being forgotten’.

title: Autumn light, Lake George/Werriwa
description: ‘For thirty years, I’ve been hugely intrigued by the mystery of Werriwa/Lake George,’ explains Luke Sciberras. ‘It is a vast flat area ringed by lovely low hills that catch the light beautifully. As it fills and recedes it transforms in a mercurial way from a series of ordinary looking sheep paddocks to a shimmering wetland teeming with birdlife.’ The lake is close to Kamberri/Canberra, with its north-western edge meeting the Federal Highway en route to Goulburn and Sydney. Sciberras remembers it as always being on his radar. On each approach, he would wonder how the perpetually changing lake might appear. A five-time Wynne Prize finalist, Sciberras recalls catching the train from Campbelltown to the city as a teenager to view the Wynne, which he regarded as ‘the most painterly inspiration I could find’.

title: Who said possession is nine-tenths of the law?
medium: watercolour and synthetic polymer paint on paper
description: In Joan Ross’s imagined Australian landscape, a colonial woman in 18th-century dress graffities a rock face with the word ‘MINE’. With its title quoting the commonly used expression ‘possession is nine-tenths of the law’, Ross’s painting refers to British colonial possession of an already inhabited land. Ross references the watercolours of colonial painter Joseph Lycett in this landscape, which is further transformed by hi-vis yellow and neon pink – synthetic colours that command attention, especially when applied to the natural world. ‘There is a greed about colonising someone else’s land, an agreed greed that continues today and a lack of sensitivity to the original inhabitants of this land and the land itself,’ says Ross. ‘Whenever I am in the bush I see signs of humans making their mark on nature. I see graffiti tags on rocks, I see love and hate, political messages, personal tags, swear words, initials and love hearts. There is a disconnection with nature and a self-centredness that defies care.’ Winner of the Sulman Prize in 2017, Ross is a two-time Wynne Prize finalist. A portrait of her by Anna Mould is in the 2024 Archibald Prize.
image_path: data/images/2024_Joan Ross_Who said possession is nine-tenths of the law_.jpg
image_stem: 2024_Joan Ross_Who said possession is nine-tenths of the law_

title: Yalpirakinu
description: This artwork portrays Adrian Jangala Robertson’s mother’s Country, Yalpirakinu, located north-west of Mparntwe/Alice Springs. Yalpirakinu is also referred to as Yuelamu. Robertson consistently paints this site to maintain his deep connection to the earth and engage with memories of family by documenting the desert mountains, ridges and trees. Working with a restricted colour palette, Robertson loads his brushwork with energy. He pushes and pulls his colour, reworking the image until it is complete. The influence of his mentor, the late Billy Benn Perrurle, is particularly evident within this painting. Recently, Robertson has been experimenting with depicting Yalpirakinu within a frame, as if he is looking through a window and viewing Country from afar. Robertson is a long-standing member of Bindi Mwerre Anthurre Artists, working through the studio since 2002. This year, he has been selected as a finalist in the Archibald and Sulman Prizes as well as the Wynne Prize.

title: The miracle of the trees
description: This painting by two-time Wynne finalist Jude Rae was inspired by a regenerating bush landscape at Mount Wilson in the Blue Mountains region of NSW . Mount Wilson is close to the site of the Gospers Mountain fire, part of the devastating ‘mega-blaze’ that blanketed the state with smoke in late 2019. Having lived in the Blue Mountains area as a child, Rae was unnerved during a visit to Mount Wilson in 2023 when she experienced ‘the burnt remains of the treetops snapping off in high winds and falling on the car.’ In the painting, a deep orange underlayer provides a menacing reminder of the destruction wrought by fire. But green plumes of epicormic foliage – a fire-adaptive trait of eucalypts – blossom over blackened trunks. ‘It is a meditation on this miraculous phenomenon in the context of climate change,’ says Rae. The work’s striking vertical composition suggests a transcendent quality to the trees’ regeneration.
image_path: data/images/2024_Jude Rae_The miracle of the trees.jpg

title: my really beautiful wonderful city wow
description: This painting by Jason Phu is an unmistakable ode to Sydney. ‘I spend a lot of time in the city,’ says the two-time Wynne finalist and 2015 Sulman Prize winner. He explains the painting’s origins: ‘I remember once, a man attempted to dodge a bull made of bronze the size of a small truck, only to be seen later picking up his bloodied teeth from the sidewalk. I remember rivers of thick mustard ammonia flowing from sandstone walls. I remember little tiny cups of glowing liquid in blue, green or pink that fuelled the cars and people alike. I remember the deep hum and thump of giants in walls of slime and salt. I remember light’s pinpoint accuracy of sharp green lasers becoming blurry tear-speckled lights of red and blue. Oh wild prophets shouting my great-grandmother’s place of birth and their mother’s before that, before expelling their stomach’s contents to divinate. This all on a rainy Saturday eve.’
image_path: data/images/2024_Jason Phu_my really beautiful wonderful city wow.jpg
image_stem: 2024_Jason Phu_my really beautiful wonderful city wow

title: Atherreyurre
description: This is Atherreyurre in Mparntwe, also known as the Telegraph Station in Alice Springs, Northern Territory. It is a site of significance for Thea Anamara Perkins, a two-time Wynne finalist who is also exhibiting in this year’s Archibald Prize. This is where her grandfather Charles Perkins was born and where he rests, and where her great-grandmother Hetty Perkins worked. The seductive beauty of Perkins’s work, with its atmospheric evocations of burnished light, draws viewers into a tender trap set to expose the looming threats of climate inaction. ‘Beauty can be a vehicle to convey hard truths,’ she says. ‘I chose to paint last light as time is running out. I’m communicating the essence of a place that I hold dear to prompt others to think of what we value.’ Thus, this painting, which echoes the energetic rhythms of landscape, becomes a portrait of the people connected to it. As Perkins explains, ‘Country is family.’

title: Man with sore finger
description: ‘ Man with sore finger memorialises the events of a DIY home repair accident where my partner cut his finger using a circular saw. Without saying a word, this resourceful and independent man left the house to walk up to the local hospital, returning with his arm in a sling and a bandaged finger,’ explains Sassy Park, a first-time Wynne finalist. This intimate sculpture references terracotta figurines from Greece and Rome and the 18th- and 19th-century statuettes known as Staffordshire figures – ceramic animals and people designed for display in English homes. In deliberate contrast to larger works of heroic statuary, Park is drawn to more empathetic, small-scale commemorations of everyday events. Modelled in clay at the artist’s studio on Gadigal land in Sydney, this sculpture was glazed and fired multiple times over months to achieve Park’s desired effect. The final surface retains marks of the artist’s fingers and her shaping process. ‘It is a practice full of expectations, disappointments and serendipity,’ she says. ‘The vulnerability of the beloved resonates with the idea of ceramics itself.’

title: Kunmanara (Jimmy) Pompey on Country
description: ‘I wanted to paint this place and include a portrait of my father-in-law,’ says Vincent Namatjira. ‘He was an important influence and role model to me when I was starting out as an artist. As well as being a stockman, my father-in-law was a wonderful musician, and a great artist who painted his memories. I’ve painted him on Country, with his guitar and a wild horse running free.’ In addition to presenting this moving tribute, Namatjira has captured the serenity of Indulkana Ridge, not far from Indulkana in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia. Namatjira’s stylistic conventions draw on the legacy of landscape watercolour painting, as championed by his famous great-grandfather Albert Namatjira, to create a singular vision of Country that is both harsh and imposing yet rendered with affection and dense with meaning. This is the first time Namatjira has been a finalist in the Wynne Prize. In 2020, he became the first Indigenous Australian to win the Archibald Prize, with a portrait of Adam Goodes.

title: Yarrinya
description: This is Yarrinya, the land and waters within a region of Point Blane in Blue Mud Bay, Northern Territory. First-time Wynne Prize finalist Barayuwa Munuŋgurr is the Djuŋgayi (cultural guardian) for this place. Depicted is the ancient Munyuku clan story that comes from Country, enshrined in manikay (song poetry) that recounts the events that shape the essence of Yarrinya and the ancestral powers that reside here. Between the bands of miny’tji (sacred clan designs), pulsing and choppy sacred saltwater flows and a reef emerges. Within are the bones of the whale Mirinyuŋu, who was murdered with stone knives by his two brothers. In Munuŋgurr’s words, ‘Dhuwaya miny’tji Yarrinyayi, Bangulŋay, Banguli, Gurrukurryay, Mayaŋarakay, Dharulyi, ŋunhi yukurra nyark’nyark’thun gapu, Manbuyŋa, Garŋgirr ga yur’yuna märi maṉḏa Maḏarrpa ga Dhaḻwaŋu Ṉuŋburindi Waṉa Marrwalami maṉḏa.’ Here, Munuŋgurr recalls the salt waters joining with those of his maternal grandmother’s – separate clans within the Yirritja moiety. Thus, this artwork can also be considered a portrait of his mother and her maternal grandmothers.

title: mudhay burrugarrbuu- bula / Possum Magpie also
medium: bush contact print on woollen blanket, possum fur screenprint, cotton and synthetic thread
description: ‘We had a visit from over 20 magpies when our daughter was born,’ says first-time Wynne finalist Juanita McLauchlan. ‘They sang at the back door when we brought her home – a welcome we had never experienced. She is almost four and the magpies run up to us on the street to this day.’ McLauchlan has contact- and screen-printed, stitched, and embellished Wiradjuri Country – Wagga Wagga, where she currently resides. While a guest to these lands, her work captures the importance of home, and celebrates the strong Wiradjuri Elders who have held on to culture. McLauchlan says that this work is also an ode to the guardians who watch over her daughter: the magpie who sings to her in the daytime, and the possum who watches over her at night. The materiality of the work also purposefully complicates the history of Aboriginal and European settler relations across the southeast of Australia. At the time of settlement, Aboriginal families received rationed blankets, which served as an informal census.
image_path: data/images/2024_Juanita McLauchlan_mudhay burrugarrbuu- bula _ Possum Magpie also.jpg
image_stem: 2024_Juanita McLauchlan_mudhay burrugarrbuu- bula _ Possum Magpie also

title: Cape Pillar, Tasman Sea
description: Cape Pillar, Tasman Sea depicts the landscape of the Tasman Peninsula in Tasmania’s remote south-east. When Noel McKenna visited Cape Pillar many years ago, he was struck by the sense that it was untouched by human presence and observed ‘a stillness which borders on ancient’. McKenna’s rose-coloured palette and simplified forms lend a poetic quality to the landscape, where a lone figure is dwarfed by the clifftop on which she stands. ‘One often sees this dramatic scene where the coastline meets the sea, sometimes with a perpendicular drop down to the water,’ McKenna explains. ‘This scene is done through my memory, the sailboat the only evidence of humankind.’ This is McKenna’s 27th time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize. Also a Sulman finalist in 2024 (a prize he previously won in 1994), he is a five-time winner of the Trustees’ Watercolour Prize.

title: Grass tree (at rest)
medium: pages from ‘Aboriginal words and place names’ by AJ Reed (1977), organic cotton thread, bamboo, rice starch glue, book cover board, acacia stool
description: ‘Our languages and the places they come from are intimately intertwined,’ explains Jenna Mayilema Lee, a first-time Wynne finalist. ‘This work seeks to take the misrepresentation of our words [as its substance] and very literally weave place and language back together into a truer form.’ Lee has woven a xanthorrhoea from many metres of handmade paper string, using pages from a decades-old dictionary of Aboriginal words and place names. It was her father who introduced the plant to Lee, teaching her about its various parts, which have been harvested and used by Aboriginal peoples since time immemorial. She also was taught that xanthorrhoeas were once derogatorily referred to as ‘black boys’. While this term is rarely used today, it has informed how Lee views the evolving nature of language, and her desire to rework traces of colonialism into figurative forms rooted in cultural knowledge. ‘My ongoing body of work transforms these fraudulent books into a pyrophytic plant which thrives under deconstruction and reconstruction,’ she says.

title: Ngayuku ngura – my Country
description: Muna Kulyuru is a respected artist, Aṉangu teacher and community leader working through Tjala Arts at Amata in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia. She has been painting since she was young, first through the schools at Pukatja/Ernabella and Amata, where she learned to mix colours and paint in the batik style. Now Kulyuru paints exclusively with acrylic, using punu (wood) sticks to lay down the important Aṉangu stories she wishes to showcase to the world. For this work, Kulyuru has painted her mother’s Country, the area of Watarru, found in the south-western corner of the Lands. ‘I teach my language and culture,’ says Kulyuru. ‘I paint my mother’s story; I pass down the stories about women dancing around the fire, where my mother was born.’ This is particularly evident in the way Kulyuru utilises colour with energetic vigour to look at landscape with affection. Her paintings are a celebration of the vitality of the Lands and the important stories attached to place. This is Kulyuru’s first time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize.

title: Moun.aw – Archer River story place
description: ‘Moun.aw is one of the most beautiful places on my Country,’ Janet Koongotema recalls. ‘The sand is really white, and the water is really clear and fresh. You can see all the fishes like barramundi, catfish and red snappers swimming around.’ Koongotema is a senior artist working with Wik & Kugu Arts and a two-time Wynne finalist. She has painted a sacred aak puulwuy (story place) called Moun.aw, located along the Archer River, a place of high cultural significance to the Winchanam clan and only accessible to traditional owners. ‘Moun.aw is really good, but you have to be careful when the tide comes in … not just because of Pikkuw (the crocodile), but because of the fairies that live there. They protect this place,’ says Koongotema. In this work, Koongotema has translated her weaving practice into paint on canvas to capture the shimmering colours of Country as it transforms with the light of day. She also gives literal form to Waangk Aw, the dilly bag story place near Moun.aw, that she draws inspiration from.
image_path: data/images/2024_Janet Koongotema_Moun_aw _ Archer River story place.jpg

title: Lake Baker
description: This is Lake Baker, a vast salt lake in Western Australia. Timo Hogan, a first-time Wynne finalist, holds cultural authority for this place – a right inherited through his father. Lake Baker is a site of both power and danger. Hogan explains in Pitjantjatjara that this notion is called mill-mill-pa, a term for the ‘dangerously sacred’. The tjukurpa of Wati kutjara (two men) is connected to Lake Baker. The two men are represented by Hogan as two small grass tussocks, whose tracks are visible upon the lake’s surface. Nearby, Wanampi, the powerful water serpent, carves out the lake’s boundary. Using a palette knife and a limited colour range of soft creams and yellows, Hogan has recorded Lake Baker from memory to show both the seen and unseen forces of the site. The success of Hogan’s practice is in his ability to emotively document a physical landscape shaped by power and presence. He presents Lake Baker as a sentient being brimming with meaning, song and dance, for those who have the means to see it.

title: Lingka
description: Simon Hogan has painted Lingka, a site near his birthplace in the Great Victoria Desert in Western Australia. For Hogan, there is no place of greater importance: when painting and retelling the stories of Lingka, Hogan’s connection to the earth is galvanised and becomes inseparable from place. While constructing this work, Hogan drew on his memories of visiting Lingka as a young man. He presents evidence of a landscape touched by ancestral beings who once had power and influence on a tectonic scale. His circular forms indicate a changing landscape after severe flooding, when the owl man, Wati wirutja was drowned, while his brother, the wedge-tailed eagle man, Wati walawuru, hunted for game nearby. Hogan’s precise dotting in bright colours to mimic the metamorphic powers that shaped this landscape have been laid down with deep intention. Hogan is a senior artist working from Spinifex Arts Project in Tjuntjuntjara. This is the first time he has been selected as a finalist for the Wynne Prize.

title: Untitled (the fear of committing a sin)
description: Untitled (the fear of committing a sin) is inspired by an object that Sophia Whitney Hewson, a first-time Wynne finalist, encountered at the National Archaeological Museum in Athens: an ancient Grecian death mask cast from the face of a five-year-old child some 2000 years ago. Hewson was struck by its grim echo in the online images documenting infant deaths in present-day conflicts. The artist was compelled to model her own clay version of the death mask, which she then cast in bronze. The chain attached to the bottom of the sculpture has several sombre associations, including the pull of gravity and tools for weight and measurement. With this sculpture, Hewson asks: ‘Why do we measure the death of one child as less than another?’
image_path: data/images/2024_Sophia Whitney Hewson_Untitled _the fear of committing a sin_.jpg
image_stem: 2024_Sophia Whitney Hewson_Untitled _the fear of committing a sin_

title: Grey nomadic visions
medium: synthetic polymer gouache and LED lights on two truck doors
description: Grey nomadic visions directs us to an everyday view from a driver’s seat: the rear doors of trucks that move commodities across Australia. Winners of the 2022 Sulman Prize, Claire Healy and Sean Cordeiro enliven the truck doors with gold paint, LED lights, a ‘Blackberry’ pattern attributed to 19th-century English designer William Morris, and a camel. Synonymous with nomadic cultures in the northern hemisphere, the camel – like the blackberry – is an invasive species in Australia, introduced for the transport of goods between desert outposts. Beyond these references, the artists also nod to Dekotora (Japanese decorated trucks); Yokohama-e woodblock prints, depicting Western traders in 19th-century Yokohama; and Razorback , the 1980s Australian desert-horror film. Inspired by a previous collaboration with Martu artists from the Pilbara region of Western Australia involving weaving and reclaimed car parts, Healy’s and Cordeiro’s darkly humorous work upends romantic notions of Australia’s sunburnt landscapes. Bringing the tangled connections between colonisation, consumption, leisure and environmental damage into our field of vision, its flashing red lights offer both decorative relief and instructive warning.
image_path: data/images/2024_Claire Healy_ Sean Cordeiro_Grey nomadic visions.jpg

title: Olive
description: Cutting, layering and sewing disparate pieces of second-hand clothing together, Julia Gutman reconstitutes people and experiences with woven matter. This textile and wire sculpture depicts a close friend cradling a whippet called Olive, on a day of intense personal grief. The frayed edges, loose stitches and wonky seams convey something of the uneven emotional textures Gutman recalls of that day. Loaded into Gutman’s textile works are the unknown personal histories embedded in old fabric. She explains the significance of her materials: ‘Clothes drape our bodies and move with us through life, they take on our smell and the contours of our form, so it makes sense that they feel like the closest thing we have to someone who wore them. I think garments often become physical artefacts of the past: stand-ins for those we have lost, or relics of who we once were.’ This is Gutman’s first time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize. She won the 2023 Archibald Prize for a painted textile portrait.

title: At the peak
description: This painting depicts a temporary sculpture erected by Juan Ford on Victoria’s highest mountain, Warkwoolowler/Mount Bogong. Collecting litter during a nine-hour hike up the remote mountain, Ford assembled it into a sculpture at the summit, incorporating branches and foliage as well. The result was a rickety cairn, briefly extending the height of the peak. Ford, who is a five-time Wynne finalist, explains that ‘such an absurd action is a recognition that for all our heedless actions and pollution (now found at the remotest corners of the Earth), we are insignificant before vast natural processes.’ Painted over a lengthy period from site drawings and photographs, the final work reveals no mountain vistas. We see only Ford’s assemblage against a wide blue sky – a meagre monument to contemporary human presence in a landscape he calls ‘huge and unknowable’.

title: Paralpi
description: This work depicts the sounds of Paralpi, a special place found just outside of Mimili on the eastern part of the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia. ‘Paralpi is a place where people come to embrace and celebrate children,’ says Fielding. ‘They are taught by the Elders how to move and mimic their clan emblem, and, for Mimili, this has always been the maku (witchetty grub).’ Paralpi is an extension of Fielding’s previous Inma series (2019–23), which includes the titular work that won him the 2023 Wynne Prize. Fielding’s scratchy application of Pitjantjatjara text as a stylistic element used to outline and define Country also captures reverberations of bodies performing the act of inma (ceremonial song and dance). ‘When this inma is sung, the sounds of the soprano, alto, tenors and baritone are thick, hitting the heart and then returning to the ngura (country),’ Fielding describes. According to Fielding, who is also a finalist in the 2024 Sulman Prize, this is a cyclical process unique to Aṉangu culture, which celebrates one’s interconnectedness with the land.

title: Nganampa Manta
description: This is an expanse of country found on the edge of Mimili within the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia. Robert Fielding, a first-time Wynne and Archibald Prize finalist, has returned to this place many times over the past 30 years. ‘When I first moved to Mimili, I was just learning my culture’s ways,’ says Fielding. ‘This was a place from which I could watch, observe, learn, and sit in silence, listening to country, listening to inma (ceremonial song and dance), watching from afar.’ Fielding’s painting layers photograph and memory to veil what should be kept secret from an uninitiated audience. His bold colours and overpainting give the landscape a sense of movement, heavily implying that this place is alive. This is a sentience formed from the beating heart of community, which the artist likens to the earth’s rhythm. ‘You can see far from up here, seeing all the people that have come before us, all the people yet to come,’ Fielding adds. ‘Iriti kuwari ngula – past, present and future – all connected in this earth.’

title: The three graces
description: Using a small brush and diluted underglaze, Nic Fern sketches verdant garden scenes onto her hand-built forms. Roaming these lush landscapes are naked figures reminiscent of Grecian athletes, or the countless depictions of the nude that appear throughout art history. Informed by Western art antecedents, Fern’s references include Michelangelo’s Renaissance figure sculptures, Paul Gauguin’s modernist renditions of Tahitian women and Pablo Picasso’s cubist distortions of the body. In this grouping, however, one of the vessels has been left unillustrated, with Fern wanting its hues and form to suggest a more natural portrayal of flesh. The first-time Wynne finalist describes her work as exploring the continuity between historical interpretations of the figure and ‘contemporary ideals of beauty and normative gender’.

title: Schrödinger the cat
description: Cast in resin from a plasticine maquette, Craig Elliott’s anthropomorphic form is frozen in the realisation of its own existential emptiness. Its hollow core takes inspiration from the story of Prometheus, the Titan in Greek myth who suffered the torment of having his liver torn out by an eagle every day for eternity. Elliott injects amusing pathos into this tragic figure by giving the sculpture cartoon characteristics – a pop-inspired trope that employs commercial imagery to convey themes of deeper significance. Having worked as a model-maker, character designer and animator, the first-time Wynne finalist teams comic-like familiarity with philosophical intent in this sculpture. The work’s title, Elliott explains, ‘is an absurdist play on the quantum theory of Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger, wherein a hypothetical cat may be considered both alive and dead simultaneously because its fate is linked to an event that may or may not have occurred’.

title: Opal Country
description: ‘The area I’ve painted is part of the Stuart Ranges, just north of Coober Pedy,’ says George Cooley. ‘This is a place I have visited many times since my early teens. It’s a place where I go camping, hunting and gathering bush tucker, and where opals are found.’ Cooley has worked from memory to paint this location, documenting the landscape and its spectacular mesas, ridges and sloping escarpments. He uses an aerial viewpoint to increase the sense of vastness and builds up rich layers of paint with a palette knife to celebrate the extraordinary beauty of desert colour, form and light. The work also draws from his many years of prospecting for opals on the land. Cooley began his career as a visual artist in 2021, working through the newly established Umoona Community Art Centre in Coober Pedy. This is his first time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize.

title: The Great South Coast wind power
description: Matthew Clarke’s paintings celebrate the marvels of his everyday environment on Gunditjmara Country in south-western Victoria, in and near the coastal town of Warrnambool. The region’s wind farms are a particular subject of fascination for Clarke. In this painting, he uses vibrant colour and pattern to describe their immense rhythmic presence amid vast green fields. The two-time Wynne finalist explains: ‘This is a painting about land use and the environment. My paintings of wind farms have often been described as sunflowers popping out of the landscape, but they are wind farms popping out of the landscape. I hope it has the softest political overtones. South-west Victoria is traditionally a conservative place and there is opposition to wind farms.’
image_path: data/images/2024_Matthew Clarke_The Great South Coast wind power.jpg
image_stem: 2024_Matthew Clarke_The Great South Coast wind power

title: Untitled
medium: linen thread, pigment and binder on linen
description: Unfixed from time and place, with vaporous, mirage-like softness, Armando Chant’s landscapes are ‘instigators for an imaginative engagement,’ he says. They emerge from a gradual process of abstraction that starts with found negatives of early-20th-century landscape photographs. Overlaying multiple negatives, Chant prints a composite image at a large scale and draws onto its surface. He then collaborates with artisans in India to embroider the composition onto linen. When the work returns from the artisans, Chant explains, ‘it is abstracted, changed; it is never what I expect’. The final step is to paint pigmented washes over the fabric, further diffusing the spectral image. A first-time Wynne finalist, Chant acknowledges his collaborators, Mohammed Waseem, Mohammed Irfan, Mohammed Imran, Mohammed Fahim and Mohammed Tasleem, for the embroidery on this work.

title: BOD (Buttercup)
description: Polly Borland’s bulging and asymmetrical figures bear no resemblance to the svelte silhouettes of classical sculpture. BOD (buttercup) relates closely to the first-time Wynne finalist’s Morph photographic series, in which she encases a human subject in a stocking and stuffs lumpy padding inside. For this sculpture, a padded figure was 3D-scanned to create a digital model, from which a mould was made. Both clownish and monstrous, Borland’s bloated beings prod our deepest fears about physical imperfection. They can also be interpreted as visualising psychological anxieties, such as our drive to present a defined and cohesive self to the world. Abstracting bodies and bringing them to an ambiguous state lends them mythical qualities, Borland believes, with the potential – like a chrysalis – to metamorphose into something else.

title: Bush holiday dreaming
description: ‘My paintings are about my Country, my landscape, my culture, my family, and the Tiwi people of Pirlangimpi and their way of life,’ says Leon Russell Black. He has painted Melville Island, the largest of a group known as the Tiwi Islands, off the coast of the Northern Territory. Specifically, Black has documented the parts of his father’s and mother’s Country that he deeply loves. He has included Jurrupi/Jessie River, which he has connections to through his father, and Yapalika/Maxwell Creek, through his mother. Black’s unique composition and mark-making is suggestive of an artist painting with purpose. His scratchy, geometric linework reveals the places where the artist likes to fish, hunt and gather. ‘I like going into the mangrove to collect jukwarringa (mud mussels), kurumpuka (mud crabs), piranga (long bum) and yuwurli (mangrove worms),’ he explains. Black is an early career artist working through Munupi Arts. This is his first time in the Wynne Prize.

title: Digitalis
description: Although tiny, Natasha Bieniek’s Digitalis conjures the extravagance of nature’s largesse – a scene of bobbing flowers, gleaming foliage and rolling clouds. It depicts the lush Burnley Gardens, a short walk from the artist’s inner-Melbourne studio. The gardens contain some of the oldest trees in the city and are a common subject for Bieniek, who won the Wynne Prize in 2015 and is also a finalist in the 2024 Archibald and Sulman Prizes. A proponent of the miniature painting tradition, Bieniek presents one of her smallest works to date. Informed by 16th-century French and English miniatures, it also has its origins in a more contemporary, scaled-down image. As Bieniek explains: ‘We are obsessed with recording and documenting our surroundings, and as a result, often experience our environment through screens. Digitalis was painted directly from an iPhone image. The title is the scientific name for the flowering plant foxglove, which features in my painting, but it also points to my interest in digital culture.’

title: The fighters
medium: ceramic, textile, wood, cardboard, underglaze, synthetic polymer paint, enamel
description: ‘In the wake of the referendum and with ongoing global conflicts pertaining to colonisation, I have found that art has been my coping mechanism,’ says two-time Wynne finalist Billy Bain. ‘This group of characters embody the unwavering intergenerational fighting spirit of First Nations peoples, particularly the grassroots physical protestors that I have encountered since moving into the city.’ For Bain, this work holds space for First Nations peoples and their experiences that are distinctly urban.
