description: During a weekend in Gerringong on the NSW south coast, HEGO was struck by the beauty of the sunrise and early morning birdsong as he sat on a headland overlooking the beach. Promptly photographing and videoing the scene on his phone, he shared it to an Instagram story, then paused. How often do we experience the natural world indirectly, through screens? With Zeitgeist , HEGO playfully acknowledges this phenomenon, and knows that viewers will engage with his artwork in a way that confirms this status quo: by photographing it and sharing it online. Interested in readymade sculptures and working with found objects, the artist was inspired to paint on an old phone screen after running out of canvas. While art can imitate nature, HEGO maintains that some things are impossible to re-create: ‘scale and temperature, feet in the grass, ocean spray, morning sunrise’. ‘I challenge you to walk outside and experience nature in real life,’ he says, ‘and walk inside an art gallery and see art in real life too.’

title: Flannel flowers under the wattle tree
medium: synthetic polymer paint on canvas, oil on birch plywood
description: ‘Flannel flowers, grevilleas, quince trees, kangaroo paws and towering gums. My grandparents’ garden occupies a place in my mind kept only for magical childhood things – a haze of whipbirds, infinite pathways and cicada shells,’ says two-time Wynne finalist Eliza Gosse. Like a threshold to another time, Gosse’s sun-warmed landscape centres on a mid-century Australian home and garden born of her imagination. The painting references images from past copies of Australian House & Garden magazine and is inspired by memories of her grandparents’ home in Gosford on the NSW Central Coast. Gosse celebrates the creativity and abundance of the cultivated Australian backyard in this work, depicting it in harmony with the plant and birdlife of the bush. ‘They took so much care and pride in [their garden] – something I feel our generation may have lost,’ she says. Painted in stylised forms that allude to popular culture and contemporary design, Flannel flowers under the wattle tree preserves a present-day longing for the past.
image_path: data/images/2025_Eliza Gosse_Flannel flowers under the wattle tree.jpg
image_stem: 2025_Eliza Gosse_Flannel flowers under the wattle tree

title: Cumberland / Wallumatta and Wanne
description: Joe Frost’s paintings are built up slowly in layers, large brushstrokes adding wet washes over dry. Like the ever-changing topography of the urban environment, Frost’s canvases undergo gradual transformations as he works. A first-time Wynne Prize finalist, Frost has been drawing and painting Western Sydney’s Cumberland Plain for three decades. He says, ‘I was born in the steep hills that I now know to have been Wallumatta [in Eastwood] and, from an early age, was fascinated by the wide view onto the industrialised plain of Wanne [south, across the Parramatta River]. I found myself as a painter by depicting this area. It dwells within me.’ Across the work’s surface zags the Parramatta River, the main tributary of Sydney Harbour that runs out to the city’s west. Fascinated by the area’s industrial history, including the departure of the American chemicals manufacturer Union Carbide in the late 1980s, Frost finds stimulation even in ‘the sadness of these poisoned places’ – inspired by memories of their abandoned forms and open spaces.

title: Graveyards in between
description: ‘This is the tip, the dump, the car graveyard,’ says Robert Fielding. ‘But to me, it’s more than that. It’s my Bunnings, my hardware store, my museum. This place is alive with story. It’s full of things people think are useless – scrap metal, burnt-out cars, old tyres – but I see memory in every bit of it.’ ‘This painting is connected to my earlier photographic series Graveyards in between ,’ says Fielding. It was painted specifically for this year’s Wynne Prize. ‘Last year, when I was a finalist, I saw so many paintings of landscapes that felt stuck in the past – empty places, like no one ever lived there. That’s not the truth of this country. This is my response, my challenge.’ Fielding is a two-time Wynne finalist and is exhibiting across all three prizes in 2025. At the heart of his practice is a desire to encourage viewers to ‘see’ Country. His work is about the act of looking, asking us to move between layers of dots and vivid colour to see the importance of the land in between.

title: Brunswick creek
medium: concertina book; ink and watercolour on paper
description: This intimate work depicts Midjimbil Creek, which runs off the Brunswick River on Bundjalung Country in northern NSW . Walking along the outskirts of a friend’s farm near the creek one day, Stephen Evans explains, ‘this body of water asked me to take a seat and have a mindful conversation’. He sat on the bank to paint the scene in a small concertina sketchbook. ‘It was a peaceful place,’ says the first-time Wynne finalist, who was struck by ‘the sunlight and reflection of eucalypts along with the stillness of the creek’. Carrying portable, compact art-making materials allows the Sydney-based artist to spontaneously capture everyday scenes as he encounters them. It is ‘the pockets of sight we neglect that make for meaningful subjects in a world where we are all consumed by moving too quickly,’ Evans says.

title: Cliff Hole, Bottom Bullock
description: The landscape along Cambalong Creek in Gunningrah, a property in the Monaro region of NSW , has been a recurring subject in Lucy Culliton’s paintings over the past ten years. The property belongs to her friend Charlie Maslin, a regenerative farmer who was also the subject of an Archibald Prize entry by Culliton in 2020. Of the property, she says, ‘Livestock are rotated in cell paddocks so the grass has long breaks from the wear and tear of animals. Charlie has built leaky weirs on the creek so large ponds hold water longer in dry times. Grasses and reeds grow along the edges of the banks so erosion isn’t an issue. All good farming practices, in my mind.’ A nine-time Wynne Prize finalist, Culliton takes an expansive view of the undulating landscape but also dwells in detail on blades of grass and dimpled clouds. Based on a smaller study painted en plein air (outdoors), the full-scale painting is electrified by blue sky, reflected on the surface of Cambalong Creek.

title: Civil Dawn Construct
medium: oil and synthetic polymer paint on linen and wood
description: ‘“Civil dawn” is a term used to describe the last moment before the sun breaches the horizon,’ says Dean Cross, explaining the title of his work. ‘On the morning I made this painting, the light was the colour of peach blossoms and my babies were asleep. Outside, there was a frost. Inside, I was in a cloud of warm breath.’ Cross, a two-time Wynne Prize finalist, has painted Walbunja Country, or Braidwood in NSW . He is an artist often described as being interested in the collisions of materials, ideas and histories. The beauty of his work, with its atmospheric evocations of morning light, is juxtaposed with the harshness of the repurposed timber he has painted on. Combined, this collage of material and thought becomes a sculptural assemblage that is complex and invites contemplation.

title: Baubo column
medium: earthenware-fired raku clay, glaze, lustre, epoxy resin
description: This statuesque work by Cybele Cox depicts the goddess Baubo, a character from Greek mythology. Early depictions of Baubo include second- and third-century- BCE terracotta figurines with heads that sit directly atop their legs. The goddess is a minor yet critical figure in the story of Demeter, the goddess of grains and harvest who falls into despair following the abduction of her daughter Persephone, and turns the land cold and barren. Only the dancing comic Baubo can cheer Demeter, restoring her will to find her daughter and beckon spring. This pearlescent large-scale sculpture honours the magical Baubo as a figure of ‘female power, friendship, laughter and unbridled freedom of expression,’ Cox says. She appears as a three-sided column to reference classical architecture and ideas of harmony associated with trios – including mind-body-soul and birth-life-death connections. ‘Much of my work is predicated on fantasy, tapping into the richness of the imagination,’ explains the first-time Wynne Prize finalist. Her Baubo stands on a laughing head as a playful expression of feminine strength.

title: Morning
description: ‘The story and journey in my artwork are about a time I remember when we lived on Country, where we went camping, hunting, and at night by the campfire, listening to stories being told by old people,’ explains George Cooley. The area he depicts is part of the Stuart Ranges, just north of Coober Pedy. ‘This is a place I know well,’ says Cooley. ‘I’ve visited it many times since my early teens.’ Cooley has worked from memory to paint this location, the spectacular coloured hills and flat-topped mesas of the Kangu-Breakaways Conservation Park. He uses an aerial viewpoint to increase the sense of vastness and builds up rich layers of paint with a palette knife to celebrate the extraordinary beauty of landscape and how the colourful hills transform under different light. The work also draws from his many years of prospecting for opals out on the land. Cooley works between the Umoona Community Art Centre in Coober Pedy and the APY Art Centre Collective’s Tarntanya/Adelaide studio. This is Cooley’s second time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize.

title: Military maneuvers 7 (after Rousseau)
medium: glazed earthenware tiles, overglaze enamels, gold lustre, wood, grout
description: ‘I wanted to convey dense, lush greenery in a figurative landscape,’ Casey Chen says of this painted ceramic work portraying a military fortress under attack. The scene is loosely modelled on depictions of China’s Taiping Rebellion (1850–64) by artist Wu Youru (1840–93), considered one of the first Chinese cartoonists. Rather than focus on the battle, Chen details the surrounding landscape, where pointer dogs observe the fire and smoke from outside the stronghold’s walls, dwarfed by plants and red peonies in the foreground and mountains in the distance. Chen’s inspirations include the jungle paintings of French artist Henri Rousseau, Dutch Delftware tiles and hunting scenes in medieval tapestries. His ceramics explore East Asian porcelain craft techniques and are decorated with an eclectic mix of traditional and contemporary motifs. In many of his vibrant works, references from Chinese literature, mythology and folklore merge with characters from pop culture, including the Japanese animations and American cartoons Chen watched as a child. This is the Sydney artist’s first time as a finalist in the Wynne Prize. A portrait of Chen by artist Sassy Park is in this year’s Archibald Prize.

title: Aura
medium: linen thread, pigment and binder on linen
description: In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, stereoscopes were popular devices for viewing landscape photographs in ‘three dimensions’. Two stereoscopic photographs – taken side by side to imitate the distance between the eyes – could be viewed simultaneously to give the illusion of depth. Armando Chant used the ‘otherworldly’ negatives from vintage stereoscopes to make Aura , enlarging, layering and drawing over the images to create an imagined landscape that retained the scratches and stains of the glass originals. Chant then worked with artisans in New Delhi to translate his composition into embroidery by hand. He completed the process of material transformation by reworking the surface with pigment washes, subtly evoking light and the ephemeral weather conditions of mist and fog. For two-time Wynne finalist Chant, these composite landscapes are images that we can all connect with: ‘The work is not about depicting a specific place, but through processes of erasure and negation an essence of place can be created and revealed.’ Chant acknowledges the contributions of artisans Mohammed Waseem, Mohammed Irfan, Mohammed Imran, Mohammed Fahim and Mohammed Tasleem for the embroidery on this work.

title: Song palm (stay forever)
medium: oil enamel and permanent marker on linen
description: ‘This work brings together several landscapes from my childhood,’ says Mark Maurangi Carrol, a first-time Wynne Prize finalist. ‘Instead of showing one specific site, the painting merges elements from different locations into a single, imagined scene. It is made from fragments – what I remember, what’s been lost and what still lingers.’ Carrol explains that he is interested in how memory shapes and informs how we understand a landscape. ‘Over time, details fade or shift, but the emotional connection remains,’ he says. ‘This painting reflects that process – how familiar places can become abstract or unclear. I wanted it to feel both recognisable and distant.’ Carrol’s painting process is heavily inspired by pāreu (wraparound skirt) dying and staining, techniques he learned in Avaiki Nui/Cook Islands. He built this composition by stitching smaller pieces of linen together to make a canvas, then pushing pigments through the reverse side until it reached his desired level of colour saturation.

title: Minyma pulka (big woman)
description: Margaret Campbell, a first-time Wynne finalist, has sculpted a naked woman sitting upright on a stool. Her body is unguarded, her gaze steady. This is Campbell’s self-portrait, but also a general expression of strong First Nations women. A Luritja artist from Warumpi/Papunya, currently working in Mparntwe/Alice Springs at the Bindi Mwerre Anthurre Artists studio, Campbell has been exploring self-portraiture since 2024. She is interested in giving form to the quiet embodied power of women who carry stories, Country and identity with them, no matter where they go. This work is heavily influenced by Campbell’s drawing practice and her research into depictions of women from varied sources, including coffee table–style art books and magazines. She is particularly interested in how clay as a medium can tell a story of identity that goes beyond appearance. By using material from the land, she infers that this woman quite literally holds Country within her.

title: Seven Sisters
description: This expansive landscape, built up with walka-walka (dotting), depicts the breadth of Amata in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands: from Atila/Mount Connor to Walinynga/Cave Hill, across to Alkanyunta and Kuḻi on the other side. This is home for three-time Wynne Prize finalist Nyunmiti Burton, but also part of the Seven Sisters story. ‘The sisters, they came through and travelled from Atila to Kuḻi, escaping from Wati Nyiru,’ she explains. ‘In the story, it is the oldest sister, and her leadership, that guides the sisters from the dangers of the world.’ Burton returns to this story each time she paints, and she enjoys experimenting with colour and composition. ‘I made this work especially for the Wynne Prize,’ she shares. This work is also a homage to the late Kunmanara Brady, who worked alongside Burton in the APY Art Centre Collective’s studio in Tarntanya/Adelaide. ‘She loved using these colours and I was thinking about her and remembering her when I made this work,’ says Burton.

title: Maralinga
medium: synthetic polymer paint, PVC glue and inkjet print on found silver platter
description: The bomb comes down and makes a big mess. It melts the sand, shakes the earth, poisons the ground. They bury it, but it’s still there – in the dust, in the water, in our memory. The story is still going on, that’s why I keep talking about it, so we can always remember. – Harriette Bryant First-time Wynne Prize finalist Harriette Bryant transforms objects that carry connotations of colonial domesticity into powerful conduits for storytelling. Inspired by her elders’ stories and her own research, Bryant paints the history of nuclear testing at Maralinga, South Australia, between 1956 and 1963. She reminds us of the lingering after-effects of the bombs and the displacement still experienced by survivors and their descendants. ‘I painted this on a silver platter,’ Bryant says, ‘because that’s how they served it. Whitefellas watching from a distance, sipping tea, while Aṉangu ran.’ Under the gallery lights, this silver platter glimmers, in stark contrast to the black puyu or mist that is said to have moved across Country. Bryant’s commentary heavily implies that this is how the Australian Government served up Country to the British: on a silver platter.

title: Soft spoken and proud
description: While creating this painting, Seth Birchall was ‘thinking about the glade and orchard as garden spaces – sites of renewal and sustenance, safety and opportunity’. On daily walks to his studio on Wangal Country in Leichhardt, Sydney, the first-time Wynne finalist contemplated public and private spaces. ‘I was imagining the public land being used for food production instead of lawn and ornamental trees,’ he says, reflecting on how fruit trees were once planted along roadsides so that coach drivers had food for their journeys. ‘Then I started thinking about grace, hospitality, charity and the hurdles to this way of thinking.’ Birchall’s work is based on a combination of found imagery and personal memory, including his experiences of apple-picking, a tree in his childhood backyard and hikes across abandoned farms to collect fruit. The bountiful apple tree in this painting stands proud behind a fence, while the full moon hovering over a mountain in the distance gives the scene a sense of meditative tranquillity.

title: Microcosm
description: Natasha Bieniek often paints pathways or bodies of water to guide viewers into her miniature worlds. In Microcosm , she depicts Fitzroy Gardens in Melbourne’s inner east, a Victorian-era garden of large elm trees, ornate flower beds and ornamental ponds. ‘By painting on such a tiny scale my intention is to create an opportunity for the viewer to engage closely with the scene, inviting them to take a moment to pause,’ she says. ‘We live in a culture that’s dominated by phones and technical devices. The hand-held scale of my painting reflects this, but also aims to reinforce an intimate and real-life experience.’ Drawn to gardens that coexist with major cities, Bieniek believes these landscapes are imperative for our wellbeing, providing respite from the pace of city life. Bieniek was the 2015 Wynne Prize winner and this is her fifth time as a finalist. She is also a finalist in the 2025 Archibald Prize with a portrait of artist Cressida Campbell.

title: Ngura – Country
medium: 3 panels: synthetic polymer paint on linen
description: ‘Ngayulu apu tjuta palyalpai, minymana tjunanyi rockhole-ta itingka nyinanyangka palyalpai, minyma Tjuta nyinanyi itingka,’ says Alec Baker, explaining that he paints the rocky hills of his Country and the tjukurpa of the women near the rock holes. ‘Ngayulu tjunanyi uwankara. Kalaya tjina I been put him whole lot. Nyangatja, uwa tjukurpa palatja emu tjina ngura tjutangka. Ngura pulka, ngura miil-miilpa tjanampa.’ Baker shares that he paints everything connected to this place – the emu tracks, the story. Everything is important and connected. This collaborative painting by senior artist Baker and younger artist Eric Barney emphasises the value of opportunities for exchange between artists from different generations. Working together through Iwantja Arts in Indulkana, Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara ( APY ) Lands, South Australia, the artists have divided the work into panels to enable simultaneous creation. This allows Baker to sit with Barney, where they share stories through conversation and song. Barney has learned the significance of punu (trees) from Baker and other senior artists. Through visceral colours and a collaborative approach to composition, the artists create a captivating depiction of their home.

title: From the area
medium: mid-fire clay, glaze, gold lustre; wooden football bench
description: Perched as guardians of their domain, with golden canines flashing, are six black panthers crafted by Billy Bain, a three-time Wynne Prize finalist who is in this year’s Archibald Prize. He uses these big cats as conduits to channel his feelings about his displacement from the traditional lands of his ancestors, the Boorooberongal people. One panther, notably adorned with a golden mask bearing the artist’s likeness, reinforces Bain’s connection to the mysterious Lithgow black panther – a creature whose existence has never been confirmed, despite claims of sightings over decades. Bain aligns himself with the elusive panther – strong, capable of blending into the shadows, yet undeniably present. Bain critically interrogates Australian identity by engaging with colonial narratives and subtly undermining them. In this case, he humorously alludes to the Penrith region as being defined by its association with the local football team, the Penrith Panthers, whose success is a source of regional pride. From the area simultaneously champions Indigenous resistance by referencing the American Black Panther Party, a political organisation that influenced Bla(c)k Power consciousness among Australian Indigenous peoples.

title: I was a light across an ocean
description: I was a light across an ocean was inspired by the view from Adder Rock on Minjerribah/North Stradbroke Island. There, Holly Anderson would watch the sun set over the ocean and see ‘glitter paths’, a phenomenon created by light reflecting off rippling water. Anderson was reminded of this shimmering effect one day when looking at the striped folds of her bedsheets in her Meanjin/Brisbane apartment. ‘I saw an affinity between the ocean’s patterns and the stripy bed’s patterns and a painterly potential to collapse the two together,’ she explains. Anderson has depicted a glitter path where a body might lie along the bed, observing ‘a connection between the eye and the landscape, the body and the world’. The scene is rendered with subtle paint colours applied with a brush the exact width as the stripes themselves. ‘I wanted this work to conjure certain optical effects of a landscape through an everyday object,’ says the first-time Wynne finalist, who here explores ‘how the impression of a landscape might continue to be felt long after we’ve left it’.
image_path: data/images/2025_Holly Anderson_I was a light across an ocean.jpg
image_stem: 2025_Holly Anderson_I was a light across an ocean
